description: At 7:12 on Saturday night, when the Devils' Billy Guerin scored, the sports bar ignored it. At 7:20, when Scott Niedermayer put the Devils ahead of the Philadelphia Flyers, 2-0, the joint shrugged.

title: Virtual Reality and Virtual Spaces Find a Niche in Real Medicine; Ill Children to Get A 3-D Playground Out in Cyberspace
description: In an unusual collaboration, leaders in the medical, high-technology and entertainment industries are working to create a computer network that allows children who are seriously ill to communicate and play in three-dimensional cyberspace -- and to heal more quickly in the process.

title: Police Plan More Training In 9-mm. Gun
description: After a two-month study of the Police Department's new rapid-firing 9-millimeter semiautomatic handguns, senior police officials have decided to increase training in the use of the weapon. But department figures show no dramatic upsurge in shooting, and the officials say there is no reason to stop issuing the guns.

title: Bridge
description: The final of the Reisinger Knockout Team Championships began yesterday at the Manhattan Club, 27 West 72d Street, between teams captained by George Tornay of Manhattan and Richard Schwartz of East Elmhurst, Queens. At the midpoint, the Schwartz team led by 34 imps.

title: INSIDE
description: Broadway Celebrates Itself

title: That Moldy Song From the 1970's Isn't Disco
description: Yesterday was Turn Back the Clock Day, Part Deux, at Yankee Stadium. Only the giveaways weren't turn-of-the-century caps or photos of Ruth and Gehrig. Rather they were a passel of bromides and quotable quotes from George Steinbrenner.

title: Blaze Destroys a Lumberyard
description: The fierce thunderstorms that barrelled through central and northern New Jersey over the weekend left some damage in their wake. Lightning from the storms ignited a fire at Rahway Lumber that burned for more than five hours and destroyed the lumberyard's main building.

title: Dole Won't Return Warner Donations
description: Senator Bob Dole said today that he would not return $21,000 in political contributions from Time Warner Inc., whose music division he criticized this week for promoting violence. The Senator, a Republican of Kansas, said that by criticizing the company, he was showing that money could not buy influence with him.

title: Patents; U.S. proposes guidelines in an attempt to deal more effectively with software inventions.
description: LAST week the Patent and Trademark Office came a step closer to dealing more efficiently and effectively with software-related inventions. The agency issued proposed guidelines for patenting software embodied in computer hardware or disks. The agency has traditionally equated software with mathematical algorithms and other thought processes that cannot be patented.

title: Into Arcadia With Simon Schama
description: In his eye-opening new book, "Landscape and Memory," Simon Schama journeys through "the garden of the Western landscape imagination" while exploring the topography of cultural identity. A transplanted Englishman now rooted in American soil, Mr. Schama lives with his wife and their two children 20 miles north of New York in a house overlooking the Hudson River. Having grown up in London, he also has an affinity for cities.

title: Challenge In Three Parts
description: A beloved choreographic rite of spring has taken place. The School of American Ballet offered its 31st Annual Workshop Performances on Saturday afternoon and evening at the Juilliard Theater. Dancers between 15 and 20 were challenged by three fine ballets. Most of the challenges were met and the result was excitement.

title: Acid-Rain Pollution Credits Are Not Enticing Utilities
description: What do you get when you cross a free-market economist with an environmentalist?

title: Bosnian Serb Insists NATO Forego Air Strikes
description: Gen. Ratko Mladic, commander of the Bosnian Serb forces, has insisted that he will not give any information on an American pilot whose F-16 jet was downed on Friday until NATO renounces the use of air strikes in Bosnia, the United Nations said today.

title: Now Let's Consider an Airport Link That Uses Mass Transit; Try a Guided Bus
description: To the Editor:

title: Pushing Books by Chat and Pleading
description: The morning began with an embrace and negotiations involving Pat Conroy and his latest novel, "Beach Music."

title: Reporter's Notebook; Trying O. J. Simpson: $4,986,167 and Counting . . .
description: The O. J. Simpson case, a drama with its own cast of gladiators, chroniclers and commentators, also has its own accountant: Michael D. Antonovich, a member of the Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors.

title: No Headline
description: "This year was a battle; next year is a war." -- ASSEMBLYMAN CLARENCE NORMAN, Democrat of Brooklyn, on the state budget. [ B4:2. ]

title: Phillips's Bat Is Confiscated
description: Before one pitch was thrown yesterday, the California Angels had lost something: the leadoff hitter Tony Phillips's bat.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ROY LICHTENSTEIN is accustomed to seeing his artwork on display in all sorts of places and locales. Now, he has donated a limited-edition silkscreen print to the 175 United States embassies around the world.

title: Learning to Live With Alzheimer's
description: Alzheimer's disease is anything but a joke, yet jokes about Alzheimer's can be very funny. "Complaints of a Dutiful Daughter" is Deborah Hoffmann's funny, sad, loving, exasperated, wry and resigned account of trying to come to terms with her mother's vagrant mind. When we meet the two women, Deborah is Doris Hoffmann's only link to a muddled present and a dim past that grows darker by the hour.

title: New Tests on Rosi Also Positive
description: The World Boxing Organization junior-middleweight champion, GIANFRANCO ROSI of Italy, faced a two-year suspension and the loss of his crown as another round of tests yesterday confirmed that he took amphetamines before his winning title fight against the American VERNON PHILLIPS. "Second tests confirmed the results of the first test," CARLO MARAFIOTI, secretary of the Italian Boxing Federation, said yesterday in Rome. (AP)

title: Nagle, Former Jet, Cut by Colts
description: Quarterback Browning Nagle, who played only part of one game for Indianapolis last season, was released yesterday.

title: Old Coach Eyeing New Cup Conquest
description: Six victories short of yet another Stanley Cup championship with yet another team, Coach Scotty Bowman of Detroit is like a man holding aces in a poker hand while waiting to draw more cards.

title: JUDGE DISMISSES 2 MORE MEMBERS OF SIMPSON JURY
description: The judge in the murder trial of O. J. Simpson dismissed two more jurors today, leaving just two alternates in a case that is not even close to being concluded.

title: Thor Industries(THO,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: Thor Industries said strong sales and net income growth in buses helped offset increases in costs of materials and highly competitive pricing that affected recreational vehicle margins in the latest third quarter and nine months.

title: Where Justice Collides With Politics and Budgets
description: With the dismissal today of two more jurors cutting in half the number of alternates left, the star-crossed trial of O. J. Simpson has moved closer to the precipice. Whether it ends up over the cliff depends largely on District Attorney Gil Garcetti, who will surely weigh public opinion polls as closely as the statutes as the case approaches the brink.

title: About Drugs and the Happiness High
description: Calling the town of Wenatchee, Wash., "happy valley" is less a comment on the townsfolk -- who reportedly swallow no more Prozac than the rest of the nation -- than a tribute to Jim Goodwin, a local psychologist who has evidently never met a client he didn't think needed the hottest selling antidepressant drug in the land.

title: Do Movies and Rap Go Too Far?
description: To the Editor:

title: What Ailed Toulouse-Lautrec? Scientists Zero In on a Key Gene
description: DOCTORS, like anyone else, cannot help being fascinated by the sorrows and afflictions of the famous, and nothing can give a rare disease more cachet than to link it to one of history's luminaries.

title: Sports of The Times; Stevens's Game Within The Game
description: NOT many hockey players would thrive on the assignment: being on the ice whenever Eric Lindros is. The Flyers' 22-year-old center is listed at 6 feet 4 inches and 229 pounds. When he puts on his skates and his equipment, he's about 6-7 and maybe 250, as huge and as ornery as a rodeo bull. But the Devils' captain, Scott Stevens, smiled at the challenge.

title: When the Easy Way Turns Out To Be Hard
description: WHY is nothing ever easy?

title: VALUE HEALTH RENEGOTIATES STOCK-SWAP BUYOUT
description: Value Health Inc. renegotiated terms of its agreement to buy Diagnostek Inc. yesterday after Diagnostek posted a fourth-quarter loss. The stock swap is now valued about $420 million, down from about $502 million on March 27 when the agreement was disclosed. The transaction would combine two large pharmacy-benefits managers that distribute drugs and negotiate lower pharmaceutical prices.

title: Hitchcock Is No Mystery to Athletics
description: Baseballs ricocheted off the outfield fence, barely falling shy of disappearing for homers and barely keeping some of the more ornery Yankee fans from drifting asleep or drifting out of Yankee Stadium. Sterling Hitchcock fooled none of the Oakland batters last night, and the results were disastrous and too commonplace in this sloppy season.

title: Backers of Minister-Councilman Reassessing Their Choice
description: When the Rev. Lloyd Henry was elected to the City Council 17 months ago, Democratic Party officials from throughout New York City heralded the quiet, friendly Episcopal minister as their best hope of bringing together the Caribbean and Jewish constituencies in the diverse 45th Council District in Flatbush, Brooklyn.

title: We Can Afford Research
description: To the Editor:

title: Legion of Gloom: Devils Smother the Flyers Again
description: The Turnpike Series is becoming one continuous speed trap.

title: Algerians Still Hunger for Better Life Even More Than an End to Civil War
description: Algeria's Interior Ministry, an imposing U-shaped building anchored to one of the many hills framing this Mediterranean city, is surrounded by barricades and some of them are guarded by gun-toting, black-clad soldiers referred to as ninjas for their ski masks and their menacing demeanor.

title: Morgan Stanley Wins the Right To Jury Trial in West Virginia
description: In a ruling with implications for Orange County, Calif., the West Virginia Supreme Court decided yesterday that Morgan Stanley & Company was entitled to a jury trial there over its role in a failed state investment strategy in the late 1980's, and reversed a lower court ruling that had fined the Wall Street firm $56 million.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Justices to Look Anew at Seizing Property Tied to Crime
description: Continuing its critical examination of government authority to seize property, the Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether forfeiture laws must give property owners a chance to defend themselves as "innocent owners" who did not know their property was being put to an illegal use.

title: Broad Coalition Fights Insurer Limits on Hospital Maternity Stays
description: "Mothers of America are in jeopardy!" said Assemblywoman Rose Heck, her voice rising as she told five male members of the Senate Health Committee that insurance companies were imperiling women and their newborn babies.

title: Corrections
description: Two entries in the listing of new equity issues in Business Day yesterday, for offerings by the Sinclair Broadcast Group and Titan Wheel International, misidentified the lead underwriter. In both cases, the lead underwriter was Smith Barney, a unit of Travelers Inc., not Salomon Brothers.

title: Public Parks Exist for Everyone, Not Bikers or Hikers Alone
description: To the Editor:

title: Chimp Talk Debate: Is It Really Language?
description: PANBANISHA, a Bonobo chimpanzee who has become something of a star among animal language researchers, was strolling through the Georgia woods with a group of her fellow primates -- scientists at the Language Research Center at Georgia State University in Atlanta. Suddenly, the chimp pulled one of them aside. Grabbing a special keyboard of the kind used to teach severely retarded children to communicate, she repeatedly pressed three symbols -- "Fight," "Mad," "Austin" -- in various combinations.

title: Metal Refiner To Cut Products
description: Handy & Harman, a refiner of precious metals based in New York, said yesterday that it would no longer produce wire and strip karat gold for the jewelry and arts industries.

title: The Specter of Perots Haunts Major Parties
description: They are obstacles in the political parties' carefully plotted paths to the White House next year. They threaten to upset the ways that Presidential campaigns have traditionally been waged in this country. And they terrify Republicans and Democrats alike.

title: East Germany's Old Spymaster Talks: He Has Regrets, but Is Uncontrite
description: The old spymaster is thinking. He is thinking of the agents he sent over there, into the badlands, who languish now in jail while he is free; he is thinking of the loveless secretaries he sent his Romeos to seduce into betrayal and wrecked lives; he is thinking how he brought down a whole government and maybe changed history.

title: 9 Women Object to Settlement Of Bias Complaint at C.I.A.
description: The principal female employees who have threatened to bring a sex discrimination suit against the Central Intelligence Agency have asked a Federal judge to reject a proposed settlement of nearly $1 million from the agency, saying it is unfair and inadequate.

title: Freeing the Icicle
description: In the summer of 1940, the historian Samuel Eliot Morison warned Franklin D. Roosevelt that he was overwhelming his new Presidential library, not with books or files, but with things. The basement was stuffed with the President's favorite carriages, sleighs, farm implements, an automobile, even two iceboats.

title: Elected to Unite, Councilman Divides
description: When the Rev. Lloyd Henry was elected to the New York City Council 17 months ago, Democratic Party officials heralded the quiet, friendly Episcopal minister as their best hope of bringing together the Caribbean and Jewish constituencies in the district in Flatbush, Brooklyn.

title: People
description: * Ron Hawkins was named senior vice president and executive creative director at Cole & Weber, Seattle, a unit of the WPP Group, succeeding Bob Brihn, who left. Mr. Hawkins was previously a senior vice president and group creative director at Ogilvy & Mather Chicago, also part of WPP. * Paul R. Hansen was named president and chief executive at Telesession Corp., New York, succeeding Loren Zesch, who continues as vice chairwoman and was named to the additional position of executive director of the newly formed strategic business unit of the company. Mr. Hansen was previously president and chief operating officer at Ketchum/BRH&M, New York, a unit of

title: Moscow Journal; Lifting the Spirit (and Face) in Russia
description: In the bad old days of Soviet totalitarianism, the worker's paradise did deliver on at least one promise of equality for all.

title: Growth in Rice Cakes
description: The Quaker Oats Company said today that it would spend $16 million to increase its North American manufacturing capacity for rice cakes about 50 percent, expanding plants in Columbia, Miss., and Asheville, N.C. About 125 jobs will be created as a result. Sales of rice cakes have more than tripled in the United States in the last five years, the company said.

title: Market Place; Laura Ashley is spurning offers and hopes to revive itself.
description: OVER the last few years, Sir Bernard Ashley has received a procession of callers asking if he wanted to sell his controlling stake in Laura Ashley Ltd., the retail and fashion company he founded with his wife.

title: Signals From Another Era Leave Room for Human Error
description: Facing the fourth major subway crash in less than four years, Transit Authority officials and Federal investigators said yesterday that they would conduct a broad inquiry into the safety of the New York City subway system but would focus especially on the 75-year-old signal system.

title: Q&A
description: Male Calico Cats

title: Sergi Bruguera and the Blustery Day
description: There was another contentious afternoon of rain-wracked tennis at soggy Roland Garros, where the bluster today came from an unlikely source, the two-time defending champion Sergi Bruguera, a low-profile type who usually reserves his high intensity for his topspin.

title: Multimedia Games Without Gore
description: IT is never too early to think about Christmas. The year's biggest preview of coming attractions for the multimedia industry is the Electronic Entertainment Expo, held last month in Los Angeles. On the evidence of two days of mind-numbing demonstrations, it seems only a matter of moments until some Newton Minow of our time tars multimedia with a phrase as catchy and appropriate as the "vast wasteland" he hung on television.

title: Europeans Seek Access to Japan's Market
description: The European Union recognizes that Japan is working to eliminate regulations that block access to its markets but feels the country could do more at a faster pace, Sir Leon Brittan, the union's trade commissioner, said today.

title: I.B.M.'S BIG MOVE: THE TREND -- From Calculator to Communications Tool; As the Role of the Computer Changes, Companies Try to Keep Pace
description: In his "Dear Colleague" letter to I.B.M. workers yesterday, Louis V. Gerstner Jr. explained his company's $3.3-billion bid for Lotus Development Corporation as a vital step toward the high-tech workplace of the future. The two companies, the International Business Machines Corporation chairman wrote, were an ideal match.

title: I.B.M.'s BIG MOVE: THE BIDDER; I.B.M. SEEKS TO BUY SOFTWARE MAKER IN $3.3 BILLION BID
description: Stunning other computer companies as well as its prey, I.B.M. made a surprise $3.3 billion bid yesterday to acquire the Lotus Development Corporation for what would be the largest amount ever paid for a computer software company.

title: Pataki Is Half Right on Drug Laws
description: Sometimes it takes a "tough on crime" governor to stand up to drug war overkill.

title: Fast-Paced Evacuation Over the East River
description: Working from front to back, Officer Chuck Churchill moved from car to car inside the M train that had been struck by another train on the Williamsburg Bridge. He raced past the slightly injured, checked one man who had been knocked unconscious, and kept advancing to where the damage likely would be worst. People called out, asking for help; asking, with tears and a deadly seriousness, if the bridge was going to tumble into the East River.

title: After Dismissing Police Force, a Village Finds No Peace or Order
description: JUST about everyone in this quiet boating haven agreed that it sure paid to dump the police force. The village saved about $600,000 when it voted the scandal-plagued department out of its misery last fall. Residents were handed checks of $200 to $300 each from the savings. And the Town of Southold picked up Greenport's policing duties without a hitch.

title: U.S. Charges Ex-Prosecutors In a Drug Case
description: In what officials said was a striking demonstration of the corrupting influence of drugs on the legal system, a former senior Justice Department official who once led efforts to extradite leaders of the Cali cocaine cartel in Colombia was indicted today on charges of helping the cartel in a criminal conspiracy.

title: For CS First Boston, Yesterday Was a Return to the 80's
description: Yesterday was a red-letter day for the takeover specialists at CS First Boston Inc.

title: Actor Undergoes Surgery Intended to Allow Head Movement
description: The actor Christopher Reeve today underwent surgery that is expected to allow him to nod and shake his head, but doctors said no operation could give him movement below his neck.

title: Attack of the Aliens: Florida Tangles With Invasive Species
description: IT is a typical day on the Wacissa River near Tallahassee: crisp blue sky, herons stalking the shallows -- and, for the third time in an hour, Don Schmitz disentangling his outboard motor from the tendrils of an alien aquatic vine.

title: Acier Leroux reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: Acier Leroux said shipments rose 98 percent in the six months, to 178,900 tons. The company said the average price of its products rose to $ 737 a ton from $ 640 a ton a year earlier. It also said that the strong growth reflects the acquisition of Ennisteel Corp. last August.The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Love in the Ruins; Preservationists Fight to Save Crumbling Queens Aquacade
description: The Aquacade sits on the edge of a glistening lake in the heart of Queens, a remnant of the 1939 World's Fair.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Football National Football League BUFFALO BILLS -- Signed Chris Green, safety, to a one-year contract.

title: Olajuwon Plays Above the Rim, in the Stratosphere
description: Hakeem Olajuwon acknowledges that only a few players inspire him to read a box score in the newspaper and that Shaquille O'Neal is one of them. So as Olajuwon sat at his locker last week in Houston, brushing his hair and trying to be humble about the way he had just humbled David Robinson, it was not surprising that the brush stopped in midstroke when he was asked about O'Neal.

title: Trooper Is Hurt in Crash
description: A state trooper checking for speeders on the New Jersey Turnpike was critically injured yesterday morning when a car smashed into his parked patrol car. The trooper, Marvin R. McCloud, 31, was unconscious and on life support last night at Cooper Medical Center. David Whigham, 26, of Belleville, has been charged with careless driving. He was not seriously injured. The accident shut down the northbound lanes of the turnpike between Exits 1 and 2.

title: International Briefs; Motorola Urging China To Accept Technology
description: Motorola Inc. is hoping the Chinese Government will soon agree to accept the company's standard for wireless data transmissions. Robert Growney, executive vice president for Motorola, said yesterday that the negotiations with Beijing, which have been going on for two years, "might conclude this week."

title: Back to You, Mr. Mayor
description: Now that New York State's Governor and Legislature have agreed on a budget, the fiscal drama shifts to Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and the question of how he will play the cards dealt by Albany. It is one of the worst hands any mayor has ever had. Mr. Giuliani appears to have ended up with maybe half the $1 billion in savings he had sought from the state to close a $3 billion budget gap. He has little time to scramble for alternatives beyond the painful service cuts he has already warned might be needed.

title: Admitting Women to V.M.I. Shortchanges All; Aid From Taxpayers
description: To the Editor:

title: MORRISON KNUDSEN TO SELL ITS WESTERN AIRCRAFT UNIT
description: The financially beleaguered Morrison Knudsen Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Western Aircraft Inc. unit to two Wyoming investors as part of its plan to focus on its core engineering and construction business. Morrison Knudsen said it would receive several million dollars from the sale of the aviation maintenance company, but it did not disclose a specific amount. Morrison Knudsen, based in Boise, Idaho, said it planned to sell its nine million shares of Western Aircraft to Al Hilde, owner of Satellite Aero Inc., based in Jackson, Wyo., and Allen Hoyt, Aero's president.

title: 3,500 G.I.'s Going to Italy In Case U.N. Force Needs Aid
description: The United States today ordered 3,500 troops plus attack and transport helicopters to move from Germany to Italy for use in a possible evacuation or relocation of United Nations peacekeepers in Bosnia, senior Pentagon officials said.

title: U.S. Acted Properly in Guatemala Death
description: To the Editor:

title: Lind Back Home With Future in Doubt
description: JOSE LIND, who left the Kansas City Royals last week, has returned to Puerto Rico to be with his family and deal with personal problems, his local agent said from San Juan yesterday.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: LSI LOGIC CORP., Milpitas, Calif., a supplier of high-performance semiconductors, said it was getting in contact with the shareholders of its Canadian unit, LSC, to buy the 45 percent of the company that it does not already own for $44 million (Canadian). MODINE MANUFACTURING CO., Racine, Wis., which makes heat-transfer products for vehicles and for the industrial and building markets, signed a definitive agreement to acquire the Signet Systems division of Equion Corp., another auto parts maker, for about $54 million and the assumption of certain liabilities. TYCO INTERNATIONAL LTD., Exeter, N.H., a maker and provider of fire protection systems, said its subsidiary Grinnell Flow Control had acquired Unistrut International Corp., Ann Arbor, Mich., a manufacturer of metal framing systems, for an undisclosed amount.

title: Giving Up One Public Station to Save Two
description: Facing sale to a commercial buyer, New York City's public television station is doing a slow fade as part of a Darwinian bargain to assure the future of other public broadcasting outlets deemed fitter to survive: the city's two radio stations.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some copies yesterday about the Tony Awards referred incorrectly to the appearances of Glenn Close and Sir Andrew Lloyd Webber near the end of the ceremony. They were not onstage at the same time.

title: Gingrich Speech Disrupted
description: Protesters interrupted a luncheon speech today by Speaker Newt Gingrich, who was promoting his book "To Renew America" at the annual convention of the American Booksellers Association.

title: Only a Mirror
description: To the Editor:

title: How to Solve Air Traffic Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: Asbestos Award Is Thrown Out
description: Both Camden shipyard workers died of asbestos-related lung cancer, juries decided. But one man's widow was awarded $5.5 million while the other's survivors got $100,000.

title: No Headline
description: "The impact threw me back on the floor on my shoulder and arm. The next thing I know I see the M train coming through the metal right at me." -- HENRY SIMON, a passenger in the subway crash. [ B4:3. ]

title: Prices of Long Bonds Gain, But Short-Term Issues Slip
description: Prices of long-term Treasury issues rose yesterday, but without the furor of the previous two sessions as activity seemed to stall and the overall market finished mixed.

title: ADP OFFERS $12 A SHARE TO BUY OUT SANDY CORPORATION
description: The Sandy Corporation said yesterday that it had received a $12-a-share takeover bid from Automatic Data Processing Inc., a computer services provider based in Roseland, N.J. The offer for Sandy, based in Troy, Mich., a consulting and marketing concern, topped a previous bid for the company by Westcott Communications Inc. Sandy's stock was up $1.75 a share yesterday, or 17 percent, at $11.625, on the American Stock Exchange. A.D.P. was up 75 cents, at $63.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Approval for Trump Stock Deal
description: Donald Trump is going public.

title: CPI Corp.(CPY,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 29
description: (Loss)Operating earnings in the latest first quarter were $ 3.5 million, compared with $ 500,000 in the year-ago period, with the increase mainly due to Sears Portrait Studio operations. General corporate expense decreased 11.9 perent to $ 3.7 million, primarily due to lower employee health care costs.

title: Futch Believes a More Humble Bowe Can Be Champion
description: After making excuses, Eddie Futch can finally admit that Riddick Bowe did not attain the level of greatness they had expected after one glorious night two years ago.

title: Tax Bill Advances in Assembly
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's tax-cut plan is on track.

title: QUALCOMM STOCK IS UP WITH INTEREST IN ITS TECHNOLOGY
description: Qualcomm Inc.'s stock rose strongly yesterday as investors saw a greater interest in the company's wireless communications technology. Qualcomm, based in San Diego, said the NEC Corporation had signed a multimillion-dollar worldwide license agreement to use the company's technology, called code division multiple access, or C.D.M.A. Qualcomm's stock rose $1.50 a share yesterday, to $29.50, in Nasdaq trading of almost 2.8 million shares.

title: Senate Votes to Aid Tracing of Explosives
description: The Senate approved an amendment to an anti-terrorism bill today to require that dynamite and other commercial explosive materials contain tagging agents that would aid investigators in tracing bombs.

title: Rebuilding 'Bridges' Without Leaving The Novel Behind
description: Richard LaGravenese paused for a long moment after being asked what he thought of Robert James Waller's best-selling novel "The Bridges of Madison County."

title: International Briefs; VW Move Into Israel Breaks New Ground
description: Volkswagen A.G. will formally announce a $220 million investment today in an Israeli magnesium plant, the first major investment by a German company in Israel. While Daimler-Benz and Siemens A.G. have opened offices in Israel in the last two years, neither company has made a large investment.

title: Science Times E-Mail
description: Science Times has an electronic mail address for comments from readers about published articles and suggested areas of coverage:

title: Judge Puts Police Panel In City Hands
description: The dispute between Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and the City Council over how to monitor police corruption moved to State Supreme Court yesterday as the two sides argued before a judge who ultimately urged them to try again to resolve their differences.

title: Accounts
description: * Cellular World Corp., Dallas, to Dally, Dallas, to handle the account of the telecommunications retailer, previously in-house. The billings were estimated at more than $1 million. * Wesley's Ice Cream Co., Detroit, to F & D Advertising, Westbury, L.I., to handle its account, previously in-house. The billings were not disclosed. * The First Years Inc., Avon, Mass., to Holland Mark Martin, Burlington, Mass., to handle the account of the toy company, previously handled on a project basis by various agencies when the company was named Kiddie Products Inc. The billings were not disclosed. * Pharmflex, Malvern, Pa., to the Dess Group Inc., New York, to handle the account of the drug sales organization, previously handled by Robert A. Becker Inc., New York, a unit of Euro RSCG. The billings have not been determined.

title: Marketing Falls Short, Not Software
description: The Lotus Development Corporation has a history of developing the "killer app" -- a software application that creates such a fundamentally new and different use for the personal computer that it spawns a new market. Unfortunately for Lotus, the company also has a history of failing to fully capitalize on the markets it helps create.

title: Miscellany
description: * Leo Burnett Co., Chicago, has named Charles H. Stern as a consultant in the area of celebrity talent negotiations. Mr. Stern will continue to run his talent agency, the Charles H. Stern Agency, Hollywood. * True North Communications, Chicago, the parent company of agencies including Foote, Cone & Belding, has donated $100,000 to the United Negro College Fund for a fund-raising program, Campaign 2000: An Investment in America's Future.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: CRASH ON THE SUBWAY: ONE TRAIN SLAMS INTO ANOTHER ON BRIDGE

title: International Briefs; Welsh Water in Deal
description: Welsh Water P.L.C. said its international water and sewage unit had bought an additional 20 percent of ScVK, the Czech Republic's largest water and sewage company, giving Welsh a total holding of 35.6 percent. Welsh Water, which provides water and sewage service to Wales, said it had now invested $:7.4 million ($11.8 million) in the Czech company, which serves 1.2 million customers in northern Bohemia. Welsh Water, like many of Britain's 10 other water companies that became privately owned in 1989, has branched out extensively in recent years.

title: Observer; Some Vision Things
description: So many persons are now running for President that it makes your head shpin. Republicans have candidates you've never heard of. Every time the newspapers print another list of Republican candidates I examine it warily to make sure I'm not on it.

title: Not Forced to Watch
description: To the Editor:

title: By Design; Snuggling Up in Terry
description: Anyone who has snuggled into a terry cloth robe after a shower or a swim knows how comfortable, not to mention practical, the fabric is. Toss it on over wet skin, and it absorbs the dampness. When it dries, it looks the same as before, with no wrinkles. Designers have come to realize that terry cloth can be turned into good-looking beach wear that can go on to an alfresco lunch or even a shopping trip to a resort town.

title: Watery Grave of the Azores To Yield Shipwrecked Riches
description: THE Azores in the age of exploration were an obligatory last stop for ships returning to Europe with the wealth of the Americas and the Orient, full of gold and silver, silks and spices, gems and diamonds, porcelains and fine steels. Over the centuries, thousands of galleons and other ships stopped at the lush volcanic isles for rest and refreshment, bracing for the final push home -- often to no avail.

title: Warren Sonbert, 47, Film Maker, Is Dead
description: Warren Sonbert, an independent film maker, died on Wednesday at his home in San Francisco. He was 47.

title: Built to Meander, Parkway Fights to Keep Measured Pace
description: The Bronx River Parkway, whose graceful turns and arched stone bridges keep traffic moving through central Westchester County at a Model-T pace, has been designated by the National Trust for Historic Preservation as one of the 11 most endangered historic spots in the country.

title: Israelis Seize 45 From Hamas, Saying They Plotted Attacks
description: Israeli security forces have arrested 45 members of the militant Muslim group Hamas on suspicion of plotting to set off a car-bomb in Jerusalem and to hijack a bus to the Egyptian border as part of a series of attacks, the army said today.

title: New England Moves to Shift Five Primaries To Same Day
description: In a bid to increase their importance in the Presidential race, five New England states have moved to create a regional "superprimary" early in the contest.

title: The Quake That Hurt Kobe Helps Its Criminals
description: When an earthquake toppled entire neighborhoods here in January, the most striking and impressive thing for many Americans was the almost complete lack of looting.

title: CHRONICLE
description: A triumph in court for GLORIA ESTEFAN: Four years ago, EDDIE PALMIERI, the salsa band leader and pianist, filed suit against her, claiming copyright infringement for her use of the line "Oye Mi Canto" at the end of a song with that name. He claimed she had lifted it from his song "Pagines de Mujer."

title: INSIDE
description: Japan's Big-Time Looters There was no looting when an earthquake hit Kobe, Japan, but now gangs are muscling their way into the reconstruction effort. Page A3. For Algerians, Life Goes On

title: International Briefs; British Airport Profit
description: The pretax profit for BAA P.L.C., the British airport operator, rose 13.7 percent in the year that ended on March 31 as the number of people passing through its airports and stores increased 7.1 percent, to 87.7 million. The pretax profit was $:366 million ($581.94 million), up from $:322 million a year earlier but at the lower end of analysts' estimates. BAA said its revenue rose 5.6 percent, to $:1.16 billion ($1.85 billion).

title: International Briefs; S.A.S.-Thai Air Accord
description: Scandinavian Airlines System and Thai Airways International signed a cooperation agreement yesterday that includes code-sharing on all routes between Scandinavia and Thailand. Code-sharing allows one airline to sell tickets for routes that are actually operated by the partner. The agreement was called a "triangular cooperation" by Jan Stenberg, S.A.S.'s chief executive, because it complements one that both carriers signed with Lufthansa German Airlines in the last year.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-12 STRIKING BACK AT THE SERBS Nine days ago in central Sarajevo, United Nations peacekeepers showed that they can fight back against the humiliation that has so often been their lot -- if they are willing to pay the price. A1

title: Guerrilla Problems Bringing Guatemala and Mexico Closer
description: Confronted with separate guerrilla movements on their common border, Guatemala and Mexico are trying to cast aside political and ideological differences and are stepping up their military and political cooperation.

title: Village Super Market Inc. reports earnings for 13wks to Apr 29
description: b-Net loss, which was after a gain of $ 400,000, or 14 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of accounting change.(Loss)The results for the year-ago 9 months ended April 23 and included 38 weeks.Sales for the latest third quarter decreased as a result of a store closed since one year ago and a same store sales decrease of 1.3 percent. Same store sales declined due to the impact of new competitive entries, continued sluggishness in the economy and comparison to a year-ago period that included higher promotional spending.The results for the latest quarter were substantially better than the year-ago period, despite lower sales, due to lower payroll and promotional costs, and increased gross margin percentages.

title: A Top Executive Is Resigning From American International Group
description: American International Group said yesterday that Jeffrey W. Greenberg, an executive vice president and a son of its chairman and chief executive, Maurice R. Greenberg, was resigning after 17 years with the insurance company.

title: The 1995 Tony Winners
description: Here are the winners of the 1995 Tony Awards, given on Sunday night at the Minskoff Theater in Manhattan:

title: An Early Hurricane Strikes Florida's Coast, but Fizzles
description: Like the early guest at a party, Hurricane Allison showed up in Florida's Gulf Coast today only five days into this year's hurricane season. To the relief of its hosts, the storm caused only minimal damage despite tidal surges and flooding.

title: Struck by History in Dresden and Prague
description: Dresden is famous as the city that was destroyed. Arriving for the Dresden Music Festival recently, a first-time visitor had the well-known catastrophic pictures in mind: the landscape photographed from above, obscured by firestorms and the lowering hulks of Allied bombers. It is staggering now to walk through the city center and see the old buildings restored to former glory, as if the smoke had cleared and left everything unharmed. The handsome sprawl of the Semper Opera conjures very different images, of turn-of-the-century Dresden, when Strauss's operas had triumphant premieres and special "Rosenkavalier" trains arrived from Berlin. Dresden is a life-size replica of itself, eerily perfect. One can forget that the original is gone.

title: Ovitz Won't Head MCA as Big Hollywood Deal Collapses
description: Hollywood's most closely watched deal ended up on the cutting-room floor yesterday as negotiations for Michael Ovitz to become head of the entertainment giant MCA Inc. unexpectedly collapsed.

title: NCH Corp.(NCH,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
E.D.S. to Join In Israel Venture
description: Electronic Data Systems said today that it had formed a joint venture with Kardan Technologies of Israel to provide computer services in the country.

title: Free-Market Failure
description: To the Editor:

title: Who's an Isolationist?
description: Democrats are complaining about Republican "isolationism" and Congressional involvement in foreign policy. How strange.

title: Frank Waters, Novelist, Dies; Chronicler of Southwest Was 92
description: Frank Waters, a prolific novelist and chronicler of the Southwest and its Pueblo country, died on Saturday at his home in Taos, N.M. He was 92.

title: Woman Testifies on Weeks Held Against Her Will in a Brothel
description: A young Thai woman said yesterday that Federal prison was "a lovely place" compared with the Chinatown brothel where she and 30 other women had been virtually imprisoned.

title: Caseload Is Nearing Gridlock as Current Term Winds Down
description: The Supreme Court's 1994-95 term almost certainly has less than a month to run, but with only one opinion announced today, and no more scheduled until next week, the familiar signs of June gridlock are settling on the Court.

title: Software Units Gain Attention
description: Stocks of most big software companies rose yesterday as investors bet that I.B.M.'s $3.3 billion plan to buy the Lotus Development Corporation would lead other companies to pursue weak software companies.

title: Existence of I.R.S. Pension-Fund Inquiry Is Admitted, but Details Are Not Disclosed
description: The Whitman administration is keeping a tight lid on reports that the Internal Revenue Service is poised to demand that the state pay back nearly $800 million in pension funds used by Gov. Jim Florio in 1992 to pay for a sales tax cut.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report yesterday about a Hindemith and Purcell concert by the Central City Chorus at the Central Presbyterian Church in Manhattan misstated the date of the concert. It was last night; it is not tonight.

title: Mid Ocean Ltd.(MOCNF,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: The latest periods included investment gain of $ 5,891,000, or 15 cents a share, in the quarter and an investment loss of $ 16,924,000, or 45 cents a share, in the 6 months.The year-ago periods included investment loss of $ 7,019,000, or 19 cents a share, in the quarter and an investment gain of $ 672,000, or 2 cents a share, in the 6 months.Mid Ocean said absent investment gains and losses, it had operating income of $ 49,688,000, or $ 1.31 a share, in the latest second quarter, compared with $ 20,257,000, or 54 cents a share, in year-ago period.The insurer said gross written premiums fell 2 percent to $ 55.6 million in the latest quarter from $ 56.8 million a year earlier, primarily as a result of a decline in reinstatement premiums after the California earthquake.

title: A Poke Check Puts a Big Dent in Flyer Hopes
description: Coach Jacques Lemaire has always preached discipline to the Devils. That philosophy has helped the Devils win 10 of 12 playoff games this spring, including the last 6.

title: Boy's Death Ruled Accidental
description: The death of a 12-year-old boy who was experimenting with gunpowder has been ruled accidental, the authorities said yesterday. The boy, Justin Szuba, was playing alone on Saturday when he decided to pack gunpowder into a carbon dioxide cartridge that he had found in his family's garage. The cartridge exploded when he lit it, driving shrapnel into his heart. SUSAN JO KELLER

title: Students Interpreting Works Old and New
description: Works by a modern-dance pioneer and two choreographers who are better known as ballet dancers were highlights of the "Senior Dance Concert 1995," presented on Sunday afternoon by the dance department of the Fiorella H. La Guardia High School of Music and Art and Performing Arts in Manhattan.

title: SOUTHWESTERN PUBLIC TO GET TUCO BACK FROM CABOT
description: The Cabot Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell Tuco Inc., its coal-handling subsidiary, back to the Southwestern Public Service Company for $75 million. The sale would include all of the coal inventory and coal contract operations managed by Tuco. Cabot, based in Boston, acquired Tuco for $33.8 million in 1979 from Southwestern Public Service, of Amarillo, Tex. Cabot said it expected most of the proceeds from the sale to be reinvested in Cabot's core specialty chemicals business.

title: 2 Subway Trains Crash on Williamsburg Bridge
description: A Manhattan-bound subway train driven by a motorman on his final run of an overnight shift slammed into the rear of another train stopped on the Williamsburg Bridge yesterday morning, killing the motorman, injuring more than 50 passengers and crumpling tons of steel like so much wadded paper.

title: Metrahealth Moves Account In-House
description: The Metrahealth Companies, a joint venture of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company and the Travelers Group, said yesterday that it had moved its account in-house after only six months at N. W. Ayer & Partners in New York.

title: Patterns
description: All Together Now

title: On My Mind; How to Succeed In Bosnia
description: It is not true that the Clinton Administration has no firm policy about Bosnia. In the space of six days last week, it had three of them just about committing troops, and another may be in the oven.

title: Upstart Wins A Ballot Slot, Embarrassing Democrats
description: For the second time in as many years, John L. Kucek, a Holocaust revisionist, has embarrassed the Democratic Party by getting his name on the primary election ballot unopposed.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Esquire, Men's Health and Rolling Stone find rare common ground in a promotion for Haggar.
description: IMAGINE Coca-Cola, Pepsi-Cola and Royal Crown teaming up to plug colas among iced-tea drinkers. Or McDonald's, Burger King and Wendy's joining forces to assert that hamburgers are better than pizza.

title: Green Shakes, Giants Rattle and Mets Roll
description: Maybe Barry Bonds and his teammates should have stood behind the batting cage at Candlestick Park and listened to Dallas Green speak prior to the Giants-Mets game this afternoon. Disgusted with the state of his team, the Mets' manager suggested that he might get fired for the club's poor play, hinted that the departure of reliever Josias Manzanillo -- who was claimed on waivers by the Yankees today -- was only the first step in a housecleaning and criticized team attitude.

title: Vending Laws and the Veterans' Lobby
description: Four years ago the State Legislature passed a much-needed law that confirmed New York City's right to regulate sidewalk vending in severely congested business districts -- even if the vending is conducted by disabled veterans. Now that sensible law is expiring, and its continuation is up for consideration today in the Cities Committee of the Democratic-led State Assembly.

title: Arthur Shapiro, 72; Led Research of Tourette's
description: Arthur K. Shapiro, a psychiatrist whose work at Mount Sinai Medical School advanced the knowledge and treatment of Tourette's Syndrome, died on Saturday at White Plains Hospital. He was 72 and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Young People Confronting AIDS
description: Through the 1980's and into the early 90's, prime time television virtually ignored the existence of AIDS. The very occasional movie on the subject was considered singularly brave. Fortunately, times and attitudes in the industry have changed.

title: A 'Good' Train Operator, Faulted Once, Known for Precision Stops
description: To one fellow worker, Layton Gibson was a motorman who could be counted on to "hit the board," or bring the train to a stop so it was perfectly aligned with the platform.

title: A+ COMMUNICATIONS TO BUY NETWORK USA FOR $84 MILLION
description: A+ Communications Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the privately held Network USA Paging Corporation in a transaction valued about $84 million. A+ Communications, based in Nashville, said it would pay $12 million cash and issue 4.2 million common shares to Network USA shareholders. The company would also redeem about $4.5 million of Network USA's preferred shares and assume its outstanding debt, which was $10.9 million on March 31. A+'s shares jumped $1.75 yesterday, to $13.50, in Nasdaq trading. A+ Communications is a provider of paging, voice mail, cellular telephone and telemessaging services in eight Southeastern states. Network USA, based in Pensacola, Fla., provides paging services.

title: F.C.C. Chief Promises 5 More '95 Auctions
description: The Federal Communications Commission will hold at least five more auctions of the airwaves this year, the commission's chairman, Reed E. Hundt, said today.

title: Merger May Be Free of Antitrust Hurdles
description: Unlike the effort by Microsoft this spring to merge with a rival software company, the unsolicited bid by I.B.M. for Lotus Development is unlikely to face a Federal antitrust challenge, antitrust experts said today.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ALLAN R. DRAGONE, the chairman of the New York Racing Association, the nonprofit corporation that runs Aqueduct, Belmont Park and Saratoga race tracks, now has a track of his own, so to speak. It will have humans, not horses, going through their paces on it.

title: After All the Talk, MCA's New Owner Fails to Lure Ovitz
description: Hollywood's most closely watched deal has collapsed. Negotiations for Michael Ovitz, the chairman of Creative Artists Agency, to head MCA Inc. broke down even though a deal had been close to completion as recently as Sunday.

title: Block to Sell Parts of Unit
description: The Block Drug Company said today that it had agreed to sell certain assets of its Reed & Carnrick Pharmaceutical division to Schwarz Pharma Kremers-Urban. Financial terms were not disclosed. Schwarz Pharma Kremers-Urban is a unit of Schwarz Pharma A.G. of Germany. Block Drug, which is based here, said Reed & Carnrick had annual sales of about $50 million. Schwarz Pharma had consolidated sales of 880 million marks, or about $624.8 million, for the latest year.

title: If Service Isn't Restored
description: The Transit Authority said yesterday that it expected subway service over the Williamsburg Bridge to be restored by the morning rush hour today.

title: Ellen Garrison, 96; Acted in Film 'Zelig'
description: Ellen Jay Garrison, the widow of the Manhattan attorney Lloyd K. Garrison and a featured performer in the Woody Allen film "Zelig" at the age of 83, died on Friday at her home in Manhattan. She was 96.

title: Man Charged in Carjackings
description: A Newark man stole two cars at gunpoint Sunday night before abandoning them both and going home, the police say.

title: America Online Seeks an Agency
description: America Online Inc. said yesterday that it was seeking an agency to help develop a corporate branding campaign, now handled in-house. The billings were not disclosed, but Adweek estimated they could total as much as $30 million.

title: Dust and Ice
description: To the Editor:

title: California Speaker Frustrates G.O.P. One Last Time
description: Willie L. Brown Jr., the all-dominant Speaker of the California Assembly for 15 years, installed his own successor today in Sacramento before heading off to his hometown, San Francisco, to run for mayor.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: I.B.M. in Hostile Bid Of $3.3 Billion for Lotus I.B.M. made a surprise $3.3 billion hostile bid for Lotus Development in what would be the largest amount ever paid for a computer software company. Lotus stock surged $28.9375, to close at $61.4375.

title: Risks to Spine Seen in Scuba Diving
description: MOST amateur divers are aware of the obvious dangers of scuba diving like decompression sickness or running out of air. Now doctors at Technical University in Aachen, Germany, say divers, particularly amateurs, may be unwittingly experiencing damage to the central nervous system.

title: Watching the Generations Of Rock Merge and Mutate
description: On Saturday night at Town Hall, the guitarist Robert Fripp sat dimly lighted on a stool at the back of the stage, the calm in the center of the storm that was King Crimson. Whenever the pioneering English art-rock band, which recently reassembled after breaking up more than 10 years ago, brought its complex instrumental thud down to a quiet drone, Mr. Fripp was left alone. He sat stiffly and impassively in his seat, either playing a sweet, harmonically rich guitar line that had been submerged in the song all along or sending sounds swooshing through the hall speakers.

title: Bones May Be Those Of Powerful Maya Ruler
description: NEW excavations at a royal Maya tomb in Honduras have uncovered a red-stained skeleton, surrounded by jade offerings, that archeologists think is the remains of Kinich Ah Pop, the second ruler of the powerful Copan dynasty in the fifth century A.D.

title: S.E.C. Said to Prepare Inside-Trading Case
description: The enforcement staff of the Securities and Exchange Commission is planning to recommend bringing charges against an analyst at Salomon Brothers and his father, who owns a brokerage firm, contending that they violated insider-trading laws during failed merger talks between the Bell Atlantic Corporation and Tele-Communications Inc.

title: Impressionable Minds
description: To the Editor:

title: Husband Dumps Wife. She's Angry. Watch Out.
description: SPLITTING By Fay Weldon 246 pages. The Atlantic Monthly Press. $21.

title: Honors
description: * Ron Fierman, executive vice president and general manager at Warwick Baker & Fiore, New York, was elected president of the Advertising Club of New York, succeeding Susan Russo, vice president for advertising sales and strategy at Hearst New Media, New York, who becomes chairwoman of the club. R. Jeffrey Petersen, advertising director of Architectural Digest magazine, New York, owned by Advance Publications, was elected first vice president, next in line to become president. * Louis London, St. Louis, was named the 1995 Promotion Agency of the Year by Promo magazine. * Stephen G. Sullivan, chief operating officer at Clarke Goward Advertising, Boston, was named the 1995-96 chairman of the board of BPA International, New York.

title: Milestone for a Yankee Manager
description: When the season began, two American Leaguers renewed their chase of records once thought to be unattainable. Cal Ripken Jr. has to keep playing until September to reach Lou Gehrig's record of 2,130 consecutive games. But last night, Buck Showalter tied Billy Martin's record for most consecutive games managed under George Steinbrenner.

title: High-End Stores Push for Designer Sales
description: The diamond tiara of Empress Josephine teetering on one model's head, the naked male model lolling on a bed covered with newspapers and drinking champagne, the portrait gallery replete with a shadow where a masterpiece had been removed. There was much that was evocative in John Galliano's show at Bergdorf Goodman.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TRACK AND FIELD Ethiopian Sets World Mark in 10,000

title: Serbs Signal Freeing of More Hostages
description: The Serbian-dominated Yugoslav Government indicated today that more United Nations hostages might soon be freed by their Bosnian Serb captors.

title: Bosnia Battle Shows U.N.'s Pride and Limits
description: When Capt. Francois Lecointre arrived in Bosnia three weeks ago as a United Nations peacekeeper, he did not expect to find himself leading a commando raid into a hail of Serbian bullets.

title: Diagnostek Inc.(DXK,N) reports earnings for Year to Mar 31
description: b-Included a pretax charge of $ 12.6 million, or 31 cents a share after taxes, primarily related to the company's State of New Jersey unit-dose service contract. Excluding the charge, net income was $ 18.7 million, or 75 cents a share.c-Included pretax charges of $ 12 million, or 31 cents a share after taxes, related to the settlement of shareholder litigation. Excluding the charges, net income would have been $ 12.6 million, or 50 cents a share.The company attributed its increased revenues in the latest fiscal year to higher integrated segment volumes and the impact of a full-year of retail operations, partly offset by decreases in managed care sales due mainly to a mid-year loss of a major customer.

title: Ross Perot, Yet Again
description: Ross Perot says his audition for Presidential candidates will be about "issues, issues, issues." But of course it will really be about Ross, Ross, Ross.

title: All the Magic Pieces Fall Into Place
description: The team pulled a few Ping-Pong balls from the hopper, invested faith and time in its first draft choices and coaxed a power forward with three rings into joining the party. Now the Orlando Magic stands on the threshold of the National Basketball Association title at the rambunctious age of 6.

title: For Riders, the Jolt of Seeing a Train Barrel Right In
description: They are the dawn patrol, the early risers from Brooklyn and Queens who turn on the lights, open the mailrooms and do the grunt work of the Manhattan law offices and brokerage houses and restaurants. When they ride the subway to work, the sun is just showing its face, the cars are blissfully uncongested and everyone expects a punctual and uneventful trip.

title: Admitting Women to V.M.I. Shortchanges All
description: To the Editor:

title: Why Student Aid Matters
description: Two years ago, Gregory McCall almost became a dropout when he failed to make the state championship basketball team at St. Anthony High School in Jersey City. As he told Neil MacFarquhar of The Times: "I had no hope of going to college because my family was so poor. I thought I would end up in Jersey City working at Kmart in a minimum-wage job."

title: Natural Gas Prices Rise Sharply On Storm-Related Supply Cuts
description: Natural gas futures jumped 2.6 percent yesterday after producers in the Gulf of Mexico, the site of a quarter of the nation's natural gas production, reduced their output as a precaution against possible damage from Hurricane Allison.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Charles Allen Blackwell, Dancer and Stage Manager, 66
description: Charles Allen Blackwell, a Broadway dancer and stage manager, died on Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 66.

title: Serena's Song Also Arrives
description: D. Wayne Lukas's Preakness winner, Timber Country, and his Kentucky Derby champion, Thunder Gulch, are expected at Belmont Park this morning for Saturday's Belmont Stakes. Lukas, seeking a record-setting fifth straight Triple Crown victory, is also bringing a little surprise: The stablemate Serena's Song, the filly who set a blazing Derby pace only to fade in the stretch.

title: Signed by Central Banks' Move, Traders Keep the Dollar Stable
description: The dollar was steady yesterday as currency traders remained wary of a repeat of last week's coordinated dollar purchases by central banks.

title: G.M. Said to Plan a Philippine Car Plant
description: Manila, Tuesday, June 6 The General Motors Corporation plans to set up a $1 billion car plant in Subic Bay, a former American naval base 50 miles northwest of Manila, newspapers here reported today.

title: Veterans Fighting for Right to Peddle in Midtown Once Again
description: Robert Smith, a World War II veteran, remembers making hundreds of dollars a day selling clothing on Fifth Avenue. These days, he is peddling in lower Manhattan and says he would be lucky to make $50.

title: Abbott Is Remembered in the Colorful Spirit of Broadway
description: In the last year of his life, George Abbott, at the age of 107, was asked what was the biggest change he had seen on Broadway. He paused, then replied, "Electricity."

title: Chess
description: The elite Dos Hermanas International Tournament in Spain in early May had a rollicking finish. With two rounds to go, Anatoly Karpov of Russia and Michael Adams, an English grandmaster, led with 5 points. The 20-year-old Brooklyn grandmaster Gata Kamsky lay back in a tie for sixth place.

title: Magna Intl.(MGA,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: Magna International said the higher sales levels reflected increased North American vehicle production, up 8 percent over the first nine months of fiscal 1994, a 7 perent increase in content per vehicle, higher tooling sales and a 15 percent rise relating to European sales, which reflected the acquisitions of the airbag, steering wheel, mirror and plastics operations, which were only partly reflected in the year-earlier period.The company also said the earnings increase reflects higher sales, an increase in equity income and a decrease in interest costs, minority interest and income taxes, offset partly by increases in variable and European SG&A costs and depreciation and amortization expense.The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: International Briefs; In Brief
description: * The Nippon Data Kiki Company, once a favorite of Japanese and foreign stock market investors, said yesterday that it had gone bankrupt, with accumulated debt of $595 million. The company, which specializes in office automation equipment and hotel room refrigerator billing systems, filed a declaration of bankruptcy with the Tokyo District Court. * The United States Banknote Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to exchange a 22.5 percent stake in its Brazilian subsidiary, ABN-Brazil, for the printing operations of Banco Bradesco S.A., a leading Brazilian bank. The company did not disclose the value of the ABN-Brazil stake, but said the unit had annual revenues of about $75 million. United States Banknote, based in New York, said the printing operation it was acquiring had 1994 sales of about $40 million.

title: Clinton Rejects Invitation To Candidate Conference
description: Side by side on a television talk show, President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore tonight made what looked like their first joint appearance of the 1996 Presidential campaign. But they were careful to keep some distance from the fray, ruling out attending a conference of Presidential contenders called by Ross Perot in Dallas for this summer.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Thursday about the improving prospects for gene therapy companies referred incorrectly to a patent on one form of gene therapy used by Genetic Therapy Inc. The patent is held by the National Institutes of Health, not the company. The institutes granted an exclusive license to the company, which was a collaborator in the gene therapy technology.

title: Winners in Lotus Deal Enjoy a Return of 37 to 1
description: Every bidding war for large companies has its winners and losers, but there seem to be especially big ones in the $3.3 billion offer by I.B.M. for Lotus Development.

title: You're Kidding, McEnroe Is Blunt?
description: If I were a tennis player, I wouldn't want John McEnroe calling my match. He's tough and blunt and can blister your game. "Abysmal" is one of McEnroe's favorite words. There is no governor on his candor. All of which makes him eminently delightful as a French Open analyst for NBC and USA Network.

title: LADBROKE SELLS ITS CORPORATE CENTER FOR $163 MILLION
description: Ladbroke Group P.L.C., the British betting, hotel and property company, said yesterday that its United States unit had sold the Bay Colony Corporate Center to Shorenstein, a real estate company based in California,, for $163 million. Bay Colony, a three-building office center in the suburbs of Boston, generated a net rental income of $8.6 million in 1994. Ladbroke said the office center was the largest property in its portfolio, and the sale "bodes well for our efforts to dispose of other United States properties." Shorenstein initially paid Ladbroke $40 million. Of the remainder, $75 million would be paid in December and $48 million in December 1998. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: No Cork, and No Apologies
description: Frisky American League hitters, beware. Essentially, that was the message George Steinbrenner was sending when he ordered Manager Buck Showalter to request that the umpires confiscate Tony Phillips's bat on Sunday before the first pitch in a game that the Yankees won, 11-3, from the California Angels.

title: Scientists Deplore Flight From Reason
description: SINCE at least the time of Archimedes, the third-century B.C. Greek physicist who was slain by a Roman soldier, scientists have occasionally had to defend themselves from forces anathema to rational thought. Once again many scientists believe their backs are to the wall, and participants at a meeting last week in New York resolved to start fighting back.

title: A Specialist In Rebounds To Run Kmart
description: The Kmart Corporation said yesterday that it had hired Floyd Hall, a specialist in pumping new life into sagging retailers, as its new chairman and chief executive.

title: Hardaway's World Has No Tomorrow
description: Anfernee Hardaway was describing the nuances of playoff basketball recently, explaining why he launched a 3-pointer with 1.3 seconds left in Game 4 of the Eastern Conference finals when the play was designed to tie the game with a 2-point shot.

title: Despite Engine Snag, G.E. Expects 777 to Be on Time
description: The General Electric Company said yesterday that it had encountered a problem in the final development of its version of the jet engine that powers the Boeing Company's new 777, but both companies said they believed they were still on schedule to deliver planes equipped with the GE90 engines to British Airways P.L.C. in September.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: PLAYTEX SHAREHOLDERS APPROVE HAAS WHEAT FINANCING
description: Shareholders of Playtex Products Inc. approved a $180 million investment yesterday that would give control of the company to Haas Wheat & Harrison Investment Partners of Dallas. About 98 percent of the voting shareholders approved the Haas offer to buy 20 million shares of newly issued common stock at $9 each -- equal to a 40 percent stake. Playtex, based in Westport, Conn., generates 60 percent of its sales and more than two-thirds of its profits from its tampon business. The new chairman of Playtex, Robert Haas, said he intended to expand the company's other businesses, which include infant care, sun care and hair care products, through acquisitions and product line extensions. Shares of Playtex gained 37.5 cents, to $8.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: TOYOTA ASKS FOR 200 CHANGES IN G.M. CAR
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation has asked the General Motors Corporation to make about 200 modifications on its right-hand-drive Chevrolet Cavalier before Toyota begins selling the car in Japan early next year, a spokesman for Toyota said yesterday. Toyota's suggestions include changing the layout of the gas and brake pedals and repositioning the seats, the spokesman said. Linda McGill, a spokeswoman for G.M. in Detroit, said most of the requested changes had been part of the normal product development process between the two automakers since the project was announced in November 1993. She declined to say if G.M. would agree to all the modifications. Toyota is planning to buy about 20,000 of the cars, which it will sell under the Toyota name. Toyota and GM declined to estimate how much the changes would cost, but both parties said the additional charges would not scuttle the project.

title: 108 U.N. SOLDIERS HAVE BEEN FREED, SERBIAN AIDE SAYS
description: A Serbian official said that 108 more United Nations troops who had been held hostage by Bosnian Serb forces were released early today with a promise that the remaining peacekeepers would be freed soon.

title: Personal Health
description: FIFTY years ago, Grand Rapids, Mich., became the world's first city to fluoridate its water supply on purpose. School-age children who grew up drinking the water experienced a 65 percent reduction in dental caries, when compared with children in a neighboring city where the water was not fluoridated.

title: Agassi's Grand Plan Goes Awry In Paris
description: When the match was over, he simply left his racquets behind and, expressionless and empty-handed, trudged away from the center court of Roland Garros like a sleepwalker.

title: The New York Philharmonic's European Tour, By the Numbers
description: On Monday, the New York Philharmonic set off on a benign invasion of Europe. In the travel plans, little has been left to chance: even the signs that say "Dressing Rooms This Way" -- as well as the markers to modify them and the tape to hang them -- were in the orchestra's gear. Here is what the orchestra's chartered jet carried to Europe and what its itinerary will include: THE PEOPLE

title: No Rockefeller REIT Dividend
description: Rockefeller Center Properties Inc., the real estate investment trust that holds the $1.3 billion mortgage on Rockefeller Center, said yesterday that it would not pay its second-quarter dividend.

title: Market Place; SunAmerica hopes to prosper with annuities for baby boomers.
description: ONE of the leaders in the race to exploit the requirements and interests of baby boomers these days is SunAmerica Inc., a financial services concern that specializes in tax-deferred long-term savings and investments.

title: Wings End Long Night And Aim For Sweep
description: Detroit's red-hot Red Wings are one victory from their first trip to the Stanley Cup finals in 29 years. They won their eighth consecutive playoff game by beating the Chicago Blackhawks, 4-3, in double overtime tonight in the United Center.

title: Hospitalized Mantle Needs New Liver
description: Mickey Mantle, who was admitted to a Dallas hospital last Wednesday complaining of stomach pains, is suffering from progressive liver failure and has been recommended for a transplant, a hospital official said last night.

title: FIBREBOARD MAY SELL WOOD PRODUCTS UNIT
description: The Fibreboard Corporation said yesterday that it was considering selling all or part of its wood products business, citing sluggishness in the wood market. The wood products group had 1994 revenue of about $180 million. A sale would leave Fibreboard, based in Walnut Creek, Calif., with operations in industrial insulation, vinyl siding and other building products, as well as two ski resorts in California. The company also said it planned to buy back up to $20 million of its common shares. At current prices, the full buyback would represent about a million of the 8.5 million shares outstanding. Shares of Fibreboard were up $2.625, or 14.7 percent, to $20.50 on the American Stock Exchange.

title: Book Notes
description: A Different Sort of Campaign

title: PCS Primeco Picks Wireless Technology
description: PCS Primeco L.P., an alliance of three regional Bell companies and Airtouch Communications Inc., said today that it would use an emerging technology called C.D.M.A. as the foundation of its wireless telephone networks.

title: U.N. Buildup in Bosnia Eyes 'Mogadishu Line'
description: The new buzzword on Bosnia is the "Mogadishu line," and suddenly policy-makers and critics from Paris to Washington are worrying about it and wondering if it has been crossed.

title: Senate Backs Military Role In Fighting Domestic Terror
description: As part of its proposed antiterrorism package, the Senate tonight agreed to loosen a 117-year-old law that limits the military's involvement in domestic law enforcement.

title: Japanese Indict Leader of Cult In Gas Murders
description: Prosecutors indicted the leader and six other members of the Aum Shinrikyo religious cult on murder charges today in connection with the nerve gas attack on the Tokyo subway system, setting the stage for eventual trials that could send the cult leaders to the gallows.

title: Last-Place Yankees Are Playing That Way
description: Buck Showalter breezes by the standings in the sports section quickly, very quickly. Steve Howe thinks the Yankees stink. Luis Polonia called the last five weeks a nightmare. Paul O'Neill conceded there is an urgency for the Yankees every day. These things happen when a team plummets nine and a half games out of first place.

title: A New Test Of Antitrust Hard Line
description: Which is the greater threat to competition: a $5 billion company that buys another that is pre-eminent in its field, or a $64 billion company that buys one with no competitor at all?

title: What's in the Soda
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about this year's convention of the American Booksellers Association misstated the publication date for a novel by Pat Conroy, "Beach Music" (Nan A. Talese/Doubleday). It is later this month, not in the fall.

title: Proceedings Get Graphic With Photos Of the Bodies
description: Nearly a dozen graphic photographs of Nicole Brown Simpson taken after she was slashed to death were shown today in the O. J. Simpson murder trial, eliciting tears, sobs and stunned looks from jury members and the courtroom audience.

title: Gift of Cartier Heirlooms To University Startles All
description: For months before Marion Cartier died last year at the age of 83, international jewelry experts speculated about who would receive the Cartier family jewels.

title: The First to Meet Disaster Are Also the First to Meet the Dawn
description: Morning did not break so much as it creaked into being in Queens yesterday, daylight stretching out slowly across the concourse at Jamaica Center. At 5:28 A.M., banks were locked, fast-food stores were shuttered, and most of the day's newspapers remained bundled in the street.

title: Telescope Captures the Fireworks When Stars Are Born
description: The final stages of starbirth, as seen in new pictures by the Hubble Space Telescope, seem to touch off a cosmic celebration. Out of the dense whirlpools of gas and dust creating the stars erupt jets of shimmering gases extending billions of miles. The stars themselves, in machine-gun fashion, fire bursts of material at speeds of half a million miles an hour, creating what appear to be strings of glowing beads.

title: Cowens Is Eyed for Celtic Coaching Job
description: M. L. CARR, director of basketball operations for the Boston Celtics, said he expected to talk in the next few days with the former Celtic DAVE COWENS about the vacant Boston coaching job.

title: Panel Sees Merit in Earned-Income Tax Credit
description: As Republicans prepare to scale back the earned-income tax credit, a Federal commission has concluded that eligibility for the credit for poor and lower-middle-class families is much broader than previously thought.

title: Different Paths and Stakes For Rival Chief Executives
description: Beyond money and strategy, big takeover deals are always a clash of people and personalities. The $3.3 billion hostile bid by I.B.M. for the Lotus Development Corporation is a confrontation between two men who were once both management consultants at McKinsey & Company but who now find themselves on very different paths.

title: Young and Unfamiliar But at Ease at the Fore
description: Both the New York City Ballet and American Ballet Theater have recently thrust young talent or virtual unknowns into principal roles with phenomenal success.

title: Let the Diner Decide
description: The Federal Government is more sophisticated about tobacco than New York City's government. It doesn't prevent adults from smoking. It just requires warning labels on cigarette packs. Health, illness or death are up to the consumer.

title: Bill Is Signed Raising Limit To 65 M.P.H.
description: Gov. George E. Pataki today signed into law a 65-mile-per-hour speed limit for 1,100 miles of the state's highways that is to take effect Aug. 1, vowing that the police would enforce the new limit more vigilantly than the current 55-m.p.h. limit.

title: U.S.I.A. Would Fit Right In at State Dept.
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Rules in Killing of Candy Heiress
description: A Federal judge today found that a horse trader and stable owner had solicited the long-unsolved killing of Helen Vorhees Brach, a candy heiress. But after a last-minute legal maneuver by a defense lawyer the judge put off sentencing the man on racketeering and other charges.

title: Snipers Tighten Terror's Grip on Bosnia's Capital
description: After more than three years of war, the lines of sniper fire are pretty well known in this city. But the Bosnian Serbs recently opened a new one, straight down the central Marshal Tito Avenue, and today they displayed their new prowess.

title: Stocks End Day Mixed, With the Dow Advancing by 8.65
description: The stock market closed mixed but essentially unchanged yesterday, as the bond market continued its rally and the dollar stabilized abroad.

title: BURLINGTON INDUSTRIES TO ELIMINATE 380 JOBS AT PLANT
description: Burlington Industries said yesterday that it would halt yarn production at its plant in Denton, N.C., in August, eliminating about 380 jobs. The company, based in Greensboro, N.C., said it had agreed to buy additional cotton and polycotton yarns for its knitted fabrics division from Parkdale Mills, which will purchase the yarn production equipment of the Denton plant. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed. The company said the Denton plant would continue as a knitting operation, with about 270 workers.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Japan and U.S. Admit Missteps Over Trade

title: Republicans' Welfare Plan Is Again Attacked by Clinton
description: With Congress moving aggressively forward on proposals to overhaul welfare, President Clinton today again attacked Republican-sponsored measures, saying they would cut spending on the poor to finance tax breaks for the rich. But he stopped well short of threatening a veto.

title: Executive Changes
description: GILLETTE CO., Boston, named A. Bruce Cleverly president for Braun U.S. and group general manager for Braun North America subsidiaries. LORILLARD TOBACCO CO., New York, a unit of Loews Corp., promoted Alexander Spears 3d, its vice chairman and chief operating officer, to chairman and chief executive, succeeding Andrew Tisch, who will take on an expanded role with the parent company's management committee.

title: Ex-Chicago Housing Chief Says Bureaucrats Hindered His Efforts
description: As the hard-riving chairman of the Chicago Housing Authority, Vincent Lane made so many enemies the police gave him a bulletproof vest and assigned him a bodyguard.

title: New York's Elderly Subways
description: The safety of New York City subway riders depends on human drivers and an antique automated safety system. On Monday one or both of these failed, with tragic results: a driver was killed and scores of passengers were injured when a J train plowed into a stationary M train on the Williamsburg Bridge. The accident has raised some hard questions about how to insure safety at a time of scarce resources for the city's mass-transit system.

title: Corrections
description: Another Business Day article, about trading in Lotus stock and options before I.B.M.'s announcement, misstated the term for an option to buy a stock at a specified price. It is a call. (A put is an option to sell.)

title: Does Dave Need Another Tooth?
