title: ARCSYS SHARES SOAR ON FIRST DAY OF TRADING
description: Shares of Arcsys Inc. rose sharply yesterday on the software maker's first day as a publicly traded company. Shares of Arcsys, which closed at $26.50 in Nasdaq trading, were priced at $13 by Morgan Stanley Group, the lead manager of the offering. Arcsys issued 2.4 million shares, and yesterday's trading volume was 3.4 million shares. Arcsys, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., develops and markets software used to design integrated circuits. A shortage of initial public offerings, combined with strong gains among high-technology issues, have made new companies like Arcsys attractive to investors.

title: Journal; Hard(cover)ball
description: The American Booksellers Association's annual convention is supposedly a literary trade fair, but no one here was debating the merits of "The Unconsoled," Kazuo Ishiguro's first novel since "The Remains of the Day." In this great city for both politics and art, politics won out this time, as the country's two most prominent fantasy candidates for President, Colin Powell and Newt Gingrich, opened their unofficial, undeclared campaigns for higher office by promoting their hardcover wares.

title: Tax-Cut Plan Is Denounced By Democrats
description: In what was supposed to be a triumphantly bipartisan event, the Suffolk County Executive, Robert J. Gaffney, announced today that he and the County Legislature had agreed to cut the county's 8.5 percent sales tax next year by a quarter of a percentage point, to 8.25 percent.

title: High Concept Meets Good Housekeeping
description: THERE is nothing haphazard or ordinary in the little Upper East Side penthouse duplex that Abbie Zabar -- artist, writer, designer and gardener -- shares with an 18-year-old Persian cat named Timothy. No piles of newspapers or magazines. No clutter of little objects in danger of overtaking any surface. No jarring conversation pieces, though Timothy does lap his water from a sterling silver porringer that is an heirloom from Ms. Zabar's Manhattan babyhood.

title: International Briefs; Profit Drops at Hambros
description: Hambros P.L.C., a British merchant bank, said yesterday that its pretax profit had fallen 58 percent in the year that ended March 31, to $:37 million, about $58.9 million, and that it had halved its year-end dividend payout to 7.5 pence. The company's stock plunged 300 pence a share, to 181. (Reuters)

title: VLSI TECHNOLOGY TO TAKE CHARGE FOR PATENT RULING
description: VLSI Technology Inc. said yesterday that it would take a pretax charge of $19.4 million in the second quarter to account for a recent judgment against the company for infringing a packaging patent of Texas Instruments Inc. A jury found that VLSI, an integrated circuit maker based in San Jose, Calif., was one of three companies that deliberately infringed patents by making semiconductor devices with a plastic packaging process developed by Texas Instruments. VLSI had been expected to earn 33 cents a share in the quarter that ends June 30. The company also filed a plan with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday to sell 2.5 million common shares. Shares of VLSI fell 68.75 cents, to $25.3125, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Securities Take Drop On Comments By Greenspan
description: Prices of Treasury securities turned sour yesterday, as the market reacted to statements by Arthur Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, that suggested the Fed was likely to stand pat on interest rates rather than cut them in the near future.

title: Ares-Serono Group reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Sales are worldwide net sales.Operating income in 1995 amounted to $ 15.1 million, compared to $ 22.8 million in 1994. This reflects a decrease in the gross margin of 3.2 percent as well as a 5.7 percent increase in R&D investment, compared to the first quarter of 1994. These figures were adjusted to reflect the sale of the diagnostic division in the second quarter of 1994.The results are in United States dollars.

title: Giant Food Inc.(GFS.A,A) reports earnings for Qtr to May 20
description: b-Included gain of about $ 1.2 million, or 2 cents a share, from the sale of the company's interest in its automatic teller machine operation.

title: Zimmer Walks Off Field Into Retirement
description: Without fanfare, the Colorado Rockies coach DON ZIMMER retired Tuesday night after 47 years in baseball as a player, manager and coach.

title: 95-Year-Old Composer Honored By Ensemble 80 Years Younger
description: As part of the final concert of its 15th season on Tuesday evening at Christ and St. Stephen's Church, the North/South Consonance Ensemble presented a tribute to Otto Luening, whose 95th birthday is next Thursday. An elder statesman of the generation of American composers who came of age between world wars, Mr. Luening did a great deal of experimentation with electronic music between the early 1950's and the early 1970's. But he has also created an enormous catalogue of instrumental and vocal music, much of which deserves better than to be dusted off only when he is celebrating a milestone birthday.

title: Stepping Out of the Ballroom and Onto the Stage
description: Whatever the season or time of day may be, it is always a starry spring evening when American Ballroom Theater dances. The troupe is celebrating 10 years of choreographic fair weather with an anniversary season, which opened on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater.

title: In Cuba, Army Takes On Party Jobs, and May Be Only Thing That Works
description: With Cuba in an economic and ideological crisis over the worldwide collapse of Communism, the role and responsibilities of the Cuban armed forces have been expanding rapidly while those of the Communist Party have been sharply declining.

title: Maker of Siding In Suit Accord
description: The Louisiana-Pacific Corporation has reached a tentative settlement with plaintiffs in a Florida class-action suit involving siding it sold in the state.

title: Sports of The Times: 1995 N.B.A. PLAYOFFS; Post-Up Pupils Take a Final Exam
description: FIRST they hugged at center court. Then, with Bill Russell watching from courtside, they battled ferociously through 53 uproarious minutes. Finally, while Shaquille O'Neal was going after Clyde Drexler's right-side runner, Hakeem Olajuwon snuck inside for a game-winning tip. Olajuwon's Houston Rockets outlasted O'Neal's Orlando Magic, 120-118, in Game 1 of the National Basketball Association finals.

title: U.S.-Serb Talks Suspended
description: Talks between an American envoy and the President of Serbia, Slobodan Milosevic, were suspended today without the diplomatic breakthrough the two had been seeking.

title: Red-Tape Waivers for Schools
description: Schools could cut through state rules on everything from building codes to curriculum under a policy approved yesterday by the state Board of Education. To get waivers, they have to convince state officials their solution will save money or solve another problem.

title: With First Veto, Clinton Rejects Budget-Cut Bill
description: President Clinton vetoed his first bill today, striking down a plan to cut $16.4 billion in spending this year and marking a new phase in his confrontation with the Republican-controlled Congress.

title: Bridge
description: Two defending champions captured the Reisinger Knockout Team Championship on Sunday at the Manhattan Club, 27 West 72d Street.

title: Youth Injured in Palisades Fall
description: After four classmates finished their final exams, they went for a walk Tuesday along the cliffs overlooking the Hudson River. Yesterday Mark West, 18, was in the hospital, critically injured, after falling off the Palisades to a ledge about 80 feet below.

title: Fluke Corp.(FLK,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 28
Limits on Free Mileage
description: WITH summer vacationers about to get rolling on behind-the-wheel trips, several major rental-car companies have announced plans to start charging consumers by the mile if they drive more than 100 to 150 miles a day.

title: Arbitragers Have a Field Day With I.B.M.'s Bid for Lotus
description: I.B.M.'s hostile bid for the Lotus Development Corporation has buoyed the spirits of the professional investors known as arbitragers, who seek to profit from mergers and takeovers. Arbitragers have continued to snap up the shares of Lotus in anticipation of a higher bid ahead for the software company.

title: AT HOME WITH: Debi Mazar; A Tomb of One's Own
description: DEBI MAZAR is an oddly likable person, and not just because she collects Lady Schick shavers.

title: Japanese Stocks Down
description: Stock prices were lower here today. At midday, the Nikkei index of 225 issues stood at 15,412.34, down 267.28 points, or 1.7 percent. On Wednesday, the Nikkei rose 18.63 points.

title: Send the Peacekeepers Home, a Ravaged Rwanda Tells U.N.
description: While world attention has been on strengthening the United Nations force in Bosnia, quiet talks have been going on with Rwanda, which wants peacekeepers -- or many of them -- to leave.

title: One Pass Holds Key That Lets Flyers In
description: Their minds were telling them that the problems of the first two games of the Stanley Cup semifinal series could be solved. Their hearts were sending mixed messages as the Philadelphia Flyers came north, searching for a breakthrough with time running out on their season.

title: Israeli Urges Hearing In Arab Prison Death
description: The Israeli State Attorney ruled today that an interrogator from the Shin Bet security service who caused the death of a Palestinian prisoner in April will not be criminally prosecuted, but should face an internal disciplinary hearing.

title: GE Power Unit Wins Big Saudi Contract
description: The General Electric Company's GE Power Systems subsidiary said today that it had won a contract worth more than $1.3 billion to provide generating equipment for two Saudi Arabian power plants.

title: Notes Creator Seen as Tied to Lotus
description: The head of the software team that created Lotus Notes -- the hot product that I.B.M. is seeking in its $3.3 billion bid for the Lotus Development Corporation -- has an employment contract that could well keep him at the company for years, according to industry executives.

title: Devils Reject Offer on New Lease
description: The Devils yesterday rejected an offer of a renegotiated lease from the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority, setting the stage for an extended battle to keep the team from trying to move to Nashville.

title: Taiwan Enthralled by President's 'Private' U.S. Trip
description: For the record, the President of Taiwan says his trip to an alumni reunion at Cornell University is strictly a private affair.

title: 2 Braking Rods Are Faulted In Fatal Crash Of J Train
description: A one-inch misalignment of two metal rods apparently caused the failure of an automatic braking system on a subway train Monday morning, moments before it slammed into another train on the Williamsburg Bridge, a state investigator said yesterday.

title: G.O.P. Also Protects the Environment
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about the trade confrontation between Japan and the United States referred incorrectly to a statement by Walter F. Mondale, the United States Ambassador to Japan, about Japanese bureaucrats. Mr. Mondale said in an interview that one reason for Japan's increased resistance to American calls for open markets was the rise to power of a new generation of bureaucrats, who had chafed for decades as their superiors gave in to Washington on one trade dispute after another. He did not attribute the new bureaucrats' attitude to a growing movement in Japan to lean toward Asia instead of the United States.

title: So How do Their Gardens Grow?
description: IT'S worth your life to get to a great garden in England. Because every brain cell must stay focused on driving on the left and surviving those endless roundabouts and making sense of signs that name villages known only to the locals.

title: New, Improved Ink-Jet Printers
description: APPARENTLY heeding the lyric of the Paul Simon song that "everything looks worse in black-and-white," printer manufacturers have flooded the home market over the last two years with inexpensive products capable of producing color or black-and-white prints. Unfortunately, one look at the output proved Mr. Simon was sadly mistaken: Early home models invariably meant blurry text, bleached-out colors and output speeds that made the movement of a bill through Congress seem swift.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: THOUSANDS OF SCHOOL LAYOFFS POSSIBLE With New York City's schools facing a double blow of city and state budget cuts, a senior Board of Education official has warned local districts that they may have to slash thousands of school jobs and make other reductions totaling $400 million. A cut of that size would be the largest to classrooms since the fiscal crisis of the 1970's. [ Page A1. ] Board of Education rejects plan to cut number of school bus riders. [ B8. ]

title: 68 Days Late, Lawmakers Pass $33 Billion New York Budget
description: The Legislature concluded a bitter five-month battle over the budget tonight, completing passage of the $33 billion spending plan at 11:40 P.M., 68 days overdue and just five hours short of the record for the latest budget in state history.

title: Big Powers Plan a World Economic Bailout Fund
description: The United States and its major economic partners plan next week to urge the creation of a worldwide emergency fund intended to bail out countries that find themselves, as Mexico did early this year, on the verge of national bankruptcy.

title: History Will Judge New York City by Its Airport Rail Link
description: To the Editor:

title: F.A.A. Opposed to Requiring Baby Seats
description: The Federal Aviation Administration told Congress yesterday that requiring babies on planes to ride in safety seats remained a bad idea, despite a renewed recommendation by the National Transportation Safety Board.

title: Big Drug Companies Brace For Battles on Patent Rights
description: The big prescription drug companies are preparing for court battles over patent rights worth billions of dollars that have been put at risk under conflicting interpretations of a new Federal law. The legislation enforces the new world trade agreement, which takes effect today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Philip Morris Studied Effects of Nicotine In 15 years of previously undisclosed research, Philip Morris studied nicotine and found that it affected the body, brain and behavior of smokers. The research is at odds with company arguments that nicotine should not be regulated under laws applying to drugs that affect the body.

title: District of Columbia Moves Toward Curfew for Those Under 17
description: The District of Columbia, which like many urban areas has watched crime rates increase for young people, is moving to enact a nighttime curfew for anyone under 17 years of age.

title: Block Drug Co.(BLOCA,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: The year-ago periods' share earnings and shares outstanding were restated to reflect stock dividend declared October 1994.

title: Kicker Anderson Rejects Steelers' Offer
description: Kicker GARY ANDERSON's 13-year career with the Pittsburgh Steelers has apparently ended after he rejected a contract that would have paid him at least $525,000 a year.

title: Plan to Cut School Bus Eligibility Rejected
description: The New York City Board of Education last night unanimously rejected a proposal by Schools Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines to cut by almost a third the number of students eligible for school bus transportation.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball American League

title: Clinton Embraces a Proposal To Cut Immigration by a Third
description: The White House today welcomed a Federal advisory panel's recommendation to cut legal immigration by one-third. But the proposals met fierce opposition from Hispanic, Asian-American, Roman Catholic and Jewish groups, as well as from the National Association of Manufacturers.

title: POP
description: A Lilting Detour From a Harder Alloy Ian Anderson Beacon Theater

title: But What of the Violence in Popular Culture?
description: To the Editor:

title: Angiola Sartorio; Dancer, 91
description: Angiola E. Sartorio, a dancer, teacher and choreographer who worked with Kurt Jooss in the 1930's, died on May 26 at her home in Santa Barbara, Calif. She was 91.

title: G.M's German Division Plans Large Investment
description: Adam Opel A.G., the German car-making unit of the General Motors Corporation, said yesterday that it was planning to invest $4.3 billion in Germany by 1997. It also said it would pay a bonus to all workers from its 1994 earnings in recognition of their efforts. In February, Adam Opel reported a profit of between 300 million and 400 million marks for 1994, up from a loss of 571 million marks the year before.

title: The Annals of Film, As Told in Dance
description: Accustomed to being challenged, provoked and even shocked by the American choreographer Bill T. Jones, dance lovers here seemed unprepared for the respectful sobriety of his latest creation, an homage to Lyons's own Lumiere brothers on the 100th anniversary of their invention of modern cinema. Not that the 80-minute work, "24 Frames per Second," lacked sensuality as Auguste and Louis Lumiere danced a steamy tango together, or the soundtrack boomed out rhythmic breathing that ended in a sexual climax, or a near-naked woman wearing a white falcon's head symbolized flights of cinematic imagination.

title: JAZZ
description: A Consistent Style, Modern but Restrained Lynne Arriale, pianist Zinno

title: Carlisle Buys Trail King
description: Carlisle Companies Inc. said today that it had completed its acquisition of Trail King Industries, the leading maker of construction equipment trailers. The purchase price was not disclosed. Trail King, based in Mitchell, S.D., is a closely held company with annual sales of about $60 million and about 500 employees. It sells its trailers through more than 150 dealers.

title: 3d Try in Tough Town for Comedy
description: New York may be a funny place, but it's not that easy to set the town laughing. The producers of the Toyota Comedy Festival have been working at it for two years. On Friday they will mount their third annual offensive, hoping to make the kind of impact that will turn a young, struggling festival into a fixture.

title: Birds' Deaths in Mexico Are a Test for Trade Pact
description: Environmental groups have used the death of thousands of birds at a Mexican reservoir in December to mount the first test of the environmental tenets of the North American Free Trade Agreement.

title: Lamps Made Of Scrap Metal
description: "I STARTED recycling metal years ago when I couldn't figure out what to do with an old refrigerator," said Heather Faulding, an architect with Faulding & Fredman in New York, who has designed a line of lighting fixtures made of scrap metal.

title: Woman Convicted in Abduction of Executive
description: A woman accused of making ransom calls in the abduction of the tuxedo manufacturer Harvey Weinstein was convicted yesterday of kidnapping the businessman, who was held captive for 12 days in a dark, cramped pit.

title: Mantle Has Liver Cancer and Needs Transplant
description: Mickey Mantle, jaundiced, stricken with liver cancer and confined to a hospital bed, has two to four weeks to live unless he gets a liver transplant, his doctors said today.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ARGOSY GAMING CO., Alton, Ill., an operator of riverboat gambling casinos, acquired Jazz Enterprises Inc. Baton Rouge, La., a casino and real estate partnership, for about $27 million. Argosy will also assume about $22 million of debt. BANTA CORP., Menasha, Wis., acquired the assets of Applied Technology Corp., Franklin Park, Ill., a specialty products supplier for the health care industry, for undisclosed terms.

title: A Bright Idea for Sick Children
description: In a contest for ideas to improve the world, children came up with more than 10,000 suggestions. A 7-year-old Morris County boy had the best one, judges decided, and they plan to provide $100,000 to make it reality.

title: Omni Hotels' Parent Raises Possibility of Selling Chain
description: Wharf Holdings Ltd., a major Hong Kong conglomerate, apparently has raised the possibility of selling some or all of its 45 Omni hotels, although it is unclear whether it currently is interested in a sale.

title: Hanna Andersson and Its Offshoots
description: SINCE 1983, parents have been ordering children's cotton clothing by mail from Hanna Andersson. On July 1, the company will open its first retail store, in the Westchester mall in White Plains.

title: Market Place; The Magellan fund's manager bets on lower interest rates.
description: INVESTORS in America's largest mutual fund might not know it, but they are betting that the Federal Reserve is about to ease interest rates -- and sharply.

title: Bucharest Journal; With Old Tricks, Romania's Old Reds Curb Press
description: On the top floor of a Communist-era apartment block, Neculai Munteanu dons headphones and readies himself before the microphone of a jerry-built hi-tech radio studio for his show, "News for the Trash Can."

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: For a Windy Aerie

title: A Birth Method Stirs a Debate
description: In a promotional video for Russian water birthing, a woman in an advanced stage of labor bobs above wind-tossed waves of the Crimean sea. The camera zooms in as a nude midwife helps the woman to shallow water, where she sprawls against a rock as her baby's head slowly pushes into the chill, bloody water.

title: Remembering the Beverly Hills Hotel
description: To the Editor:

title: Executive Quits As CBS Unit Fills New Job
description: Peter Tortorici, the president of CBS Entertainment, resigned yesterday with the naming of Leslie Moonves, the president of Warner Brothers Television, to a new position in charge of the CBS entertainment division.

title: Merrill Lynch campaign shows a shift to financial planning basics.
description: IN advertising, sentiment is a well-worn tool of the trade. But in a new $22 million campaign devised by Bozell Worldwide for Merrill Lynch, the agency uses a provocative variation -- sentimental comeuppance.

title: Israeli Anthem Revised
description: To the Editor:

title: Editors' Note
description: An illustration on the Education page yesterday with an article about a gift of Cartier heirlooms to St. Louis University was actually a montage of items in the bequest, including two photographs and articles of jewelry. The montage was prepared by the university for publicity.

title: U.S. IS SEEKING SALES DATA FROM COMPUTER RESELLER
description: The Justice Department is asking Government Technology Services Inc. to give the Federal Government information about its sales from 1988 to the present, the company said yesterday. Government Technology, based in Chantilly, Va., is a reseller of microcomputers and work stations to the Government. The company said the agency's civil investigative demand was seeking information about the company's disclosure to the Government and its use of rebates and marketing funds supplied to it by vendors in connection with sales to the General Services Administration. A Government Technology spokesman said the company would not release further information until it had reviewed the request. In Nasdaq trading, shares of Government Technology closed down $2, at $4.75.

title: Neophytes No Match For Gifted and Talented
description: The score, at the close of yet another soggy day at Roland Garros, was two for the past and present French Open champions and nothing for the underqualified opponents, both of them neophyte Grand Slam quarterfinalists.

title: SERVICE CORPORATION TO BUY FUNERAL COMPANY
description: The Service Corporation International said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Gibraltar Mausoleum Corporation for cash and stock valued at about $195 million and assumption of about $54 million in debt. Gibraltar, a privately held funeral services company based in Indianapolis, owns 23 funeral homes and 54 cemeteries in 12 states. Service, a Houston-based funeral and cemetery company with operations in the United States, Canada, Australia and Britain, said Gibraltar had annual revenue of $108 million. Service will issue 3.3 million common shares to Gibraltar and pay about $99 million in cash. Shares of Service rose $1.875, to $30.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Tuesday about the financial results of the Lotus Development Corporation carried erroneous scales in some editions. The figures showing net sales and net income were in millions, not thousands. In 1994, Lotus reported net sales of $970.7 million and a net loss of $20.9 million.

title: U.S. Jet Pilot Lost in Bosnia Is Found Alive
description: The pilot of an American F-16 that was shot down by Serbs over northwestern Bosnia has been found alive by an international rescue team and United States Marines, the Pentagon announced early today.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: SOCCER Akers Will Miss at Least One Game

title: Stewart Enterprises Inc.(STEI,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
19 Nonresident Families Sued for School Fees
description: An Essex County school district yesterday unleashed the latest tactic to keep students from other towns out of their system, filing a lawsuit demanding that the parents of 19 children from outside the district pay back over $500,000 in tuition.

title: Only a Paper Boon; Consumers Aren't Spending Their Profits From Surging Stocks
description: With blue-chip stocks up 16 percent since January, many Americans are a lot richer today than they were on New Year's Day. This year's bull market, the strongest surge since late 1990, has been powered by lower interest rates and rising corporate profits. It has already added more than twice as much to the wealth of America's households as all the money families painstakingly salted away in savings last year.

title: Unmasked German
description: To the Editor:

title: Teaching Nazi Past to German Youth
description: In the tranquillity of the Konrad Adenauer High School, no one has to fret about the kinds of things that worry Americans on campus, like guns or drugs, because such things do not happen here, said Heinz Wilms, a history teacher.

title: Peter Kump, Expert Chef and Cooking Teacher, Dies at 57
description: Peter Kump, one of the most influential figures on the American food scene as founder of Peter Kump's New York Cooking School and the James Beard Foundation, died Wednesday at his weekend home in East Hampton, L.I. He was 57 and also had a home in Manhattan.

title: Mets Gift-Wrap Big Inning for Mlicki
description: Dave Mlicki did not know what kind of lead the Mets needed to feel safe from Barry Bonds, the Giants slugger. Neither did his manager, Dallas Green.

title: Mets Trade Segui to Expos
description: The Mets announced after today's game that they had traded first baseman David Segui to the Montreal Expos for Reid Cornelius, a right-handed pitcher currently playing for Class AAA Ottawa.

title: Kerrey Vows to Stall Telecommunications Bill
description: After laboriously stitching together agreement from industry on a sweeping telecommunications bill, Senate leaders were bogged down today by a maverick Democrat who complained that they had ignored consumers.

title: Now the Banks Turn Against the Elderly To the Editor:   Once again, senior citizens are being singled out as freeloaders (front page, June 5).
description: First we were accused of robbing our grandchildren by accepting our fair share of Social Security and Medicare. Now we are told that banks resent the fact that we no longer borrow from them and that it actually costs them money to process our deposits and checks.

title: Small-School Idea Also Applies to Big Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: The Right Man Who 'Maintained His Cool'
description: The people who know Scott F. O'Grady are overjoyed that he survived for six days on bugs, grass and rainwater in hostile territory. But no one is surprised.

title: McDowell Seems Lost In Yankees' Dense Fog
description: Forty-two days. Enough time to collect six paychecks. Enough time to complete one fourth of this truncated baseball season. Sadly for the Yankees, a month and a half has not been enough time for Jack McDowell to win two games.

title: Maybe They Just Like 3-Card Monte?
description: With a 25-pound stone owl, summons books and lots of dis -- as in disrespect and disdain -- New York City opened a new offensive yesterday against an old foe: the pigeon.

title: Seized Jerusalem Land
description: To the Editor:

title: Alltel to Buy 20% of Go
description: The Alltel Corporation said today that it would acquire a 20 percent stake in the Go Communications Corporation, a wireless communications company based in Alexandria, Va., for $40 million. Alltel, a telecommunications and information services company based in Little Rock, Ark., said Go plans to bid on licenses for wireless telephone services in a coming auction by the Federal Communications Commission. Alltel also said it had agreed to develop and manage Go's billing and data processing systems for the next 10 years.

title: INSIDE
description: Cuts Loom in New York City

title: CHRONICLE
description: Seventy-one years ago, BURGESS MEREDITH was a boy-soprano soloist with the Cathedral School choir at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. The 83-year-old actor is no longer a soprano or a soloist, but on Sunday he will sing with a combined student-adult choir at the cathedral. He will also be the guest speaker at the school's alumni day.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions that are to close soon: Closing This Weekend "A MONTH IN THE COUNTRY," Roundabout Theater, 1530 Broadway, at 45th Street. A Turgenev drama, set in 19th-century Russia, about a woman who falls in love with her son's tutor; with Helen Mirren; directed by Scott Ellis. Through tomorrow. Performances: Today at 8 P.M.; tomorrow at 2 and 8. Limited seating available at $55. Information: (212) 869-8400. "2: GORING AT NUREMBERG," Primary Stages, 354 West 45th Street, Clinton. Romulus Linney's drama about Hitler's deputy. Through Sunday. Performances: Today at 8 P.M.; tomorrow at 2 and 8; Sunday at 3 P.M. Tickets: $25. Information: (212) 333-4052.

title: Changing Plea, Man Admits Montclair Shootings
description: The janitor arrested in the shooting rampage at a post office in Montclair, N.J., admitted his guilt today, reversing an earlier plea. But his terse confession in court did little to explain the mystery of his actions: Why would a man with no criminal record, who came from a religious family and aspired to be a police officer, kill four helpless people and seriously wound another, all for a few thousand dollars?

title: Also of Note
description: Critics' choices of some other Manhattan art shows: ALBERT YORK, Davis & Langdale, 231 East 60th Street (through June 23). A pleasurable selection of 43 paintings, from the late 1950's to the present, by this reclusive master of the small, creamy and offbeat oil sketch. Mr. York's works, which can bring to mind artists as different as Delacroix and Manet, David Park and Jane Freilicher, are remarkably fresh, knowing and sometimes quite funny (Michael Kimmelman).

title: Devils' New Goal Is to Regain Their Spark
description: Jacques Lemaire knew it wasn't going to be easy. He wasn't sure his players felt the same way. That's why he gathered the Devils together today for a meeting.

title: Legal Attack on Tobacco Intensifies
description: The legal assault against the nation's tobacco makers intensified yesterday in response to the disclosure that Philip Morris Inc. had conducted 15 years of research on nicotine and found that it affected smokers' bodies, brains and behavior.

title: Random House Wins 'Huck Finn' Rights
description: Random House has won the battle for the right to publish a new version of "The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn," which will include previously unpublished material from a recently discovered manuscript.

title: Reputed Russian Crime Chief Arrested
description: A man described by Federal authorities as the most powerful Russian organized-crime leader in the United States was arrested in a Brooklyn apartment yesterday and charged with trying to extort $8.5 million from two immigrant businessmen.

title: Dairy Mart Convenience Stores Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 29
description: b-After a charge of $ 389,000, or 7 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.(Loss)

title: A Bruised Knee, a Slippery Case
description: A Baltimore man did indeed fall on a wet floor at the Sands Hotel and Casino here. But the bruise on Robert Ginski's knee did not keep him out of work, the authorities said yesterday, alleging that he faked letters from his employer and doctor saying that the injury cost him $3,000 in wages. Mr. Ginski has been charged with forgery and attempted theft by deception.

title: Getty Petroleum Corp.(GTY,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: b-After a gain of $ 183,000, or 1 cent a share, from an adjustment in accounting.Getty Petroleum said earnings before interest, taxes and depreciation, or EBITD, for the latest first quarter was $ 10.7 million, compared with $ 10.3 million in year-ago period.The company said improvement in EBITD during the latest quarter was due to higher rental income, gains on dispositions of assets and lower selling, general and administrative expenses, and partially offset by higher environmental expenditures.Getty also said higher revenues during the latest quarter are primarily from an increase in average selling prices attributable to the introduction of reformulated gasolines and an increase in retail gallonage sold, partially offset by a decrease in wholesale gallonage sold.

title: U.N. Moves Heavy Guns Near Sarajevo
description: The United Nations peacekeeping force in Bosnia today moved heavy artillery within range of Sarajevo for the first time, apparently signaling a readiness to respond to aggression with considerable force.

title: A Big Hedge Fund Returns $1.3 Billion to Its Investors
description: The Caxton Corporation, a big hedge fund based in New York, returned about $1.3 billion of its capital to investors, saying that its very size had begun to hurt its performance.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about a project to track shad in the Hudson River omitted the identity of the woman in the lower photo in some editions. The woman, shown with a transmitter that is inserted into the fish, was Valerie Whaton.

title: The Dry-Plate Genesis, And What It Wrought
description: Just when the art world seemed to be winding down for the summer, the International Center of Photography has come in with a quiet powerhouse of a show that by any measure is one of the standouts of the season. "An American Century of Photography: From Dry-Plate to Digital" offers nothing less than an expansive, thorough recounting of the last 100 years of photography in this country, based on the great riches of a collection assembled since 1964 by Hallmark Cards.

title: Draining Simpson Session Is Cut Short
description: The O. J. Simpson trial was abruptly adjourned today when jurors, after a long and emotionally draining day of viewing gruesome photographs of the murder victims, could apparently continue no longer.

title: Handleman Co.(HDL,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 29
description: b-Included a $ 5.5 million pretax, or 10 cents a share after tax, charge for the transition to its regional Automated Distribution Center from the current midwestern distribution structure, in the quarter and year.c-Included a $ 2 million pretax, or 3 cents a share after tax, provision in connection with realigning its western region into the first Automated Distribution Center.Handleman said that excluding the provisions for facility realignment recognized in each year, earnings would have been $ 31.4 million, or 94 cents a share, in fiscal 1995, compared with $ 28.9 million, or 86 cents a share, in fiscal 1994, a 9 percent improvement.

title: Restaurants
description: When the right restaurant moves into a neighborhood, it is instantly obvious. Consider the case of the Chelsea Bistro and Bar.

title: Land Sale to Ease Budget Woes
description: Balancing a budget always means making tough choices, and in Essex County it meant selling a huge piece of prime real estate. The Hilltop tract, 365 acres of steep woods straddling Verona, Cedar Grove and North Caldwell, will be sold to the Essex County Improvement Authority for $33 million. The county board of freeholders approved the sale Wednesday.

title: The Baseball Hero Beyond Mere Fame
description: DIMAGGIO The Last American Knight By Joseph Durso Illustrated. 272 pages. Little, Brown. $22.95

title: Corrections
description: The Market Place column in Business Day yesterday, about the Fidelity Magellan fund's anticipation of changes in interest rates, misstated the expected impact of a weak dollar on interest-rate policy. A weak dollar is likely to persuade the Federal Reserve to raise rates, not lower them.

title: Art in Review
description: Alberto Savinio Paolo Baldacci Gallery 41 East 57th Street Manhattan Through next Friday

title: Looking Back Over a Century of Films, and Loving It
description: A glossy valentine produced in association with the American Film Institute, "The First 100 Years: A Celebration of American Movies," begins by declaring that "they amazed us from the start; they amaze us still." The documentary was written and directed by Chuck Workman, who has crammed a staggering number of images into a mere 90 minutes (the final credits are yards long). Its scattered broadcast times on HBO include this afternoon at 4:30.

title: Filming at a School Displeases Cortines
description: The Mayor's office and the New York City Schools Chancellor, ever at odds, now have new grounds for disagreement: the fact that a city public school was used as the site of a terrorist bomb scene in a new film, "Die Hard With a Vengeance."

title: Duplex Products Inc.(DPX,A) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 29
description: b-Included after-tax restructuring charges of $ 7.3 million, or 96 cents a share, in the quarter and 6 months.c-Net loss, which was after a charge of $ 7,084,000, or 92 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.(Loss)

title: Squabbling Continues After Rejection of Lease
description: A day after the Devils spurned a sweetened lease from the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority, the team's owner bluntly explained the rejection.

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about infant safety seats on airliners misstated the position of the Federal Aviation Administration in some copies. As the article reported, the agency said that it opposed requiring babies to ride in safety seats and that certain types of restraints were risky; it did not call all safety seats a bad idea.

title: Panthers Send a Shocked Neilson Packing
description: The Florida Panthers closed a chapter in their young existence yesterday, firing Coach ROGER NEILSON, who had the team within a point of the playoffs in each of its first two seasons.

title: Downed U.S. Pilot Rescued in Bosnia in Daring Raid
description: United States marines staged an audacious rescue mission into the Bosnian war zone after dawn today, snatching up a missing American fighter pilot from his hiding place in the woods and helicoptering him to safety through a smattering of Bosnian Serb missile and machine-gun fire.

title: High-Tech Gorillas vs. Dumbed-Down Scientists
description: The endangered species about which viewers of "Congo" will be most worried is the Michael Crichton thriller. This 1980 best seller is one of the last remaining Crichton novels (after "The Andromeda Strain," "The Terminal Man," "Rising Sun," "Disclosure," etc.) not yet recycled into movie material, and now it meets a dubious fate. This glib, overheated film about vicious primates delivers little suspense, nor are there signs of the 65 cited volumes and articles that turned Mr. Crichton's book into such a learning experience. Also missing is the inspired showmanship with which the author's paranoid naturalism was exploited in "Jurassic Park."

title: Home Video
description: With more people collecting videos, distributors are freshening supplies of vintage items. In stores this summer, or at least those stores that make room for older collectibles, that might mean discovering an "Intermezzo," say, or a "Compulsion" or, in September, a reissued "Magic Flute."

title: Step Right Up! See the Bearded Person!
description: THREE stiltwalkers are in a dusty yard on West 134th Street in Harlem, surrounded by abandoned buildings. The stiltwalkers wear tops with stars and multi-colored ribbons, striped pants, strange helmets with long plumes glittering in the sun. They are ambiguous figures. Male or female? One has a beard. But . . . you can't be sure. This is the opening act of Circus Amok, an alternative circus performing in parks throughout New York City until June 18.

title: Two Forecasts on Tax-Cut Plan
description: Senate President Donald DiFrancesco says he has no doubts: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's income tax cut plan will be ready for her signature on June 26.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * American Airlines, Dallas, a unit of AMR Corp., is selling $63.5 million of pass-through certificates due in 2017 through J. P. Morgan Securities. The certificates carry an interest rate of 8.39 percent and are priced at par. The issue is rated A3 by Moody's Investors Service and BBB- by the Standard and Poor's Corp.

title: Should She Work Or Play?
description: Daisy von Scherler Mayer's silly urban comedy "Party Girl" imagines bohemian life on the Lower East Side of Manhattan as a floating open-house bash at which the worldbeat never slacks and hair colors and costumes change nightly. The area's clubs and lofts teem with exotic 20-something punks, transvestites and aspiring celebutantes of every race, sex and nationality eager to imbibe any potion that can perpetuate the fantasy.

title: Tartabull Asks to Be Traded
description: Danny Tartabull is apparently tired of being criticized by George Steinbrenner, tired of sitting on the bench against certain right-handed pitchers and tired of being booed at Yankee Stadium. Yesterday, he asked the Yankees to trade him, a club official said.

title: airo Journal; Nights on the Nile: Under the 7 Veils, a Russian?
description: Egyptian belly dancers, condemned by Islamic militants as licentious and scorned by the general public as disreputable, face a new onslaught from Russian rivals, who have invaded the nightclubs that line the road to the pyramids and crowd the banks of the Nile.

title: 2d Bankruptcy At Spectravision
description: Spectravision Inc., the nation's largest provider of pay-per-view movies to hotels, is back in bankruptcy court less than three years after its previous reorganization, as losses mount and the company continues to stagger under a heavy debt load.

title: Harvard Journal; A College and Its Graduates Move On
description: It was raining, but was it commencement week at Harvard University and the greatest home-run hitter of all time was not about to be rained out of this appearance, as class-day speaker.

title: British G.E. Raises Its Bid for Submarine Maker
description: The General Electric Company of Britain raised its takeover offer today for the submarine maker VSEL P.L.C., topping British Aerospace P.L.C.'s competing bid by about 34 percent.

title: Greif Brothers reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: Share and per-share earnings are class A common shares, and have been adjusted for the 2-for-1 stock split paid on March 10.Greif Bros. is traded on the Chicago Stock Exchange with the ticker symbol GBC.

title: Brown-Forman (BF.B,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: b-After charge equaled to 4 cents a share for an accounting change. The change had no net effect on full-year results.c-After $ 5.35 million after-tax charge associated with the consumer durables segment for the closing or reformating of seven retail stores, in the quarter and year. The year was also after gain of about $ 18,350,000 for the sale of the company's credit-card processing business and charge of $ 3,580,000 for the retroactive effect of a higher tax rate on earnings from Jan. 1, 1993, to April 30, 1993.The 1984 year was also after a charge of $ 32,542,000, or 41 cents a share, for the cumulative effect of accounting change for postretirement benefits other than pensions, postemployment benefits, and contributions received and contributions made.Brown-Forman said that excluding special items in the year-ago periods, the company had net income of $ 35,677,000, or 52 cents a share, in the fourth quarter, and net income of $ 151,649,000, or $ 1.92 a share, for the fiscal year.The company also has class A shares traded on The New York Stock Exchange with the ticker symbol BF.A.

description: In percent

title: No Arbitration as Twins Sign Knoblauch
description: The Minnesota Twins signed the last of their four arbitration-eligible players yesterday, agreeing to a one-year, $2,987,500 deal with second baseman CHUCK KNOBLAUCH, a two-time All-Star who had asked for $3,425,000, while the Twins were offering $2.55 million. He was scheduled for a hearing today. Minnesota hasn't gone to arbitration with a player since 1987. Knoblauch, American League rookie of the year in 1991, earned $1,625,000 last year.

title: Sanchez Vicario and Graf Bracing for a 2-in-1 Battle in France
description: The favorites punched in, the challengers punched out; the two leading ladies of tennis prefer not to have it any other way.

title: Abroad at Home; 'A Culture of Rights'
description: Until a few years ago South Africa was an extreme example of a country that exalted the power of the state. Today it makes the rights of the individual the society's highest value.

title: Art in Review
description: Kurt Schwitters Michael Werner Gallery 21 East 67th Street Manhattan Through June 30

title: Gussie Mae Makes It, Finally
description: Gussie Mae finally won a race. The victory cost him a record.

title: In Search Of Answers In Wrong Places
description: After a few drinks, after saying, "My only regret is that I didn't take better care of myself," Mickey Mantle might hunch forward and narrow his eyes and add, "People think that my legs and my injuries hampered me a lot; they did, but if I had taken better care like Willie Mays and Stan Musial and Hank Aaron, the guys that are up in the record books, Pete Rose. . . ." His voice would trail off and the eyes would seem wistful.

title: Maxxim Medical Inc.(MAM,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: b-After a gain of $ 380,000, or 6 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of adopting Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No. 109, ''Accounting for Income Taxes.''Sales are net sales.

title: House G.O.P. Narrowing Bill On Deregulation
description: Abandoning an effort to broadly rewrite the rules that have separated banks from the rest of the nation's financial systems, the chairman of the House Commerce Committee said today that he had been unable to broker a compromise to allow mergers between banks and insurance companies.

title: Ernst Home Center Inc.(ERNS,NNM) reports earnings for 13wks to Apr 29
description: b-Net income, and the 9 months was after a one-time gain of $ 7,961,000, or 85 cents a share, from the cumulative effects of adopting SFAS No. 109, relating to accounting for income taxes, and SFAS No. 106, relating to accounting for postretirement benefits.(Loss)The per share earnings and shares outstanding for the year-ago periods are pro forma. The company completed its initial public offering in September 1994.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; For the networks, a bull market in advance sales of commercial time.
description: DON'T be surprised if the next network television executive you see is sporting a goofy grin and chanting an old cigarette slogan: "It's what's up front that counts."

title: City Shortfall Even Worse Than Forecast
description: Just hours after lawmakers in Albany finally adopted a state budget, a grim reality settled over City Hall: New York City will receive $670 million less in state assistance than requested -- far less than expected even a week ago.

title: Microsoft's On-Line Plan Is Scrutinized
description: It may not be a full-blown investigation yet, but the Justice Department is giving Microsoft's plans to enter the commercial on-line business in August a hard look. In the last two weeks, Justice Department officials have been asking questions of executives of services like America Online, Compuserve and Prodigy and to their lawyers, some of the people questioned say.

title: On My Mind; Legal and Damnable
description: The story in the paper stuck with me as I was doing reporting on other things, even when I was writing about them. After a bit I knew why -- this story was a personal assault, a mugging on a lighted street.

title: Genovese Drug Stores Inc.(GDXA,A) reports earnings for Qtr to May 26
description: b-Included a gain of $ 715,000, or 7 cents a share, from the sale of the nursing home division.

title: SMITHKLINE IN DRUG VENTURE WITH SARNOFF RESEARCH
description: The British pharmaceutical giant SmithKline Beecham P.L.C. and the David Sarnoff Research Center Inc. said yesterday that they would collaborate to develop a device for the rapid screening of molecules for drug discovery. To develop and commercialize the device, Sarnoff will form a company in which it will have a majority stake. SmithKline, which has its United States headquarters in Philadelphia, will hold a stake in the new company and have access to any devices developed. The American depository receipts of SmithKline rose $1.625, to $44, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title:
About Real Estate;
Market May Be Sluggish, But Luxury Houses Sell
description: The residential market in the suburbs of New York City is generally sluggish. But the demand for new luxury single-family homes has been more consistent, resulting in a spurt of such housing.

title: BIG O TIRES APPROVES SWEETENED BUYOUT OFFER
description: Big O Tires Inc. said yesterday that its directors had approved in principle a sweetened $54.6 million buyout offer from a management group headed by Steven P. Cloward, the president of the company. The offer of $16.50 a share is subject to final approval by the board and stockholders. Shares of Big O Tires rose $1, to $15, in Nasdaq trading. In April the board rejected a buyout offer of $16 a share from the management group, which also includes Big O Tire Dealers of America, a group of franchise holders. Big O Tires, based in Englewood, Colo., franchises retail tire and auto service stations and distributes its private brand of tires and other brands.

title: Fleshing Out Jung's Theory
description: DO you believe with Sigmund Freud that sex is at the root of everything? Or do you side with Carl Jung, especially with his theory of the collective unconscious: human behavior is influenced by mythological images and archetypes that have been buried in the mind since time's beginning? Have you ever been analyzed by anybody other than your so-called best friend? Do your eyes glaze when someone insists on telling you last night's dream? Have you read to the end of this paragraph?

title: Budget Conferees Gather, But Not Really to Confer
description: The Senate-House conference committee on the Federal budget met for the first time today, and this much was settled:

title: International Briefs; Deutsche Telekom Cut Losses in 1994
description: The German telephone company Deutsche Telekom A.G. said yesterday that it had slashed its losses in 1994 by cutting jobs and wiring up more than 1.2 million new customers in the former East Germany. The company predicted a "considerably improved" result for this year. Net losses were trimmed to 300 million marks ($214.3 million) in 1994 from 1.6 billion marks in 1993. Excluding 1.6 billion in losses carried forward from previous years, Deutsche Telekom said it made a pretax profit of 1.3 billion marks.

title: The Director Emulated By Bergman
description: When Ingmar Bergman was a fledgling artist, he scribbled a story in a blue notebook. That schoolboy fiction, based on his torturous final year at school, became his first produced screenplay, "Torment," a 1944 film directed not by Mr. Bergman but by Alf Sjoberg. The young Bergman was thrilled to be in such hands. Though little known in the United States even now, Sjoberg (1903-1980) was one of the masters of the underrated Swedish cinema, and his career as a theater director and as a writer and director of films was a model for Mr. Bergman's.

title: Welcome Mat for Foreign Banks
description: A cold war-era law that forbids foreign banks to open offices in New Jersey took two big steps toward the scrap heap of history yesterday as committees in the State Senate and Assembly approved bills that would remove restrictions. The legislation got a big push from officials in Hudson County who believe that Jersey City, already a budding financial center, could see an influx of jobs and tax revenue.

description: Baseball American League

description: b-Net income(Loss)The company said the poorer results reflect the decrease in the value of the Canadian dollar compared to the United States dollar. It noted that major expenses such as fuel, aircraft lease payments and foreign hotel accommodation fees are payable in U.S. dollars.The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: In Looping Lines, a Clue To the Elusive Malraux
description: Who was Andre Malraux? The question probably sounds absurd to older Americans for whom he equaled French culture in the years before and after World War II. Like Sartre, Malraux was an intellectual celebrity. Every educated person in this country knew who he was, and even what he looked like, with his deep-set eyes, Byronic gaze, slicked-back hair and omnipresent cigarette, which he waved around in "a kind of aerial dogfight," as one observer wrote. There were various Malrauxs, and all of them were famous: Malraux the adventurer, Malraux the Resistance hero, Malraux the novelist, Malraux the art writer, Malraux the hypnotic orator, Malraux the Communist sympathizer, Malraux the Gaullist.

title: Trevor N. Dupuy, 79, Prolific Military Historian
description: Trevor N. Dupuy, a prolific military historian and battlefield theorist whose expertise extended over 5,000 years of warfare, from the conflicts of ancient Egypt to the Persian Gulf war of 1991, took his life on Monday, three weeks after learning that he was terminally ill. He was 79 and lived in Vienna, Va.

title: Chic Venue, New Owner
description: The Russian Tea Room, the world-famous restaurant and celebrity haunt next to Carnegie Hall on West 57th Street, has changed hands.

title: For Defense Lawyer in Bomb Case, Latest in a Line of Unpopular Clients
description: Over the last three decades, Michael E. Tigar, a law professor at the University of Texas, has represented many of the most vilified criminal defendants. So his assignment last month to represent Terry L. Nichols, one of two men accused of blowing up the Federal Building in Oklahoma City, is hardly novel.

title: Baseball Takes Steps to Speed Up the Game
description: Major league baseball owners, expressing alarm that nine-inning games that took approximately two and a half hours to play less than 20 years ago now last three hours, adopted six recommendations today to roll back the clock.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about the recent performance of the Lotus Development Corporation referred incorrectly to the origin of one software product, Lotus Notes. It was created by Iris Associates, which was acquired by Lotus last year -- not by Softswitch Inc., also acquired last year.

title: Affirmative Action Makes Colleges Better
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Envoy to Press a Wary Seoul on Atom Talks
description: The United States, struggling to persuade a reluctant South Korea to endorse an agreement intended to end any nuclear threat from North Korea, has dispatched a senior diplomat to Seoul to discuss the issue with the South Korean President.

title: New York Hospitals Show a High Rate Of Newborn Deaths
description: A New York State Health Department study has found an unexpectedly high number of deaths among newborns in some of the city's busiest public and private hospitals.

title: Mishima's View of Marquis de Sade
description: First seen here two years ago, Ingmar Bergman's stunning production of Yukio Mishima's "Madame de Sade" has returned to the Brooklyn Academy of Music, where it opened Wednesday night and will be available for just two more performances, today and tomorrow at 8 P.M.
