title: Getting Tough on Ex-Convicts
description: Since a parolee from Pennsylvania killed a Gloucester County police officer last month, New Jersey's parole system has been under scrutiny. One parole officer told a legislative hearing yesterday that he and his colleagues believe they have very little leeway to reject out-of-state parolees who meet residency and job requirements. "It's a source of frustration," Anthony Sgro said.

title: Stock Close Mixed, With Dow Off 3.46
description: The stock market was mixed but little changed yesterday in advance of the release this morning of the Producer Price Index. The index will be the first major economic indicator since traders began thinking seriously of the economy as coping with a recession rather than just a slowdown that offers still-robust corporate profits.

title: Sports of The Times; Bonds Could Learn From Saint Nick
description: HE didn't have to relive his nightmare at the free-throw line, but he did. He could have hid behind any number of industry cliches, but he didn't. Nick Anderson sat himself in the bleachers yesterday and patiently explained what it was like to miss not one, not two, not three, but four free throws that would have iced a game his team eventually lost.

title: This Time, Young Hands Out the Honor
description: STEVE YOUNG, the San Francisco 49ers quarterback and Super Bowl most valuable player, returned to Greenwich, Conn., yesterday to pay tribute to his former math teacher, TERRY LOWE, and present him with the National Football League 1994 teacher of the year award. Young nominated his former Greenwich High School advanced-placement calculus teacher for the award.

title: Sentencing Reform Has Nothing to Hide
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: Originally, the plan to establish the MARTIN DUBERMAN Fellowship in Lesbian and Gay Studies was to have been a surprise for the celebration, on Wednesday, of Mr. Duberman's 65th birthday.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Beyond Fish, Way Beyond

title: ECHO BAY VENTURE TO ACQUIRE COPPER AND GOLD PROJECT
description: Echo Bay Mines Ltd. and its Canadian joint venture partner, TVI Pacific Inc., agreed in principle yesterday to acquire the Kingking copper and gold project in the Philippines from the Benguet Corporation for as much as $67 million. The agreement calls for Echo Bay, based in Denver, to own 75 percent of the mine, which is on the southern island of Mindanao. TVI Pacific, based in Calgary, Alberta, will hold the remaining 25 percent. Echo Bay said it expected to pay at least $50.3 million for its share. The mine contains 5.3 million troy ounces of gold and 3.1 billion pounds of copper, of which 3.8 million ounces of gold and 2.2 billion pounds of copper are expected to be recoverable, Echo Bay said.

title: General Host Corp.(GH,N) reports earnings for Qtr to May 21
No Headline
description: This is Basher-52. I'm alive and I need help. -- CAPT. SCOTT F. O'GRADY, before his rescue in Bosnia. [ A1:6. ]

title: The Simpson Jury's Right to Be Needy
description: How they bicker, how they kvetch, those jurors in the O. J. Simpson trial. And then they manage to force Judge Lance Ito to release them, and who can blame them? We're down to two survivors among the alternates, and no one will be surprised if they turn into jurors soon. After that they can harass their companions or appear to be writing a book and then they too can depart.

title: Grace Avoided Tax, Former Auditor Says
description: W. R. Grace & Company's former audit chief says in a lawsuit that the company set up a reserve fund and used it to avoid paying Federal taxes owed by its health care unit.

title: Brake Failure Was Cited in '87 Subway Crash
description: The emergency brake system that the Transit Authority counts on to keep subway trains from running red lights has failed once before, transit officials said yesterday.

title: Late Budget In Hand, Pataki Faces Power Shift
description: Was it just coincidence, or was there some Democratic design behind bringing the budget in so close to a new record for lateness?

title: Gen. Juan Carlos Ongania, Argentine Ex-President, 81
description: Gen. Juan Carlos Ongania, a cavalryman who was Argentina's repressive President from 1966 to 1970, died yesterday at the Military Hospital in Buenos Aires. He was 81 and lived in a suburb of Buenos Aires.

title: Article 290895 -- No Title
description: If a restaurant fails in one location, you can't just pick it up, move it and start all over again somewhere else. But Mellyana Alaties, a waitress and manager at Nusantara, an Indonesian restaurant on the East Side that closed last year, did the next best thing. She opened a new Indonesian restaurant, Bali Nusa Indah, on the West Side and took along the entire staff of Nusantara, including the chef.

title: Jerry Zipkin, Who Lunched And Listened, Is Dead at 80
description: Jerry Zipkin, a celebrated fixture on the international social scene for almost half a century, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 80.

title: Eyelashes Sufficient To Be Wigs
description: Mistress Formika (sometimes a guy named Mike) opens "Wigstock: The Movie" singing "The Age of Aquarius" in elbow-length purple gloves, a long skinny diva dress and a wig with furled braids sticking out of her head like giant Mouseketeer ears. Partly a documentary and partly a celebration of outrageous wigginess, the film chronicles the annual drag festival that takes place in downtown Manhattan over Labor Day weekend. The singing and lip-synching men onstage wear mountainous blue and pink wigs and sequins to spare, and the audience is almost as fantastically glamorized. A distant cousin to the Halloween parade in Greenwich Village, Wigstock, the event and the movie, is good-natured, campy fun.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: HIGH HOSPITAL MORTALITY FOR NEWBORNS A State Health Department study has found an unexpectedly high number of deaths among newborns in some of New York City's busiest public and private hospitals. Officials have not identified a cause for the high mortality rates, which at some hospitals are roughly 50 percent above the national average. But they have ordered an extensive investigation. [ Page A1. ] OFFICER QUITS OVER WASHINGTON RAMPAGE One New York City police officer has resigned and two others have been suspended from the force because of their participation in a drunken spree through seven Washington hotels three weeks ago, police officials said. [ A1. ]

title: Rescue in Bosnia
description: The sunrise rescue of Capt. Scott O'Grady displayed American military performance and NATO coordination at its best. Sophisticated technology and raw courage combined to produce a happy ending to the closest American brush with death under fire in Bosnia's three-year-old war. Whatever their views on the proper role of United States forces in Bosnia, Americans can rejoice at a rescue mission well accomplished.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CONAGRA INC., Omaha, completed the acquisition of the Van Camp's canned bean and Wolf Brand chili businesses from the Quaker Oats Co., Chicago, for undisclosed terms. LAKELAND FIRST FINANCIAL GROUP INC., Succasunna, N.J., a bank holding company, said its shareholders had approved its acquisition by Valley National Bancorp, Wayne, N.J., in a stock swap valued at $27.6 million.

title: Private Company Narrows Its Focus to 5 Hartford Schools
description: A private education company that gained national attention after signing a contract last year to manage this city's entire troubled public school system has narrowed its plans and now expects to concentrate on just 5 of the system's 32 schools this fall.

title: Washington Talk; A Senator Holds the Center for Medicaid
description: Whether it be an era of Democratic dominance or Republican revolution, the middle usually matters in the Senate. This explains the continued relevance of Senator John H. Chafee, the moderate Republican from Rhode Island, even as the political world on Capitol Hill has been made anew.

title: Treasuries Fall Hard Again As Rate-Cut Hopes Recede
description: Fading expectations of a cut in interest rates anytime soon caused prices of Treasury securities to pull back sharply for a second consecutive day yesterday.

title: Inside Art
description: Loyalty to Art and Yale

title: Robert Vesco, Fugitive Financier, Is Arrested in Cuba, the U.S. Says
description: The Cuban Government has arrested Robert L. Vesco, who fled the United States in 1973 to avoid swindling charges, and has approached Washington about returning him here, Clinton Administration officials said today.

title: Art in Review
description: Jeff Wall Marian Goodman Gallery 24 West 57th Street Manhattan Through tomorrow

title: International Briefs; Zeneca Shares Jump On Takeover Talk
description: The shares of Zeneca Group P.L.C. jumped yesterday amid speculation that the company might be a takeover target. Zeneca said, however, that it knew of no reason for the share rise. The drug maker has for months been the subject of speculation it would be the subject of a hostile bid by a major pharmaceutical company seeking to cut costs by consolidating. Zeneca, which was spun off from Imperial Chemical Industries P.L.C. in 1993, has a strong franchise in the anti-cancer and heart treatment markets.

title: Now the Banks Turn Against the Elderly; A Changing Scene
description: To the Editor:

title: Japan Announces Package To Deal With Banks' Crisis
description: Describing Japan's banking crisis as the worst since the Great Depression, Finance Minister Masayoshi Takemura today announced a rescue package aimed at restoring confidence in the financial system, but the plan contained few concrete steps.

title: 3 Are Held in Plot to Sell Material to Iraq
description: Three men from Queens and Long Island, apparently in collusion with a Russian general, smuggled nearly eight tons of material used in nuclear reactors from a military stockpile in Ukraine, stored most of it in a warehouse in Queens and spread the word that they would sell it to the highest bidder, Federal officials said yesterday.

title: Affirmative Action Makes Colleges Better
description: To the Editor:

title: Give Them an Alternative to the Drug Trade
description: To the Editor:

title: At the Bar; For the Clinton Administration, a constitutional scholar forges opinions from theory and real life.
description: On a recent morning, the Clinton Administration's designated arbiter of what is and what is not constitutional was summoned to the White House to pronounce upon a policy. He donned a safety helmet, leaped upon his bike and pedaled the half mile from his Justice Department office to the meeting.

title: Zirconium: Covering for Fuel Rods
description: Zirconium is used in nuclear reactors to provide the cladding, or outer covering, for the cylindrical fuel rods that power a nuclear reaction. Packed inside the zirconium cladding are pellets of uranium oxide or other fissionable materials.

title: Jets' Front Office Continues to Swirl
description: The transformation of the Jets continued yesterday, this time to the front office. Two longtime scouts, JOE COLLINS and DON GRAMMER, have been replaced by two former Steelers associates of DICK HALEY, the Jets' de facto general manager.

title: CHRONICLE
description: NEEN HUNT has been named executive director of the newly formed Mary Woodard Lasker Trust and executive vice president of the 50-year-old Albert and Mary Lasker Foundation, the foundation's president, JAMES W. FORDYCE, announced this week.

title: President Replaced At Warwick Baker
description: Bob Fiore, president and chief creative officer at Warwick Baker & Fiore in New York for the last decade, is being replaced unexpectedly, effective immediately, by Kevin O'Neill, who has held a top creative position at Ammirati & Puris/Lintas in New York.

title: MASCO MAY GIVE UP ITS HOME FURNISHINGS BUSINESS
description: The Masco Corporation said yesterday that it might divest itself of its home furnishings business by selling the unit to an outside buyer or creating an independent company through either a public sale of stock or a spinoff of new shares to its current stockholders. Masco said it wanted to focus on home improvement and building products. Masco said its home furnishings group had sales of about $1.9 billion in 1994 and operating profit of about $80 million. The unit includes the Henredon, Drexel Heritage, Lexington, Universal, Berkline, Bench Craft, Maitland-Smith and Robert Allen Fabrics brands. Shares of Masco were unchanged at $28.625 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Mr. Clinton's First Veto
description: If not the shot heard round the world, President Clinton's veto of a Republican-sponsored $16.4 billion budget cut was a welcome and overdue display of White House resolve.

title: Risen From the Past, Precise and Polished
description: "Red Buttons! I haven't seen you in so long I thought we were both dead."

title: Nikkei Index Plunges 2.6%
description: Stock prices plunged again here today, sending the Nikkei index of 225 issues down 2.6 percent, as investors worried that a Japanese Government plan to help banks dispose of bad loans was not sufficient to do the job.

title: Hill, Holliday Chairman to Retire
description: George J. (Jay) Hill 3d, chairman and partner of Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos in Boston, said yesterday that he would retire from his active role at the agency he helped to found 27 years ago.

title: Meat Seller Accused in Scheme
description: People called him Chuckie the meat man because he said he was in the wholesale meat and fish business. But the authorities say that Charles N. Cugliari was really in the business of running a pyramid scheme that cost investors $80 million. Mr. Cugliari, who pleaded not guilty yesterday to fraud and money laundering charges, will go on trial July 12.

title: Market Place; Regulatory Alarms Ring on Wall St.
description: With the frenzy of merger deals and takeover battles these days, it seems like old times on Wall Street in more ways than one. Securities regulators say they are opening investigations into insider trading at a rate not seen since the mid 1980's, the era in which Ivan Boesky, who went to jail for trading on inside information, became a household name.

title: School Prayer Debate Opens With Everything but Silence
description: Heated exchanges erupted in Congress today over one of the most contentious issues lawmakers will face, a constitutional amendment on school prayer.

title: Chock Full O'Nuts Corp.(CHF,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: b-Net lossc-Included an after-tax gain of $ 7,068,000, or 67 cents a share, on the sale of the company's specialty coffee operations.(Loss)The results for the year-ago 9 months included net sales of $ 9,557,000, net income of $ 1,093,000, or 10 cents a share, of the specialty coffee product line sold in November 1993.Sales are net sales.

title: 'Play Ball!' 'Faster!'
description: Baseball owners unanimously backed six proposals to shorten the time of games, including one to keep hitters in the batter's box.

title: Now the Banks Turn Against the Elderly; No to Teller Fees
description: To the Editor:

title: Stroll Through the Gardens of Fashion
description: The Costume Institute of the Metropolitan Museum of Art has dipped into its overflowing vaults and pulled out a plum of a collection. It's not planned to illuminate any arcane fashion strain, though specialists may spot some dressmaking techniques they were not aware of. But the aim is not so much educational as it is entertaining. The exhibition is as lighthearted as a walk down a garden path or through a roomful of paintings by Renoir. With a single exception, there are no hidden meanings. The overall message is, simply, "enjoy."

title: Shift Blocked In Rockefeller Center Stake
description: The shareholders of Rockefeller Center Properties Inc. voted down a proposal yesterday that would have given Goldman, Sachs & Company the chance to own a controlling stake in the company, which is a real estate investment trust holding a $1.3 billion mortgage on the bankrupt Rockefeller Center.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about trading in the credit markets on Wednesday misstated the given name of the chairman of the Federal Reserve, whose comments helped send Treasury prices lower. He is Alan Greenspan.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: Well, that's it. The season is officially over.

title: It's Not in 'Serious' Talks to Sell Hotels, Omni Chain Parent Says
description: Wharf (Holdings) Ltd. has been approached by several parties to discuss the sale of some or all of its 45 Omni hotels, but it is not holding "serious" discussions with any potential suitor at present, an executive of the conglomerate said today.

title: Riots by Vietnamese Erode Plan to Send Them Home
description: An international plan to end the 20-year sojourn of the Vietnamese boat people and force the last of them back to their homeland is in danger of unraveling after riots by the Vietnamese in detention camps across Southeast Asia.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Lotus Ability to Deal May Lack Strength

title: Ex-Replacement Player Sues Yanks for Termination Pay
description: The curse of Replacement Baseball lives, at least as far as the Yankees are concerned.

title: Opposition on Bosnia
description: Hours after President Clinton celebrated the downed pilot's rescue with a cigar on a White House balcony, he faced renewed Congressional demands to change policy on Bosnia.

title: Overnight and Under the Stars
description: IT happened about 11 on a Saturday night. Roy had already pitched the first tent of his life (Dad's first since Boy Scout days), stroked the belly of an alligator, pondered why golf courses in the desert might not be a great idea for the environment, learned that boa constrictors swallow 35-pound pigs every three weeks or so and gobbled enough free Power Ranger candy to keep him awake forever and ever.

title: Cigars and Conversation In the Course of Revelation
description: The first moments of the new film by Wayne Wang and Paul Auster remind us that Sir Walter Raleigh found a way to weigh smoke by subtracting ash from tobacco and calculating the difference. That's easier than taking the measure of "Smoke" itself, an inviting but evanescent film that does have casualness, curiosity value and a lot of talent on its side.

title: Art in Review
description: Fred Tomaselli Jack Tilton Gallery 49 Greene Street SoHo Through June 17

title: Progress on the Police Rampage
description: The investigation into the drunken rampage by New York City police officers three weeks ago in Washington D.C. is beginning to show results. One officer has resigned and two others have been suspended from the force for participating in the near-riot that wrecked several hotels during a police gathering in Washington.

title: A Liberal Takes Half a Loaf; An Unlikely Bipartisan Hero in Hartford
description: State Representative William R. Dyson, for years one of the legislature's most outspoken voices for the poor, was arguing in favor of an idea he hates -- the fingerprinting of welfare recipients -- to prevent something he hates more: a nearly 50 percent cut in benefits.

title: Former Clinton Aide Pleads Guilty to Misusing U.S.-Backed Loan
description: A former aide to Gov. Bill Clinton in Arkansas, Stephen A. Smith, today pleaded guilty to conspiring to misapply a Federally backed loan and agreed to cooperate with the Whitewater independent counsel.

title: 11 Linked to Homemade Bombs LITTLE EGG HARBOR TOWNSHIP
description: Homemade bombs, made with granulated chlorine, have damaged mailboxes and a golf course since March 14. The culprits, the police say, are 11 teen-age boys who now face charges of possession of explosive devices and criminal mischief.

title: VOLVO BUS UNIT COMPLETES DEAL FOR CANADIAN CONCERN
description: Volvo Buses, the bus manufacturing arm of the Swedish auto maker A.B. Volvo, said yesterday that it had completed its acquisition of the Canadian bus maker Prevost Car Inc. for 740 million Swedish kronor, or about $102 million. Volvo plans to sell a 49 percent stake in Prevost to Henlys Group P.L.C. of Britain. The deals, announced in May, have been cleared by the authorities of all the countries involved. Prevost holds a 20 percent share of the North American market, Volvo said.

title: Off Screen, a Detective Fights Drugs in Schools
description: CALVIN HART strode to the podium at Public School 40, his bald head shining under the lights. Built like a missile, he looked a little scary in his gray-green suit, fairly filling up the stage. He stroked his goatee.

title: Touch of Intrigue: Lukas Colts on Outside
description: One of them is the son of Risen Star, who won the Belmont Stakes in 1988, and the grandson of Secretariat, who won it by 31 lengths in 1973. One is the son of Easy Goer, who won it in 1989. One is the full brother to Go and Go, the Irish colt who won it in 1990. And then there is the one Nick Zito calls "the horse with the funny name," Is Sveikatas, which means something like "Cheers" in Lithuanian.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TRACK AND FIELD World Record in 5,000 Meters Moses Kiptanui of Kenya broke the men's 5,000-meter world record yesterday, clocking 12 minutes 55.30 seconds at the Mobil Grand Prix Golden Gala meet in Rome. The previous record was 12:56.96, set last June by Haile Gebrselassie of Ethiopia. Kiptanui's countryman, Daniel Komen, finished second in the 5,000, also under the previous record, in 12:56.12. Komen's time was a world record for juniors.

title: For New Jersey Welfare Recipients, a Rule to Join H.M.O.'s
description: All New Jersey welfare recipients, except the elderly, disabled and the chronically ill, will soon be required to join a health maintenance organization, a move state officials say will provide better health care and reduce state and Federal Medicaid costs by millions of dollars.

title: Jeffrey Z. Rubin, 54, an Expert on Negotiation
description: Jeffrey Z. Rubin, an academic expert in and author on the art of negotiation, died on Saturday in a mountaineering accident in Baxter State Park in Maine. He was 54 and lived in Newton, Mass.

title: A Hasty Response to Terrorism
description: The Senate is congratulating itself for passing the Comprehensive Terrorism Protection Act of 1995 just seven weeks after the Oklahoma City bombing. But the Senate's hasty and ill-considered action has come at a price. Steps designed to protect Americans' physical safety will in many cases erode their liberties.

title: What's Disney in Park To Most New Yorkers?
description: To the Editor:

title: Japanese Are in Rush to Sell Their Real Estate in the U.S.
description: Japanese companies, which unleashed one of the biggest international flows of investment ever when they flooded the United States with capital during the 1980's, are selling off many of their American assets with growing haste in a critical area, real estate, a new survey shows.

title: INCO TO ACQUIRE INTEREST IN MINING DISCOVERY
description: The Canadian mining concern Inco Ltd. agreed yesterday to acquire a 25 percent interest in the Voisey Bay discovery of nickel, copper and cobalt from Diamond Fields Resources Inc. for $386.7 million in preferred stock. Inco also agreed to pay $18 million in cash to finance a feasibility study and exploration work in the claim area, which is in Labrador. As part of the transaction, Inco bought two million shares of Diamond Fields Resources for $68 million from three entities: two investment funds of Robertson Stephens & Company, the Contrarian fund and the Orphan fund, which together sold 1.7 million shares, and a trust related to the co-chairman of Diamond Fields Resources, Jean-Raymond Boulle. Inco, based in Toronto, also plans to buy back about 10 million of its common shares. Shares of Inco rose $1.25, to $25.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Administration, Burned in Past, Declines to Join Challenge to Gay Rights Ban
description: The Clinton Administration, which has taken some of its worst political beatings over its occasional support of gay rights, has decided not to join in the legal attack in the Supreme Court on Colorado's ban on all measures protecting homosexuals against discrimination.

title: 2 Are Killed in Restaurant
description: Two men were shot and killed yesterday by three gunmen who burst into a restaurant in Elmhurst, Queens, the police said.

title: Three Officers Disciplined For Drunken Hotel Spree
description: A New York City police officer has resigned and two others have been suspended from the force because of their participation in a drunken spree through seven Washington hotels three weeks ago, police officials said yesterday.

title: Art in Review
description: Win Knowlton Bill Maynes Contemporary Art 225 Lafayette Street SoHo Through tomorrow

title: House Votes to Lift Bosnia Arms Ban
description: The House defied the Clinton Administration today and approved a sweeping foreign aid bill that includes an amendment, passed easily, to end United States participation in the arms embargo against Bosnia.

title: Semper Fi, and Proud: Marines Do Their Job
description: It was a good day to be a marine.

title: Art in Review
description: Mike Disfarmer Staley Wise Gallery 560 Broadway (at Prince Street) SoHo Through tomorrow

title: Briton Suggests U.N. May Leave Bosnia
description: Britain's Defense Minister said today that the United Nations should withdraw its troops from Bosnia, perhaps by this fall, if Bosnian Serbs continued to challenge the United Nations mission there.

title: Air & Water Technologies Corp.(AWT,A) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $ 34,956,000, or $ 1.39 a share, in the quarter and $ 41,579,000, or $ 1.66 a share, in the 6 months. The 6 months also reflected charges of $ 14.5 million for contemplated divestitures.Sales in the latest second quarter reflected the contribution of Professional Services Group, which Air & Water Technologies acquired in June 1994 as part of its strategic alliance with Compagnie Generale des Eaux, as well as an increase in sales at Research-Cottrell.(Loss)

title: P. J. Harvey Breaks Down Love to Its Scary Essentials
description: Composure can be devastating, and P. J. Harvey knows it. At the Academy on Wednesday night in the first of two sold-out concerts, Ms. Harvey wailed and moaned, yelped and growled while her new band pounded out primal blues riffs and slow, stark backdrops for ballads. She was singing about love stripped of all romantic comforts: love that would be heaven or hell, all-consuming and irrevocable, as strong as religious faith and as terrifying as a revelation. But she sang about abandon without giving in to it; every phrase was controlled, every gesture plotted. From the blues, Ms. Harvey has learned how to visit the abyss without falling in.

title: From Democrats, Another Welfare Plan
description: After months of debate over Republican plans to revise the nation's main welfare program, Senate Democrats today unveiled a new counterproposal, a plan that would retain guaranteed payments to poor families but limit them to five years.

title: Lotus Chairman Is Seeking Stronger Bargaining Stance
description: As he met for a second day in New York yesterday with Louis V. Gerstner Jr., the I.B.M. chairman, Jim P. Manzi of Lotus Development had few bargaining chips.

title: Aetna Stock Climbs on Report of Sale Talks
description: The stock of the Aetna Life and Casualty Company rose yesterday after it was reported that the company was discussing the sale of part of its property and casualty business.

title: Japan Deserves A Tariff
description: Although European and Asian governments have complained about the Clinton Administration's regrettable but justified proposal to place tariffs of 100 percent on 13 Japanese-made cars, most agree that Japanese trade barriers threaten the world trading system.

title: Waging Trade War With Fax and Figures
description: Somewhere in this city there is a lobbyist whose firm has not been hired by one side or the other in America's trade confrontation with Japan. "There is one, I think, but no one knows his name," Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, said not long ago.

title: ENSERCH COMPLETES ACQUISITION OF PACIFIC GAS UNIT
description: The Enserch Corporation said yesterday that it had completed the acquisition of the Dalen Corporation in Dallas, a unit of the Pacific Gas and Electric Company, for $340 million in cash and the assumption or refinancing of $115 million of Dalen's bank debt. Enserch, a natural gas and oil exploration company based in Dallas, said yesterday that it had paid for the transaction with lines of credit and a bridge loan. The deal was announced in April.

title: For Children
description: Garden Design Workshop

title: Beethoven a Proto-Nazi? Is One Paranoid to Ask?
description: Paul (Jim Helsinger), the central character in Richard Brody's earnest but hopelessly muddled film "Liability Crisis," is a morose young advertising executive and aspiring film maker whose obsession with the Holocaust has gone way out of control. Paul has been compiling interviews with World War II survivors for a documentary film, and the project has propelled him to a state of paranoia.

title: After the Cigars, Clinton Still Faces Growing Criticism of Bosnia Policy
description: President Clinton and his national security adviser, Anthony Lake, celebrated the rescue of a downed American fighter pilot with cigars on the Truman balcony early this morning. But within hours, Mr. Clinton faced renewed Congressional demands for changes in the Administration's Bosnia policy.

title: Rockets Playing on the Road Again To Test the Magic for Resiliency
description: The Orlando Magic learned how quickly a game can slip away, especially against the Houston Rockets.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on May 31 about Rabbi Milton Grafman, a civic leader in Birmingham, Ala., omitted a survivor. She is Ida Weinstein Grafman, his wife of 64 years.

title: CNN Officials to Propose a Business News Cable Service
description: Executives of CNN today will ask the board of its parent company, Turner Broadcasting System, to approve a new cable service offering business news on weekdays.

title: Mantle Receives New Liver As Donor Is Found Quickly
description: Surgeons replaced Mickey Mantle's liver ravaged by cancer, hepatitis and decades of heavy drinking -- this morning in a bid to save his life. As Mr. Mantle's health had deteriorated, with organ failure spreading from his liver to his kidneys, a liver donor was suddenly found overnight.

title: British Union Of Big Cable Operators
description: TeleWest Communications, Britain's largest cable television operator, said today that it would acquire the fifth-largest cable company, SBC Cablecomms, in a stock deal valued at $1.1 billion.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about a guilty plea in the killing of four men at a post office in Montclair, N.J., misstated the given name of one victim. He was Scott Walensky, not Ernest. The caption also misidentified the site where the wives of three victims were photographed. They were at a news conference, not in a courtroom in Federal District Court in Camden.

title: Gen. J.C. Ongania, Ex-Argentine Dictator, 81
description: Gen. Juan Carlos Ongania, a cavalryman who was Argentina's repressive President from 1966 to 1970, died on Thursday at the Military Hospital in Buenos Aires. He was 81 and lived in a suburb of Buenos Aires.

title: AMERICAN RADIO SHARES CLIMB ON FIRST DAY OF SALES
description: The shares of the American Radio Systems Corporation rose strongly yesterday on the concern's first day as a public company. The stock of the Boston-based radio-station operator closed at $20.25 in Nasdaq trading of almost 5.6 million shares. The company sold five million shares at $16.50. American Cable Systems, the last company headed by American Radio's chairman, Steve Dodge, went public in 1986 at $14.50 a share. Two years later, Mr. Dodge sold the company to Boston-based Continental Cablevision Inc. for $46.50 a share.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Brother DONALD SULLIVAN is not a man who would overstay his welcome. He has been the president of St. Francis College in Brooklyn for 26 years, and when the board of trustees approached him to stay on for another five years, he said thanks, but no.

title: President of A.F.L.-C.I.O. Is Reportedly Set to Retire
description: Lane Kirkland, who has been president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. since 1979, has decided not to run for re-election, union officials said yesterday.

title: Thomas Cabot, 98, Capitalist And Philanthropist, Is Dead
description: Thomas D. Cabot, a hardy industrialist who spent 40 years building a great family fortune and 30 years hiking, skiing, canoeing, yachting and giving away money, died on Thursday at his home in Weston, Mass., the Boston suburb where he lived for 75 years. He was 98.

title: The Food Fight
description: "Is it opportunity to operate one pushcart your entire life?" asks Christopher Ferencsik, vice president of the Big Apple Food Vendors Association. "Where is that going to lead you?"

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about a guilty plea in the killing of four men at a post office in Montclair, N.J., misstated the given name of one victim. He was Scott Walensky, not Ernest. The caption also misidentified the site where the wives of three victims were photographed. They were at a news conference, not in a courtroom in Federal District Court in Camden.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Chic by H.I.S. Inc.(JNS,N) reports earnings for Qtr to May 6
Sports of The Times; Magic Needs Some Tough Knicks 'D'
description: ALL that was missing from these National Basketball Association finals earlier this week were league-licensed buttons that read: "Ban The Knicks." Who now will be the first to stand up to ask where have they gone?

title: Hunters Can Do More To Stop Gun Violence
description: To the Editor:

title: Tipasa Journal; Algerian Anti-Terror Force Can Instill Terror, Too
description: "Our mission is to make people feel secure," the commander of an armored Nissan patrol said. He was going nearly 100 miles an hour on a stretch of Mediterranean road toward this seaside resort as his men signaled cars to make way for a convoy of the so-called ninjas, the strike force used to combat Muslim militants.

title: Secretary General Asks to Increase Peacekeeping Forces
description: At the request of Britain, France and the Netherlands, Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali formally recommended today that the United Nations expand its military force in the Balkans by 12,500, to include the reinforcements of rapid-response brigades those countries are sending to Bosnia.

title: Save the Job Corps
description: The Federal Government finances a dizzying array of education and training programs. Chairman Nancy Kassebaum of the Senate Labor Committee will propose a bill next week to combine 70 or so training programs into a block grant, giving the money to the states to help low-skilled or unemployed workers. Dismantling may make sense for marginally effective programs, but it makes no sense for the Job Corps, a uniquely successful program for disadvantaged youths. The Kassebaum bill is expected to preserve the Job Corps, but risk its future by turning it over to the states to run.

title: Bridge
description: The International Team Trials, which began Thursday in Las Vegas, Nev., have a new, larger format. Instead of including only teams that have won one of the four national championships, they are open to all who can afford travel, rooms and entry fees. Two teams will qualify for the World Championships in Beijing in October.

title: INSIDE
description: Warning on Air Traffic

title: International Briefs; Nynex Unit Raises $610 Million in Britain
description: The Nynex Corporation said yesterday that an initial public offering of shares of its British subsidiary, Nynex Cablecomms Group, had raised about $610 million in proceeds. The New York-based Nynex sold a 33 percent stake in the subsidiary through the public offering. Nynex sold 305 million Nynex Cablecomms units for 137 pence a unit, or $21.81 for each American depository share. Each American depository share represents 10 units. The units are expected to be listed on the London Stock Exchange; the American depository shares closed at $21.75 on the Nasdaq market.

title: Mary Doyle, Actress, 63
description: Mary Doyle, an actress in theater, films and television, died on Thursday at her home in Manhattan. She was 63.

title: Giuliani Is Seeking New Cuts in Schools And Social Services
description: Reacting swiftly to the news that the state budget provides far less aid than New York City requested, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday proposed deep new cuts to the Board of Education, the city hospital system and local welfare programs, many of which benefit the poor.

title: Expect Suspensions, Even Dismissals, Bratton Warns
description: Police Commissioner William J. Bratton said yesterday that more officers had begun to identify colleagues who took part in a drunken rampage in Washington three weeks ago and that more suspensions, and even dismissals, were expected in the next few weeks.

title: Labor Complaint Filed Against Murdoch
description: The New York office of the National Labor Relations Board filed a complaint yesterday against Rupert Murdoch's publishing company, the News Corporation, asserting that it violated labor laws when it dismissed 287 unionized employees of The New York Post as a result of a strike in 1993.

title: Driver Is Aching But Status Is Unclear
description: The Devils may be heading into Game 4 of the Eastern Conference finals against the Flyers Saturday afternoon without a key defenseman.

title: JAPAN TELLS U.S. IT WILL NOT JOIN EMBARGO ON IRAN
description: In a sharp rebuff to the Clinton Administration, the Japanese Government has told Washington that Tokyo will refuse to join its embargo on trade with Iran, undercutting the American effort to isolate Teheran economically for its sponsorship of terrorism and its suspected pursuit of nuclear weapons.

title: Clinton Moves Closer to a Detailed Plan to Balance the Budget, Officials Say
description: President Clinton is inching closer to proposing his detailed way to balance the Federal budget in 10 years, Administration officials and Congressional Democrats said today. But his advisers remain sharply divided over whether it is too soon to begin such compromising with Republicans.

title: Houston Takes Total Control With a Crushing Victory
description: The Houston Rockets played like a team of destiny. The Orlando Magic looked like a team in trouble.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about a student's attempt to give a commencement speech at Martha's Vineyard Regional High School about her experience of rape referred incompletely to the charge to which a fellow student pleaded guilty in the case. The youth, Keith Devine, pleaded guilty to the rape of a child under the age of 16 -- a charge similar to statutory rape -- and to performing unnatural and lascivious acts. He did not simply plead guilty to rape.

title: Schneider Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to May 13
description: The company said the sales increase in the latest six months reflected its acquisition of a 50 percent stake in Prince Group, higher sales of the Fleetwood brand and increases in its fresh pork and poultry businesses.The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: ITT Selling The Rest of Subsidiary
description: Completing a process it announced last September, the ITT Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell the remaining assets of its ITT Financial Corporation subsidiary for about $5.5 billion.

title: SALE OF STYRENE PLASTICS BUSINESS IS CONSIDERED
description: The Monsanto Company said yesterday that it would consider selling its styrene plastics business over the next several months. The St. Louis-based maker of chemicals, food additives and pharmaceuticals said that "this business may be more valuable from a strategic point of view to another company." Styrene plastics -- a hard, molded material -- are used in a wide variety of consumer products, including toys, housewares, power tool housings and auto interior parts.

title: A Prince Charming?; Disney and the City Find Each Other
description: It is not, at first glance, a marriage made in heaven: the Walt Disney Company, the entertainment giant with the family-values image, and New York City, the hard-edged metropolis.

title: N.Y.P.D. White
description: I wish that anyone who angrily opposes affirmative action could have been in a patrol car with me in Harlem one weekend 30 years ago. The dispatcher reported a shooting at Sugar Ray's Bar, on Seventh Avenue near West 123d Street. It was 2 A.M. when my partner and I arrived. The bar was packed. In the dim light, two men lay on the floor, one dead. About 70 African-Americans stared in silence at us white cops.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball American League BOSTON RED SOX -- Activated Mark Whiten, outfielder, from the 15-day disabled list. Called up Joe Hudson, pitcher, from Trenton of the Eastern League. Designated Tuffy Rhodes, outfielder, for assignment. Sent Brian Looney, pitcher, to Pawtucket of the International League. KANSAS CITY ROYALS -- Signed Juan Labron, outfielder. MILWAUKEE BREWERS -- Activated Mike Fetters, pitcher. Placed Turner Ward, outfielder, on the 15-day disabled list. National League LOS ANGELES DODGERS -- Traded Rafael Bournigal, shortstop, to the Montreal Expos for John Foster, pitcher. Assigned Foster to their rookie camp in Vero Beach, Fla. NEW YORK METS -- Assigned Reid Cornelius, pitcher, to Norfolk of the International League. Purchased the contract of Jeff Barry, outfielder, from Binghamton of the Eastern League. ST. LOUIS CARDINALS -- Agreed to terms with Ken Hill, pitcher, on a one-year contract. Carolina Leauge WILMINTON BLUE ROCKS -- Loaned Kortney Paul, catcher, to Lethbridge of the Pioneer League. Northern League NL -- Named Brad Brooksbank director of media relations. Northeast League ALBANY-COLONIE DIAMOND DOGS -- Signed Chris Newcomb, pitcher, and Dan Gray, catcher. Prairie League MINNEAPOLIS LOONS -- Signed Brian Sutter, catcher-infielder. Released Eric Lovdahl, pitcher. Basketball United States Basketball League JERSEY TURNPIKES -- Activated Dan O'Sullivan, center, from the taxi squad. Placed Brent Dabbs, center, on the taxi squad. FLORIDA SHARKS -- Activated Stanley Jackson, guard, from the taxi squad. Placed Jerome Robinson, guard, on the taxi squad. MEMPHIS FIRE -- Signed Rob Renfroe, center. MIAMI TROPICS -- Released Eric Johnson, guard. Activated Orchiel Swaby, forward, from the taxi squad. Signed Malcolm Ruckaby, guard, and placed him on the taxi squad. Football National Football League CAROLINA PANTHERS -- Named Dan Ruiz assistant trainer. CINCINNATI BENGALS -- Signed Ryan Grigson, offensive tackle. WASHINGTON REDSKINS -- Signed Zack Abraham, wide receiver, and Ron Lewis, offensive guard. Released Craig Dubose, linebacker; Barry Dillard, defensive back; Brad Fichtel, center; and Doug Thomas, wide receiver. Canadian Football League BRITISH COLUMBIA LIONS -- Signed Rob Prodanovic, defensive end. SHREVEPORT PIRATES -- Released Gill Carillo, running back. Signed Freeman Baysinger, wide receiver. Arena Football League ALBANY FIREBIRDS -- Activated Mike Green and David McLeod, wide receivers-defensive backs, from the exempt list. Waived Nuygen Pendleton, wide receiver-defensive back, and Dwayne Ware, defensive specialist. ARIZONA RATTLERS -- Activated Craig Barr, fullback-linebacker, and Cedric Tillman, wide receiver-defensive back, from the exempt list. Placed Brad Clark and Milton Vaughn, wide receivers-defensive backs, on injured reserve. CHARLOTTE RAGE -- Activated Bill Stewart, fullback-linebacker, from the refuse-to-report list. MIAMI HOOTERS -- Activated Alvin Ashley, wide receiver-defensive back, from the refuse-to-report list. Placed Matt Vogler, quarterback, on injured reserve and Quentin Knight, lineman, on the refuse-to-report list. Signed Tony Missick, wide receiver-defensive back, and Charles Puleri, quarterback. Waived Darian Bryant and Bryan Moore, wide receivers-defensive backs.

title: U.S. WAS UNAWARE ON SERB MISSILES, OFFICIALS ASSERT
description: As the Clinton Administration celebrated the flawless rescue of an American pilot in Bosnia, NATO and Administration officials acknowledged today that intelligence and planning failures contributed to the downing of the F-16 fighter in the first place.

title: Spirits Good, Reeve Shows More Signs Of Movement
description: The wife of Christopher Reeve said today that the actor had begun therapy for his paralysis and had been watching hockey on television.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about House passage of a foreign aid bill misstated a provision on Tibet. The bill would create the position of special envoy to Tibet, but it would not require the President to recognize Tibet as a sovereign nation.

title: Religion Journal; Taking On Hollywood, Long Before Dole
description: When it comes to critiquing Hollywood, a politician like Bob Dole, the Senate majority leader, may reap headlines, as Mr. Dole did in abundance last week when he attacked the movie and recording industries for creating "nightmares of depravity."

title: THERMO ELECTRON PLANS TO BUY MEDICAL TECHNOLOGIES
description: The Thermo Electron Corporation said yesterday that it planned to acquire Bird Medical Technologies Inc. in a stock transaction valued at about $57.6 million. The agreement values Bird Medical at $8 a share, according to Thermo Electron, a maker of environmental-monitoring instruments and an array of other equipment based in Waltham, Mass. Bird Medical's stock gained 62.5 cents yesterday, or 9 percent, to close at $7.25 in Nasdaq trading. Bird, based in Palm Springs, Calif., a manufacturer of respiratory care equipment and accessories and infection control products, had 1994 sales of $53.8 million.

title: Robert H. Ganz, 65; Packaging Executive
description: Robert H. Ganz, an inventor and head of a New Jersey company whose specialized packaging machinery is sold worldwide, died on Tuesday at Hackensack Medical Center. He was 65 and lived in Saddle River, N.J.

title: How Long-Life Milk Tastes: A Bit Less Sweet, Creamy
description: Various types of Parmalat's long-lasting milk, which is superheated and packaged in aseptic cartons, were tasted for Business Day by Florence Fabricant, who contributes food articles to The Living Section.

title: Vera A. Ries, 86, Collector of Books
description: Vera Aberle Ries, whose living room was lined from floor to ceiling with one of the country's richest private collections of early children's books, died at her home in Forest Hills, Queens, on Monday. She was 86.

title: Bankruptcy Judge Blocks Move on Rockefeller Center
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge yesterday blocked an attempt by Rockefeller Center Properties Inc., which holds a $1.3 billion mortgage on Rockefeller Center, to wrest control of the trophy property from its owners.

title: Once Again, Sex Abuse By Employee At a School
description: A school security guard has been charged with the statutory rape of a 15-year-old sophomore who is now pregnant, and officials acknowledged yesterday that he continued to patrol the halls of Canarsie High School for more than three weeks after school officials first learned of the allegations.

title: U.S. Bonds Take Plunge On a Rumor
description: Prices of Treasury securities, already beaten back by the fading prospects that the Fed would ease credit, were battered again yesterday, as traders speculated that the Japanese might curtail future purchases of United States Government securities.

title: U.S.O.C. Likely to Pick Former N.C.A.A. Leader
description: The United States Olympic Committee's worst-kept secret is that Dick Schultz is expected to be named executive director, in perhaps as soon as two weeks.

title: Eisenhower Fought For Every '52 Delegate
description: To the Editor:

title: CNN Is Backed On New Service
description: The board of Turner Broadcasting approved a request yesterday by CNN to initiate a new financial news service in January to be called CNNFN.

title: Balkan Update
description: Capt. Scott O'Grady returned to AVIANO AIR BASE in ITALY yesterday, thanking God and the United States Marines for his rescue Thursday from Serb-held territory Bosnia.

title: Employees Watch Stock Surge As Management Forbids Sales
description: For employees of Lotus Development, the company's fall from Wall Street grace has been a painful one. Many are also shareholders, through various company plans, and until I.B.M. offered $60 a share, Lotus stock was selling for less than it was fetching five years ago. And it is still below its peak of more than $86, reached in March 1994.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GENICOM CORP., Chantilly, Va., a computer network parts, printer and related services company, said it had ended talks about acquiring a desktop printer business from an undisclosed company. MITY-LITE INC., Orem, Utah, a maker of multipurpose furniture, agreed to buy Fixtures Manufacturing Corp., Kansas City, Mo., another furniture maker, for $18 million in cash and stock. SMITHFIELD COS., Portsmouth, Va., a food processing concern, will sell its Bunker Hill Foods division to closely held Castleberry/Snow's Brands Inc. Augusta, Ga., for $12.9 million. WESTWOOD ONE INC., Culver City, Calif., a radio programing distributor, said it planned to buy as much as $15 million of its common stock outstanding in the open market and through negotiated transactions.

title: New York Homeowners Bear a Double Burden
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Wednesday about John Presper Eckert, co-inventor of what many historians consider the first electronic digital computer, misstated the affiliation of Dr. John V. Atanasoff, another computing pioneer. It was Iowa State University, not the University of Iowa.

title: Past Upstages Present at Venice Biennale
description: The centenary edition of the Venice Biennale opens to the public on Saturday, but the verdict is already in from many of the museum directors, curators, gallery owners, collectors and art critics who crowded the exhibition's three preview days: the past seems to be faring better than the present.

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column on the Media Business page yesterday, about the leading broadcast television networks' booking of $5.6 billion in advance sales of commercial time for the 1995-96 season, misstated the number of commercials the amount would have bought during Super Bowl XXIX. It is 5,600 30-second commercials, not 5.6 million; the 5,600 would have run for 1.94 days, not 1,944.

title: Ithaca's Honors Program Benefits All Students
description: To the Editor:

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: A Singer and Accompanist Make a Point of Equality Music of the Americas Americas Society

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about a student's attempt to give a commencement speech at Martha's Vineyard Regional High School about her experience of rape referred incompletely to the charge to which a fellow student pleaded guilty in the case. The youth, Keith Devine, pleaded guilty to the rape of a child under the age of 16 -- a charge similar to statutory rape -- and to performing unnatural and lascivious acts. He did not simply plead guilty to rape.

title: F.A.A. Faults An L.I. Center For Air Traffic
description: The system that is supposed to keep airplanes from colliding over the New York City area is beset by problems, from aging computers to a serious shortage of trained technicians, that have made it far too vulnerable to breakdowns, officials at the Federal Aviation Administration said yesterday.

title: Yankees Absorb Another Pounding
description: It was the Seattle Mariners' turn to beat up the Yankees last night. They pounded three home runs en route to an 11-1 victory that would have been embarrassing if it wasn't becoming routine.

title: Bratton Expects More Dismissals
description: Police Commissioner William J. Bratton said yesterday that more officers have begun to identify colleagues who took part in a drunken rampage in Washington three weeks ago and that additional suspensions, and even dismissals, are expected in the next few weeks.

title: Surgery for Mantle
description: One day after he underwent a liver transplant, Mickey Mantle was brought back to an operating room, where doctors stanched some internal bleeding. The doctors said his liver was working well, and that he was alert enough to watch news about his condition on television.

title: Private Review of Homeless Program Is Planned
description: The Grand Central Partnership, faced with government inquiries into a program it operates for homeless people, said yesterday that it had retained a well-known advocate for homeless services to review and recommend changes in its program.

title: Not First Gene Patent
description: To the Editor:

title: Russia and Ukraine Settle Dispute Over Black Sea Fleet
description: The leaders of Russia and Ukraine signed an agreement today that should conclude their bitter dispute over the Black Sea Fleet, improving relations between the two most important countries of the former Soviet Union.

title: Corrections
description: Stock options tables in Business Day yesterday reflected Wednesday's trading rather than Thursday's in some copies. (The correct version is recognizable by the "Most Active Options" listing, which shows the price of the Lotus Development Corporation as 63 1/2.) Readers wishing corrected copies of the tables may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or telephone (212) 556-1992.

title: World News Briefs; Conservatives Defeat Socialists in Ontario
description: The Progressive Conservative Party, promising tax and spending cuts and radical changes in social policy, have swept out the socialist New Democrats to take control of the provincial government in Ontario.

title: From a Wreck to a Fish Haven
description: "Big Mama," an 85-foot old tugboat, was blown up and sunk off the coast in 95 feet of water yesterday in hopes that it will become a feeding station for fish. Like 80 other vessels that have been deliberately sunk in New Jersey waters since 1983, the wreck is supposed to attract sea bass, cod, bluefish, lobster, mussels and crabs. But not everyone is convinced that this is a good idea. "The only question is whether these artificial reefs are increasing (ocean) productivity or are simply making it easier to catch fish," said Dery Bennett, director of the American Littoral Society, a environmental organization.

title: Clay Cruisers Reach Final: It's Muster Against Chang
description: Michael Chang did it by putting mind over the possibly daunting matter of trying to dethrone the French Open's two-time defending champion.

title: Market Responds to Northeast Pollution
description: To the Editor:

title: Observer; All in What Family?
description: Which family are we talking about in this debate about family values? Is it the Gambino family? Of course not. Could it be the House of Atreus? Don't be absurd.
