description: To the Editor:

title: A Reunion of Sorts Involving a 'Miracle'
description: Late in the regular season, when Slava Fetisov arrived in Detroit after a trade from the Devils, he approached Mike Ramsey in the Red Wings' dressing room.

title: Denver Ensemble Reaches Back For a Look at Black Themes
description: The American Dance Festival is always up to date. Every year it brings to the campus of Duke University here an array of premieres that attest to the diversity of modern dance. Yet even as it shows where modern dance is and hints at where it may be going, it is also concerned with where it has been.

title: Sci-Fi Channel Allows 'Chats' While a Show Is in Progress
description: We know that science-fiction pioneers -- at least since "Star Trek" -- have a mission to boldly go where none have gone before.

title: In Performance; DANCE
description: The Master's Settings Of Russian Favorites New York City Ballet New York State Theater

title: Pesticides in Food Poised for Comeback
description: To the Editor:

title: Barclays May Soon Purchase Wells Fargo Nikko
description: Barclays Bank P.L.C. is expected to announce plans to buy Wells Fargo Nikko Investment Advisers for about $800 million as early as tomorrow, people familiar with the situation said today.

title: A Toast to the 'Lemon Law'
description: The people at the Division of Consumer Affairs were in a celebratory mood last week. Instead of champagne, they said they wanted . . . lemonade. The humor was strained, but the agency's director, Mark B. Herr, and Attorney General Deborah T. Poritz did not care. They announced that the amount collected for car buyers under the six-year-old "Lemon Law" program had topped $10 million. The program provides for hearings that can lead to reimbursement for consumers who buy faulty automobiles and motorcycles.

title: Time in the Classroom
description: Time magazine will introduce an advertising-free classroom edition in September, aimed at children in the fourth through sixth grades. Time for Kids will be an eight-page issue reflecting up-to-date issues. The magazine will be printed in full color on magazine-quality paper, according to Time Warner Inc., the magazine's parent company. Initial circulation will be 500,000.

title: In Performance; ROCK
description: A Straightforward Sneer With a Pummeling Beat Mudhoney Irving Plaza

title: Burning of Flag Is an Act of Contempt
description: To the Editor:

title: Israel and P.L.O. to Miss Target Date for New Accord
description: With time running out, Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin told his Cabinet today that Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization would miss a July 1 target date for a full agreement on expansion of Palestinian self-rule in the West Bank.

title: Rising Storm on Hong Kong's Vanishing Harbor
description: When she was small, Romy Chiu remembers, the waters of Hong Kong harbor lapped against the sea wall at the end of Man Yuen Street, a claustrophic alley of noodle stalls, engine shops and her family's Vietnamese restaurant.

title: Accounts
description: * Miller Brewing International, Beijing, part of the Miller Brewing Co. unit of the Philip Morris Cos., to Dentsu, Young & Rubicam Hong Kong, a joint venture of Dentsu Inc. and Young & Rubicam Inc., as the first agency to handle its Miller beer brand in China. The billings were not disclosed. Y.& R. is the agency of record for the international business of Miller Brewing Co. Also, Dentsu, Y.& R. was named as the first agency to handle advertising for Five Star, a brewery in Beijing, with which Miller has a licensing agreement. The billings were not disclosed.

title: Heineken Reviewing Warwick Baker
description: Heineken USA in White Plains, a unit of Heineken N.V., has, as expected, placed in review the account of its flagship Heineken beer brand, a longtime account of Warwick Baker & Fiore in New York. Though the Heineken billings were not disclosed, Adweek estimated them at $20 million to $25 million.

title: Harsh Memories of Detention Center
description: Even after 12 years as an immigration lawyer in New Jersey, Rosa Soy was stunned the first time she met a young Somalian refugee in a glass interview room at the Esmor detention center in Elizabeth, N.J.

title: Senate's Passage Of Bill Relieves Cable Industry
description: Cable television executives kept a vigil all last week as the Senate debated a sweeping overhaul of the nation's telecommunications laws. Of the half-dozen major industries affected by the legislation, their industry clearly had the most to lose.

title: After Message Of Hate, One of Hope
description: It was referred to only as "the incident," but the racial slur discovered in a school yearbook last week found its way into Greenwich churches today, condemned by nearly a dozen ministers who urged their congregants to begin a healing process.

title: Rutgers Wants Stringer
description: Rutgers has reached general agreement for its women's basketball head coaching position with C. VIVIAN STRINGER, head coach at the University of Iowa for the past 12 seasons, according The Home News of East Brunswick. Details, the paper said, are to be worked out.

title: In Darcey Bussell's 'Swan Lake,' Time Is Savored
description: George Balanchine once said that the 1895 four-act version of "Swan Lake" was essentially a suite of dances to Tchaikovsky's music. The narrative may have been unimportant to him, but it helps to know what the ballet's plot is about, as Darcey Bussell proved so persuasively in Balanchine's one-act staging on Saturday afternoon.

title: Taking In the Sites; Mapping Out Specific Destinations to Faraway Places
description: Armchair travelers have long used the Internet to roam the planet vicariously, but genuine road warriors can find information within minutes that once took days to amass.

title: MOSCOW ACCEPTS CHECHNYA TALKS
description: After the failure of two attempts to storm the hospital where Chechen commandos still held as many as 1,000 hostages, Russia's Prime Minister, Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, ordered a cease-fire throughout Chechnya today during negotiations by telephone with the commando leader and sent a high-level team to the Chechen capital for peace talks with rebel leaders.

title: Resist the Urge to Splurge
description: If you have a steady job, it's not difficult to calculate your standard yearly income and budget accordingly. If you're prudent, you save one-time bonuses for future hard times.

title: George Stafford Is Dead at 80; Headed Commerce Commission
description: George M. Stafford, a Kansas Republican who was chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission from 1970 to 1977, died on Friday at Sibley Memorial Hospital in Washington. He was 80 and lived in Bethesda, Md.

title: Newark Case Is Keeping Mexico Rapt
description: It has not quite rivaled the O. J. Simpson trial for courtroom drama, but after only a few days the extradition case in New Jersey of a former Mexican prosecutor has created a media frenzy of its own on Mexico's side of the border.

description: Fueling Improvisation By Doing a Little Homework James Carter, saxophonist Village Vanguard

title: In Performance; DANCE
description: A Balanchine Challenge With 3 Dancers in New Roles New York City Ballet New York State Theater

title: Life Rejects Art; Students Find No Shock of Recognition In a Novel Set in Their Own Backyard
description: Students at the Keene Central School, one of the state's smallest, don't come face to face with novelists very often, or with novels that purport to be about them. Maybe that's why they told Russell Banks that the mirror he held up to them had a warp in it. Chappie Dorset, the protagonist of Mr. Banks's new novel, "Rule of the Bone," they said, didn't live here.

title: Captives Free, U.N. Gives Up Effort to Shield Sarajevo
description: In a tradeoff that secured the release of the last 26 peacekeepers held hostage by the Bosnian Serbs, the United Nations today abandoned its attempt to protect Sarajevo from bombardment by heavy artillery.

title: Pearl Jam Stands Firm on Tickets
description: Pearl Jam has reaffirmed that it will not use Ticketmaster to distribute tickets for its current tour. As a result, it is not performing on the usual rock-tour circuit, and no shows have yet been scheduled for the eastern United States.

title: Illegal Aliens Overrun a Jail In New Jersey
description: Frustration flared into violence early yesterday at an immigrant detention center in Elizabeth, N.J., that has been buffeted by charges of mistreating the illegal aliens held there. A ragtag band of detainees took over the building, demolished much of the interior and barricaded themselves inside for five hours before the center was stormed by law enforcement officers.

title: Prejudice Exists Even at Greenwich High School; Our Justified Anger
description: To the Editor:

description: HISTORY OF ILLS AT IMMIGRATION JAILS

title: Shut the Detention Center, Local Authorities Urge
description: The Union County Prosecutor's office and the Elizabeth Police Department have called for the closing of the Esmor immigration detention center here, saying the site is so poorly managed by a company hired by the Federal Government that it has become a threat to public safety.

title: Ashe Joining Dixie Heroes
description: After checking to be sure no cannons would be pointed at the statue, Richmond officials voted today to memorialize the tennis champion Arthur Ashe on an avenue dominated by monuments to Confederate heroes.

title: Charles Elmer Martin, or CEM, New Yorker Artist, Dies at 85
description: Charles Elmer Martin, an artist whose work was seen in galleries and museums, in national magazines and in books, died on Sunday at the Seaside nursing home in Portland, Me. He was 85 and lived in Queens until several years ago when he moved to Portland.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League YANKEES -- Agreed to terms with Darryl Strawberry, outfielder, on a one-year contract.

title: Artists With AIDS Race Time To Preserve Work for All Time
description: Working frantically in an East Village studio overflowing with his paintings, sketches and papers, Copy Berg is racing the clock, desperate to finish cataloguing his work before AIDS beats him to the deadline.

title: N.B.A. Players Send Message Of Displeasure To Union
description: Negotiators for National Basketball Association owners and players continued trying to complete a new labor agreement yesterday, but players and agents made their job potentially more difficult by escalating their dispute with the union's leader.

title: Go Home? Torrence Gets Home in First
description: As she neared the finish line in the first round of the 100 meters, Gwen Torrence seemed to flash a grin. No, she explained later, the smile was a grimace. What appeared to be a celebration was instead the agony of victory.

title: High School Is Struggling With 2 Cases Of Prejudice
description: One anti-Semitic note was tucked under a teacher's office door; another was left on a teacher's desk.

title: Mission Possible; Reviving a Dying Public School
description: For six long years, Public School 165 in Manhattan dwelled in the wasteland of New York City's lowest performing schools. Miserable test scores were only a sliver of the problems that it faced.

title: Those Troubled Marriages Out of Genesis
description: A concept opera is usually an invitation to trendy gimmickry. In the case of "Hotel Eden," by the composer Henry Mollicone and the librettist Judith Fein, the concept, though not highly original, is refreshingly unpretentious.

title: Vicorp Restaurants Inc.(VRES,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to May 14
description: Vicorp Restaurants said its latest second quarter was hurt by turnaround efforts at its Bakers Square business, including price reductions which lowered the average guest check by about 10 percent, and continued investment in food and labor.

title: Science Times E-Mail
description: Science Times has an electronic mail address for comments from readers about published articles and suggested areas of coverage:

title: Lemieux Looking to Play
description: MARIO LEMIEUX will announce today that he plans to return to the Pittsburgh Penguins next season. Lemieux, a four-time National Hockey League scoring leader, sat out the 1994-95 season to rest after five years of persistent back problems, a bout with Hodgkin's disease and anemia. He laced up his skates only once all season, for a charity game in March.

title: Los Angeles Official Seeks To Close a Major Hospital
description: Facing a budget deficit of more than $1 billion, the chief administrative officer of Los Angeles County touched off a storm today by proposing broad cuts that include closing of one of the largest hospitals in the nation, the Los Angeles County-University of California Medical Center.

title: Univar Corp.(UVX,N) reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary loss of $ 2.1 million, or 10 cents a share, for re-engineering operations.

title: Growls From Barracks Echo in Peru and Chile
description: There were no coups or crackdowns in the streets, but the military forces of Peru and Chile demonstrated last week how reluctant they are to give up their influence in two of Latin America's struggling democracies.

title: Gilberto Gil's Melange Of Styles and Messages
description: For decades in countries outside Europe and North America, the most socially and politically galvanizing musicians to emerge have been those with one ear tuned to influences beyond their borders and another sensitive to the musical needs of their home region. On Sunday afternoon, during the opening weekend of the Central Park Summerstage series, Gilberto Gil and Chico Science, two Brazilian musicians of different generations and from different areas, combined a gift for marrying musical styles with a talent for writing smart, socially conscious songs. The result was a satisfying and rewarding double bill.

title: Review/Fashion; Resort Wear With a Serious Air
description: Resort is a funny season on Seventh Avenue. It used to mean beach clothes and bare little dresses to go on a Caribbean cruise or spend the winter in Florida. But some designers have come to realize that few of their customers enjoy such a privileged way of life. A week or two in the sun doesn't call for more than a few T-shirts and some white pants.

title: TransTexas Gas Corp.(TTXG,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: b-Net income, which included nonrecurring litigation accural of $ 3 million in the quarter and $ 12 million in the 9 months.(Loss)The company said it was able to mitigate the 34 percent drop in third quarter natural gas prices with a 9 percent increase in average daily natural gas production.

title: Sports of The Times; N.B.A. Stars Get Heads Out of the Clouds
description: THE first victory for professional basketball players in the arena of collective bargaining came in 1964, when Larry Fleisher organized a boycott of the National Basketball Association All-Star Game and the principals fell right into line.

title: Chess
description: Gary Kasparov of Russia took no chances in winning the Professional Chess Association's Super Classic Tournament in Novgorod, Russia, in early June. He pointedly avoided being lured into the type of unclear attack that had failed him three weeks before in an event in Amsterdam.

title: House of Fabrics Inc(HF,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: b-Included reorganization costs of $ 3,522,000.House of Fabrics said the decrease in sales was primarily due to the closing of more than 250 stores since April 30, 1994.(Loss)

title: Observer; Bliss for the Barbecued
description: Unnoticed by the public and mostly unreported by a press and television besotted with the sound-bite fun of the budget story, a radical rewrite of telecommunications law is now under way in Congress. The immediate result, reports The New York Times, is likely to be "chaos." But then -- ah! -- benefits galore!

title: No Charges Against Officer Who Killed Student in Scuffle at Mall
description: A Suffolk County grand jury has refused to indict a 31-year old police officer who fatally shot a 21-year-old student at the Smith Haven Mall in Lake Grove in December.

title: Forstmann & Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: b-Net income.(Loss)

title: Giuliani Steps Up Criticism of School Board
description: Even as Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is asking the Board of Education to give him a role in selecting the next schools chancellor, he stepped up his criticism of the board members yesterday, saying that they had failed to fight for change in the schools.

title: Saudi Deal for Boeing and Douglas
description: Ending 18 months of uncertainty, Saudi Arabia said yesterday that it would proceed with the purchase of 61 aircraft from the Boeing Company and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation for more than $6 billion.

title: Inmates Set Back
description: The Supreme Court made it substantially more difficult for prisoners to bring constitutional lawsuits challenging prison management.

title: TV Offers a Melodrama in Real Time
description: Russian television viewers have a pretty high threshold for amazement. That's understandable in a country that has watched a coup attempt, the death of an empire, an assault by the President on Parliament and a brutal war.

title: Pencils, Yes; Camera, No
description: Though for years I favored cameras in courtrooms, I have concluded that the issue needs a lot more thought than people in my profession were willing to give it when the issue first arose.

title: Micron Electronics Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jun 1
Yanks Give More Proof They Need A Pitcher
description: If Darryl Strawberry were the savior the Yankees desperately desire, he would be able to pitch competently every five days and do a capable imitation of Jimmy Key. George Steinbrenner made noise today by signing Strawberry to hit, but ineffective pitching tonight continued to make the Yankees mediocre. Cal Ripken Jr. also helped doom them.

title: Future of Newsday Edition In New York Is Weighed

description: The Supreme Court today repudiated the approach of its recent prisoners-rights cases and made it substantially more difficult for prisoners to bring constitutional lawsuits challenging prison management.

description: The Clinton Administration broadened its confrontation with Japan today, threatening to bar Japanese airlines from some of their most profitable cargo routes to the United States in retaliation for Tokyo's refusal to allow Federal Express to expand its operations there.

LESLIE FAY WILL NOT SELL ITS CORE BUSINESSES
description: The Leslie Fay Companies has abandoned efforts to find a buyer for its core businesses, saying it plans to emerge from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection as an independent entity. The apparel company, which is based in New York, declined to comment on why it ended the sale efforts. In March, the company asked its financial adviser to explore the sale of its Leslie Fay Dress, Sportswear, Albert Nipon, Outlander and Castelberry apparel manufacturing and marketing businesses and its Leslie Fay group of 54 retail stores. Leslie Fay said it would file a bankruptcy reorganization plan by the end of July and would try to emerge from bankruptcy by the end of the year. Current shareholders' equity will probably become worthless in the reorganization, the company said.

title: Celtics Gamble on Carr
description: M. L. CARR has never coached before. His boss does not know if he can. Yet the Boston Celtics' director of basketball operations took the coaching job yesterday after a long search. The enthusiastic Carr is devoted to changing the somber mood surrounding the once-proud franchise. He is committed to installing a running game and will rely on his assistants to help him do it.

description: IF bad news can make for good business at some companies, the financial crisis in Orange County, Calif., is a red-letter event for MBIA Inc., the nation's largest municipal bond insurer. MBIA makes money by selling insurance protection for municipal bonds that could go bad, and its stock has been climbing since Orange County's problems began.

title: Price Climb Is Resumed By Treasury Securities
description: Prices of Treasury securities resumed their climb to higher levels yesterday, as market optimism of a Fed easing increased because of recent remarks by Fed officials.

title: Executive Changes
description: CITIZENS FINANCIAL CORP., Louisville, Ky., named its chairman, Darrell R. Wells, to the additional postions of chief executive and president. SGI INTERNATIONAL INC., La Jolla, Calif., a developer of energy technologies, named Joseph Savoca president, co-chairman and chief executive. TELE-TV, New York, a joint venture of Bell Atlantic Corp., Nynex Corp. and the Pacific Telesis Group, named Edward Grebow president. UNITED DOMINION INDUSTRIES, Charlotte, N.C., an engineering services company, named Charles D. Houseman president and chief operating officer. U S WEST INC., Englewood, Colo., named Sol Trujillo president and chief executive of its communications unit and Gary Ames president and chief executive of its international unit. WOOLWORTH CORP., New York, appointed Paul T. Davies president and chief executive of its F. W. Woolworth Co. subsidiary, succeeding Edgar J. Swain, who retired on May 1.

title: R.G. Bernreuter, 93, Psychology Teacher
description: Robert G. Bernreuter, a psychologist and university administrator who designed an early personality test and helped create one of the first laws in the nation to require psychological testing in public schools, died on Thursday at Centre Community Hospital in State College, Pa. He was 93 and lived in State College.

description: b-Included extraordinary income of $ 1,332,000, or 25 cents a share, related to debt refinancing, in the quarter and nine months. Both periods also included a write-off of $ 1.4 million for an investment in Hazleton Environmental.

description: * Miller Brewing Co., Milwaukee, a unit of the Philip Morris Cos., to the Chicago office of Young & Rubicam Inc., to introduce Big Sky and Big Sky Light beer in Wisconsin. The brand is priced below premium brands like Miller Lite. Billings were not disclosed. * American Institute of Architects, Washington, to Richardson, Myers & Donofrio, Baltimore, to handle its account, previously at the Martin Agency, Richmond, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos. The billings were estimated at more than $1 million.

title: 50 Years of Catholic Talk: New Faces and New Ideas
description: Outside Ballroom C and D at the Grand Hyatt Hotel in Manhattan, where the Catholic Theological Society of America was holding its 50th annual meeting earlier this month, hung a photograph of the group's first gathering, in late June 1946 at the same hotel, then called the Commodore. All in the photo were men, all were priests, and all were dressed in black clerical garb.

title: A Spirited Woman Without Sight
description: Trying to shatter stereotypes with a portrait of a blind woman who refuses to be, in her words, "a goody-two-shoes," "Out of Sight" only ends up showing how the blind can be as tacky as anyone else. Produced and directed by David R. Sutherland, whose previous credits include incisive portraits of the artists Jack Levine and Paul Cadmus, the documentary is to be presented tonight on "P.O.V," the gutsy forum for independent nonfiction films.

title: New York, New York, It's Strawberry's Town
description: Darryl Strawberry wearing Yankee pinstripes might have seemed unthinkable, but at least one native of the Bronx thinks it won't be a strange sight.

title: ETHAN ALLEN TO EXTEND SUMMER IDLING OF PLANTS
description: Ethan Allen Interiors Inc. said yesterday that it planned to idle some furniture manufacturing plants for longer periods than usual this summer because of reduced demand. The company, based in Danbury, Conn., said it typically closes certain plants during the summer. But unusually weak demand this year is prompting the company to extend the closing for an extra week at about six plants that make wood furniture. The company also predicted that results for the fourth quarter, which ends June 30, might be significantly below those of the comparable period last year, when it had profits of 43 cents a share on sales of $116.4 million. Ethan Allen's stock slid $3.625 a share, or 17 percent, to $17.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: HIGH COURT LETS PARADE IN BOSTON BAR HOMOSEXUALS
description: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that the private sponsors of Boston's St. Patrick's Day parade had a constitutional right to exclude marchers whose message they reject, including those who seek to identify themselves as gay, lesbian, and bisexual Irish-Americans.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Federal Home Loan Bank is selling $75 million of debentures due in 1998 through First Tennessee Bank. The debentures, which are callable in one year, have an interest rate of 6.34 percent and are priced at par. * Federal Home Loan Bank is selling $50 million of notes due in 1998 through Smith Barney Inc. The notes, which are callable in six months, have an interest rate of 6.51 percent and are priced at par.

title: A Way Out of Chechnya
description: Russians and Chechens keep finding new ways to kill and torment each other. Their violent confrontation over the weekend in the southern Russian city of Budyonnovsk, where Chechen fighters held 2,000 residents hostage, may have left both sides ready to talk peace. But like the Chechen war itself, the battle was a senseless conflict in which civilians paid dearly for the military and political miscalculations of Russian and Chechen leaders. If any further evidence was needed why the war should be ended promptly, the vicious fighting in Budyonnovsk surely supplied it.

title: High Court to Hear Holder-Suit Issue
description: The Supreme Court has agreed to decide how much authority state courts have to approve negotiated settlements that let companies avoid further class-action claims.

title: In Lightness and Other States, the Glare of Graham's Legacy
description: David Wood was one of Martha Graham's most memorable solo dancers. And it was no surprise to see the high quality of performing by his Bay Area Repertory Dance/East, a group of former students, on Saturday night at Kaye Playhouse.

title: Where Tarnished Pit Bulls Tidy Up Their Image
description: It is shaping up to be another pit bull summer. The dogs are arriving at the Elmsford Animal Shelter at a steady pace, about one a day. As the dogfighting season reaches full swing, more and more will wind up here, battered, broken, all the worse for wear.

title: BellSouth Unit Reviewing Account
description: The BellSouth Telecommunications unit of the BellSouth Corporation, a longtime client of Tucker Wayne/Luckie & Company in Atlanta, said yesterday that it had placed its account in review. Though the billings were not disclosed, Adweek estimated them at $45 million to $50 million.

title: Manhattan Project Set to Music
description: The woman in "The Woman at Otowi Crossing" -- Stephen Paulus's new piece for the Opera Theater of Saint Louis -- serves as a fulcrum. On it the newly invented atomic bomb and the mystical powers of New Mexico's Pueblo people teeter back and forth. At Helen Chalmers's tearoom in the desert, Manhattan Project scientists dine and agonize. Around them, the magic of the countryside is in operation.

title: Judge Orders State to Provide Special Help to Deaf Prisoners
description: Ruling that New York State had violated the constitutional rights of deaf prison inmates, a Federal judge in Manhattan ordered the state yesterday to provide deaf prisoners with sign-language interpreters, typewriterlike devices for communicating by telephone, closed-caption televisions and other services.

title: Micron Technology Inc.(MU,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Jun 1

description: The Horizon Healthcare Corporation said yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings would be reduced by $16.9 million for expenses related to the sale of eight health care centers -- four in Massachusetts, three in Michigan and one in Ohio. Horizon estimates earnings per share for the quarter ended May 31 will be 77 cents, including the 63 cent charge, compared with 25 cents a share for the corresponding quarter last year.

title: In the Field With the Price Indexers
description: Her thick blue binder in hand, Diane Balaguer strides purposefully through the department store in the Concord Mall north of town. She checks the price of a women's pullover (short sleeve, solid color, no design) eyes a Hastings & Smith polo shirt, notes the seasonal absence of men's turtlenecks and then confronts the day's first challenge to statistical perfection.

title: Lemieux First in Goals and Complaints
description: Claude Lemieux irritates his coaches and teammates the same way he does opponents, but nobody around the Devils minds his attitude and temperament as long as the feisty right wing keeps producing in the Stanley Cup playoffs.

title: A Wild Start for Cacao
description: IN 1566, Bishop Diego de Landa, who chronicled a Spanish exploration, gazed over the Yucatan Peninsula and saw what he thought were cacao trees growing in sacred groves of the Maya.

title: Harry Loomer, 86, Psychiatrist, Dies
description: Dr. Harry B. Loomer, a psychiatrist whose pioneering research into drug treatment for depression was recognized after court litigation, died on Thursday at Columbia Memorial Hospital in Hudson, N.Y. He was 86 and lived in Taghkanic, N.Y.

title: SPRINT TO UNVEIL COAST-TO-COAST FIBER-OPTIC LINE
description: The Sprint Corporation., the nation's No. 3 long-distance carrier, said yesterday it would unveil by June 30 the first coast-to-coast fiber-optic line that guarantees voice, data, image and video service without interruption. The line, known as a synchronous optical network, will transmit communications at high speeds. If the cable is cut, Sprint said, its system will reroute signals within 60 milliseconds.

title: Excerpts From Court Opinion Barring Homosexuals From Boston Parade
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's opinion today that the privately sponsored St. Patrick's Day parade in Boston has a constitutional right to exclude marchers who seek to identify themselves as gay. Justice David H. Souter wrote the opinion in Hurley v. Irish-American Gay, Lesbian and Bisexual Group of Boston, which was unanimous. There were no separate opinions. BY JUSTICE SOUTER, For the Court

title: International Briefs; British Steel Profit Soars 7 Times in Year
description: British Steel P.L.C. said yesterday that its pretax profit soared more than sevenfold in the year that ended on March 31, with increased demand leading to higher prices and paving the way for even higher profit in the year ahead.

title: Cuba Tells U.S. It Will Not Extradite Fugitive Financier
description: The Cuban Government told American diplomats today that it does not plan to extradite Robert L. Vesco to the United States even though Cuba hinted after arresting him in Havana two weeks ago that it would hand him over, Administration officials said today.

title: Trial Period for Ticket Scalping
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman conditionally vetoed a bill yesterday that would have repealed the state's ban on ticket scalping. But the Governor said she was willing to test eliminating the price cap on resold tickets for an 18- month trial period to see how consumers are affected. Senator Robert W. Singer, a Republican from Ocean County, sponsor of the bill, said he would support the 18-month trial period.

title: Sports of The Times; Darryl Must Keep His Eye on Ball
description: YEARS after departing New York, Darryl Strawberry has chosen to describe his experiences with the Mets as baseball's version of a Roman orgy.

description: The Alliance Gaming Corporation, a Las Vegas-based operator of gambling machines and the owner of casinos in Mississippi and Nevada, said yesterday that it had offered to acquire Bally Gaming International, the nation's second-largest slot machine maker after International Game Technology of Reno, for more than $134 million, or $12.50 a share, in cash and stock.

title: Simpson's Shoe Size Fits Bloody Prints Left at the Crime Scene, an F.B.I. Expert Says
description: An expert from the Federal Bureau of Investigation testified today at O. J. Simpson's trial that the person who left a trail of bloody shoe prints along the walkway in front of Nicole Brown Simpson's home last June wore size 12 shoes, the same size worn by Mr. Simpson.

title: What's in a File Name? Confusion
description: A YEAR ago Windows 95 was known as Chicago and expected late in 1994. Since then a combination of curiosity, speculation, publicity and delay has made this operating system the cynosure of the computer business. Countering industry japes that the long-delayed product might not arrive before its name became history, the Microsoft Corporation has announced that Windows 95 will be available on Aug. 24, the date when Mount Vesuvius erupted in A.D. 79.

title: Newspaper Reviewed
description: The editor of New York Newsday said yesterday that an examination of the newspaper's "viability" is under way by its owner, Times Mirror Company, and that one option under consideration would be to close the New York City edition. It was the first public confirmation that Times Mirror is reviewing its commitment to the edition.

title: Pavin Permitted to Wear Giant Stamp of Approval
description: Corey Pavin knows now. When he woke up this morning, the full weight of his accomplishment hit him. Winning the United States Open on Sunday at Shinnecock Hills Golf Club did a whole lot more than fatten his bank account and clutter his trophy case. It did more than make him a hot commodity for TV chat shows and raise his appearance fee for outings.

title: International Briefs; Belgian Bank Remains In Credit Lyonnais Deal
description: Generale de Banque S.A., Belgium's largest bank, is the only suitor left in talks to buy a 94.3 percent stake in Credit Lyonnais Bank Nederland N.V. after the Dutch-Belgian financial services company Fortis A.G. said on Sunday that it had been outbid by Generale. Fortis said it was willing to pay from 10 to 15 times C.L.B.N.'s profit. That would have put the top price Fortis was prepared to pay for C.L.B.N. at around 650 million guilders ($415 million). Henjo Hielkema, chief executive of Fortis, said on Sunday that he had been told Generale's offer was "substantially higher."

title: Bernard R. Ostrow, Food Executive, 76
description: Bernard R. Ostrow, the founder and former president of a large kosher-food processing business in Newark, died on Friday at his home in West Orange, N.J. He was 76 and also lived in Delray Beach, Fla.

title: Prized Lab Shifts to More Mundane Tasks
description: ON Jan. 10, Dr. Robert W. Wilson, a co-winner of the 1978 Nobel Prize in Physics and a former astronomy wizard at AT&T Bell Laboratories, observed his 59th birthday at the South Pole, where he and other exiles from Bell Labs were using a radiotelescope to probe the structure of interstellar gas clouds.

Christine Todd Whitman's budget for the coming fiscal year that preserves the Governor's 15 percent income tax cut for 1996 and eliminates several increases in taxes and fees that Mrs. Whitman had sought. It also adds $25 million in new spending on pet projects in powerful legislators' districts.

description: Forty million dollars' worth of lobbying bought telecommunications companies a piece of Senate legislation they could relish last week. But consumers may have less to celebrate. The bill starts off right by knocking down barriers that keep telephone, cable and electrical utility companies from competing for each other's customers. But its anti-regulatory zeal goes too far, endangering the very competition the bill is supposed to create.

title: Iraq Reportedly Cracks Down On Clan That Tried a Coup
description: The Iraqi Government has begun a major purge of a rebellious army unit that attempted an uprising against President Saddam Hussein last week, arresting and executing as many as 150 soldiers and officers, say Iraqi opposition figures here and in London and Arab diplomats in Europe.

title: DICKSTEIN PROPOSAL FOR HILLS STORES WINS BACKING
description: Institutional Shareholders Services Inc., which advises large institutional shareholders on issues of corporate governance, has recommended that its clients vote for a change of control at the Hills Stores Company, according to people who have seen the report. The recommendation is likely to aid Dickstein Partners Inc., an investment group with a 14.3 percent stake in Hills, in its bid to elect four directors to the regional discount chain's board as a precursor to auctioning off the company to the highest bidder. The recommendation by Institutional Shareholders may win broader support for Dickstein's proposal. Dickstein has offered to buy the company for $27 a share in cash and new debt, but Hills has rejected the offer. Yesterday, Hills shares fell 25 cents, to $24.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Gramm, After a Torrid Start, Slips and Slides in 1996 Race
description: Nearly six months ago, when Phil Gramm was outhustling his competitors for the Republican Presidential nomination, the Texas Senator sipped an iced tea at a restaurant in Baton Rouge, La., and explained that his path to victory was based on two simple propositions.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Wait! Isn't This Backward?; Roles Reversed in U.S.-Japan Dispute on Airlines
description: In the automobile trade dispute with the United States, Japan has said it cannot accept Washington's demands, saying they add up to "managed trade." If American cars and car parts do not sell well in Tokyo, Japan says, it is simply because they are not competitive.

title: Patterson in Line for Post
description: The former heavyweight champion FLOYD PATTERSON was nominated by Gov. GEORGE E. PATAKI yesterday to be chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission. Patterson "exemplifies the hard work and determination our state needs to once again make New York the world's boxing capital," the Governor said.

title: Bosnia Mission: Can U.N. Learn From Its Failures?
description: On a freezing day in February 1994, as NATO planes waited to strike, the United Nations mission to Bosnia muddled its way to a fateful decision: Instead of collecting Serbian guns ringing Sarajevo, peacekeepers went to the Serbian gun positions to watch over them.

title: Hibernians See Vindication In Emphasis on Free Speech
description: By upholding the exclusion of a gay, lesbian and bisexual group from the St. Patrick's Day Parade in Boston, the Supreme Court vindicated the Ancient Order of Hibernians in its long-running efforts to keep a gay contingent out of the line of march in New York City, lawyers for the Hibernians said yesterday.

title: Victims' Kin Can Talk to Jurors
description: A bill allowing families of victims to speak to juries considering whether to recommend the death penalty was signed into law yesterday by Governor Whitman. Prosecutors and advocates for victims' rights had lobbied for the legislation. In the past, only relatives of the defendant were permitted to address jurors.

title: The Battle To Protect A Shipyard From Cuts
description: In the basement of his house here, surrounded by pictures of submarines, William D. McDonough, a retired Navy captain, has been waging what may be his final battle: the fight to save the 195-year-old Portsmouth Naval Shipyard.

title: Jailers Come Under Scrutiny
description: In six years, James F. Slattery built Esmor Correctional Services into the nation's fifth largest prison business as Federal and local governments turned increasingly to privatization. But after an uprising Sunday of the 300 immigrants detained at the company's Elizabeth center, Esmor has come under intense scrutiny. The Union County Prosecutor, Andrew K. Ruotolo Jr., mocked Esmor as "privatization at its worst" and has vowed to block any effort to reopen the center. [ Page A1. ]

title: Free Speech Lost in Computer Smut Vote
description: To the Editor:

title: APPLAUSE AND DAKIN TOY MAKERS TO MERGE
description: Applause Inc. and Dakin Inc., two closely held toy makers, agreed yesterday to merge in anticipation of a public offering to take place early next year. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed, but a spokesman said the merger will be through an exchange of stock. The new company, called Applause Enterprises Inc., will have revenue of more than $150 million in 1995. The new company is expected to be taken public as early as January.

title: Suspension of Gotti's Lawyer Is Upheld by Appeals Panel
description: A Federal appeals court yesterday chastised Bruce Cutler, John Gotti's lawyer, for defying a judge's order to curb his fist-waving remarks to reporters on behalf of his client, and it affirmed his sentence of three months of house arrest and suspension from practice in some Federal courts for six months.

title: Award for Rutgers President
description: Rutgers University's president, Francis L. Lawrence, the target of protests earlier this year over remarks he made about blacks, was honored by a Hispanic group at the university yesterday. Mr. Lawrence received the Hispanic Women Leadership Institute's Eagle award for his contributions to multiculturalism and leadership development. Protesters had demanded Mr. Lawrence's resignation because he said that blacks lack the "genetic, hereditary background" to score higher on standardized tests.

title: Grizzlies Name Winters
description: BRIAN WINTERS, an assistant with the Atlanta Hawks and once one of the National Basketball Association's top shooters, was hired yesterday as the first coach of the expansion Vancouver Grizzlies.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ABBOTT LABORATORIES INC., Abbott Park, Ill., entered an alliance with Arqule Inc. to speed the development of the novel drug compounds. Terms were not disclosed. FIDELITY NATIONAL FINANCIAL INC., Irvine, Calif., a title insurance underwriter,, said it planned to buy National Title Inc., Overland Park, Kan., a unit of Nations Holding Group, for $30 million in cash and stock. HOST MARRIOTT CORP., Bethesda, Md., announced the acquisition of the San Antonio Marriott Riverwalk Hotel for about $50 million.

title: Nabisco's Snackwell to Offer Yogurt
description: RJR Nabisco's successful Snackwell's line will soon branch out from the cookie and cracker aisle to the dairy case in the nation's supermarkets, when the company introduces a no-fat chocolate yogurt line this week.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Saturday about the expansion of a hotel franchise company, Hospitality Franchise Systems, misstated the given name of the chairman of the company. He is Henry R. Silverman, not Harry.

title: Critics See Humbler Origin of 'Dinosaur' DNA
description: THE dream of recovering DNA from preserved dinosaur tissue inspires serious research as well as science fiction, and last November a group of biologists reported that they had apparently hit pay dirt. But a fresh assessment of their evidence by four independent scientific teams has concluded that hunters of dinosaur DNA have not yet captured their quarry and must go back to their cloning boards for another try.

title: INSIDE
description: Cuba to Hold Vesco

title: Open for Business?
description: I recently returned from Kanazawa, Japan, where a symposium on culture and landscape was held. A delegate from Tokyo said of his country: "We are very, very rich and we are very, very poor. We have sold our souls in the name of the yen. There is no wild nature left in Japan. . . . We must look to America for environmental leadership. Perhaps now, what the United States of America has to offer the world is wilderness."

title: Hunt Manufacturing Co.(HUN,N) reports earnings for Qtr to May 28
description: b-Included an extraordinary loss of $ 1,356,000, or 9 cents a share, incurred in connection with the resignation and planned replacement of the company's chairman and chief executive and other organizational changes for the quarter and six months. Remaining related charges will be recognized over the balance of the fiscal year and total charges, including the latest quarter, will be 10 cents to 14 cents a share.c-After a gain of $ 795,000, or 5 cents a share, from an accounting change.

title: First Union Buying First Fidelity to Form Big Eastern Bank
description: In a deal that would create an Eastern banking giant stretching from Connecticut to Florida, the First Union Corporation of Charlotte, N.C., said yesterday that it would buy First Fidelity Bancorp of Newark for $5.4 billion in stock.

title: Trak Auto Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 29
Big Merger to Create Bank Giant in East
description: In a deal that will create a banking giant from Connecticut to Florida, the First Union Corporation of Charlotte, N.C., plans to buy First Fidelity Bancorp of New Jersey for $5.4 billion in stock. The combination would be the nation's sixth-largest banking company.

title: A Modern 'Rigoletto,' With Drugs and Titles
description: For the last 11 seasons, the Opera Festival of New Jersey has had a policy of performing foreign-language operas in English translation, a practice much maligned by opera purists but a defensible and valuable option. But the new season opened on Saturday with a modern-dress production of Verdi's "Rigoletto" performed in Italian with English supertitles. The trend toward supertitles is proving impossible to buck.

title: Mayor May Invoke the Fifth
description: Mayor Sharpe James of Newark has often said that he is fully cooperating with investigators examining his financial dealings. But now he has apparently decided to invoke the Fifth Amendment if he is called before a Federal grand jury. That strategy is revealed in court papers filed in a civil lawsuit tied to the Federal investigation.

title: Rite Aid Corp.(RAD,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Jun 3
Russia Allows Rebels to Leave With Hostages
description: In a severe humiliation for Russia's military and Government, a Chechen commando leader who terrorized this small Russian town and took up to 2,000 hostages was allowed to leave freely today for Chechnya after nearly all his demands had been met. He took with him his fighters and about 150 hostages.

description: Figures are in Canadian dollars.

title: Taming the School Feud
description: Following Ramon Cortines's resignation as New York City Schools Chancellor, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani insists he has the right to approve Mr. Cortines's successor. The Board of Education president, Carol Gresser, says "no way." But Mr. Cortines's departure should mark a fresh beginning rather than a new fight. It will if everyone backs off and reviews some first principles of governance.

title: Israel's Russians Organize to Win Respect
description: As Anatoly Shcharansky, he was one of the best-known "refuseniks" in the Soviet Union, until he was freed in 1986 as part of an East-West prisoner exchange.

title: Court Allows Welfare Cuts In Connecticut
description: The state's highest court ruled today that Connecticut has no constitutional responsibility to care for its poorest citizens, upholding a 1992 law that allows cities and towns to cut off welfare benefits to able-bodied individuals after nine months.

title: State-Mandate Bill Approved
description: Voters will be asked this November whether they want to change the New Jersey Constitution to make the state pay for programs it requires local governments and schools to carry out. The Assembly gave final approval yesterday to the proposed "state mandate, state pay" amendment by a vote of 77 to 0. Supporters acknowledged that even if the measure passes, lawmakers will have to decide exactly what constitutes a state mandate. TERRY PRISTIN

title: Dispute Erupts on Plans For Ancient Footprints
description: A PLAN to conserve the oldest known humanlike footprints in Africa by re-excavating them, treating the soil to eliminate encroaching root growth and other threats and then reburying the trackway has been attacked by an international group of scientists and Tanzanian Government officials.

title: By Design; Jellies: In With the Tide
description: Remember jellies? Those fishermen's sandals with clear vinyl straps that resemble jellyfish? Every 10 years or so they creep back into fashion, and they've arrived in a tidal wave.

title: Panel Sets Rules for a Prison
description: A special prison for sex offenders drew intense criticism last year after a man who had spent six years there was charged after his release with the sexual assault and killing of a 7-year-old girl, Megan Kanka. A legislative task force has recommended keeping open the Adult Diagnostic and Treatment Center at Avenal but reducing its population. The task force said sex offenders should be sent to Avenal for treatment only at the end of a prison sentence. Under the proposed legislation, all sex offenders would have to appear before a parole board before being released.

title: Dole Relents on Surgeon General Vote
description: Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the majority leader, met today with Dr. Henry W. Foster, President Clinton's nominee for Surgeon General, and relented on his threat to block a confirmation vote on Dr. Foster's nomination.

title: Public Housing Efficiency Plan, Step 1: Get New Refrigerators
description: The New York Power Authority has persuaded housing officials to throw away most of the 180,000 refrigerators in New York City's public housing units over the next nine years -- even if they are working fine. The authority will recruit manufacturers to build more efficient ones, and will provide them free to the New York City Housing Authority.

title: The Right to March in Bigotry
description: A unanimous Supreme Court has upheld the right of the private sponsors of a St. Patrick's Day parade to decide who may march with them. The South Boston Allied War Veterans Council, like the Ancient Order of Hibernians in New York City before them, may exclude a band of Irish who want to proclaim with banner and emblem that they are homosexuals and lesbians.

description: What's going on with The Baseball Network?

title: BIOCRYST STOCK FALLS ON REVISED DRUG-TEST RESULTS
description: Biocryst Pharmaceuticals Inc. Inc. shares fell 32 percent yesterday after the company said the results it announced in February for trials of its lead drug were inaccurate. A second analysis of the data found that the drug, BCX-34, did not work better than a placebo in treating the skin diseases psoriasis or cutaneous T-cell lymphoma. Biocryst shares fell $4.125, to $8.75, in Nasdaq trading. BCX-34 is an enzyme inhibitor that Biocryst thinks can be used to treat a range of disorders caused by a proliferation of T-cells. T-cells, part of the body's defense system, are used to control infection and attack disease-causing bacteria; in some inflammatory diseases, however, the T-cells attack the body's own tissue.

title: For Nonprogrammers
description: PROGRAMMING is not for most of us. It requires both excruciating attention to detail and a creative bent. Both left brain and right brain work hard.

description: b-Included a loss of $ 83,363,000, or 37 cents a share, from discontinued operations, which was from a noncash charge in the second quarter related to the final calculation of the loss on the spin-off of assets to Price Enterprises Inc.c-After income from discontinued operations of $ 2.6 million, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and $ 9,113,000, or 4 cents a share, for the nine months.d-Included merger and restructuring charge of $ 80 million, or 36 cents a share, after-tax.The increase in share earnings for the latest quarter reflected a reduction of 23.2 million outstanding shares of PriceCostco common stock beginning on Dec. 20, 1994, relating to the completion of the spin-off of Price Enterprises.

description: DARRYL SUTTER said yesterday that he is quitting as coach of the Chicago Blackhawks to devote more time to his family, saying it's the right thing to do.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the What Is Jazz? series, which opened last night at the Knitting Factory, misstated the starting time for events in the series. It is 7 P.M., not 8 P.M.

title: ATP Hits Becker With Fine
description: BORIS BECKER has been fined $20,000 for insinuating after a defeat in the Monte Carlo Open final last month that the winner, Thomas Muster, had taken drugs, the ATP Tour announced yesterday. Becker has appealed, the ATP said.

title: For Haytaian, Feisty Preview Of His Tone As Chairman
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman wanted more forceful leadership for the New Jersey Republican Party when she chose Assembly Speaker Chuck Haytaian to lead the party last Thursday, and in his first appearance as chairman-designate today, Mr. Haytaian delivered.

description: Both year-ago periods ended May 28.

It was the American Program Service, not the Public Broadcasting Service.

title: Madrid Journal; To Join Europe and Africa, Will a Tunnel Suffice?
description: Myth holds that Hercules pushed apart great rocks and pried open the passage between the Atlantic and the Mediterranean. Now a modern engineering project aims to reconnect Europe and Africa.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; A new campaign will spread the word that QVC is much more than cubic zirconia jewelry.
description: THE initials QVC in the name of the cable television home shopping network stand for quality, value and convenience. But beginning in a couple of weeks, viewers will be excused for believing they mean Quite a Voluble Channel.

title: World News Briefs; Walesa Defends Priest After Anti-Semitic Slur
description: Under fire from Polish Jews for remaining silent about anti-Semitic remarks made by a prominent Roman Catholic priest in his presence, President Lech Walesa has defended the priest as his friend.

Ticket Sales Surprisingly Strong for Some Events
description: Demand for 1996 Olympic Games tickets has been unexpectedly strong for some often-overlooked events, while thousands of tickets remain for some glamour events, including track and field, Atlanta Olympic officials said yesterday.

title: Operator of Immigration Jails Has a History of Troubles
description: James F. Slattery started small, managing a hotel on the edge of Kennedy International Airport. He kept the Riviera hotel filled through a contract with the Federal Government to absorb the overflow from immigration jails, which convinced him that the future of the lodging industry lay not with tourists but with inmates.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Just 15 months after an operation to replace her left hip, ELIZABETH TAYLOR underwent surgery yesterday to have her right hip replaced.

description: Figures are in Canadian dollars.

title: Sewers and Clean Water a Must At Border Housing, Texas Says
description: Developers of colonias, the squalid settlements that line the Texan-Mexican border, will have to provide their new residents with sewers and clean running water under a bill Gov. George Bush of Texas signed on Saturday.

title: Lift, Drag, Spin and Torque: Sending Toys Aloft
description: EACH summer, they fill the skies with aerobatic wonder. Above beaches, parks, picnic areas and just about any open space, they are like flocks of oddly shaped birds feathered in plastic, metal, cloth or wood.

title: Report on S.& L. Supervision Draws Criticism by Officials
description: A dozen current and former Government officials today questioned the accuracy of a report last year by Treasury Department officials that concluded the Government had done enough to recover money from wrongdoers at savings and loans that failed in Texas.

title: Dunkin' Donuts Begins a Review
description: Dunkin' Donuts said yesterday that it had placed its account, with billings estimated at $25 million, in review. For the last 18 years the account has been handled by Ally & Gargano in New York.

title: Light Vegetable Menu to Highlight Summer's Tomatoes
description: TOMATOES are becoming less expensive and better in quality at this time of year, and I like to use them in special tomato soups. I serve a tomato chowder as a combined first and main course in this light menu, which is vegetarian except for the chicken stock used in the soup. To make the dish vegetarian, replace the chicken stock with vegetable stock or water.

title: Students in Bias Incident Can Attend Graduation
description: In a decision that drew immediate criticism and threats of graduation-day protests by teachers and Jewish groups, Schools Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines announced yesterday that six seniors at Norman Thomas High School in Manhattan who wrote or knew about an anti-Semitic note to a teacher would be permitted to attend the graduation ceremony.

title: The One-Two Punch Of Cherries for Lamb
description: WHILE traditional dried fruits like raisins, prunes and apricots add a great deal of sweetness to an otherwise savory dish, dried cherries add something much more interesting -- a tart-sweet flavor. They are perfect in this lamb dish, and they are also a good complement to beef, pork and poultry.

title: AT&T AND BOLT BERANEK TO OFFER INTERNET SERVICES
description: The AT&T Corporation and Bolt Beranek & Newman Inc. agreed yesterday to provide businesses with services for access to the Internet. The terms of the deal were not disclosed. The companies said the venture would generate more than $120 million over three years for the BBN Planet Corporation, a unit of Bolt Beranek. AT&T, based in Basking Ridge, N.J., will supply knowledge of the communications needs of businesses, as well as physical and technical resources. Bolt Beranek, based in Cambridge, Mass., will provide the Internet services. Shares of Bolt Beranek rose $9.125, to $27.625, on the New York Stock Exchange, while shares of AT&T gained 12.5 cents, to $52.875.

title: Acquisition of Track Data
description: Global Market Information Inc. said yesterday that it had reached a nonbinding agreement in principle to buy the Track Data Corporation for 10.8 million shares, or about $50 million. Global, a New York-based provider of electronically transmitted trading information, said it would issue 10.8 million additional shares of its common stock to Barry Hertz, Track Data's sole shareholder. Track Data, which provides real-time market information, had annual revenue of $32 million in 1994, Global said.

title: Air Force Officer Is Acquitted In Downing of Army Aircraft
description: The only person to face a court-martial in the accidental shooting of two Army helicopters over Iraq last year was acquitted on all counts today, a finding that further clouded rather than resolved the question of who was responsible for an incident that killed 26 people.

title: Cultist Hijacks Japanese Jetliner, Demanding the Release of Leader
description: A member of the Aum Shinrikyo religious sect hijacked an airplane with 365 people aboard today and demanded the release of the imprisoned sect leader, official reports said.

title: House Committee Passes Anti-Terrorism Measure
description: The House Judiciary Committee today passed its anti-terrorism package, sending the legislation to the House floor for expected approval later this summer.

title: Sports of The Times; Who Profits From Tyson's Comeback?
description: ALL of a sudden, New York is the redemption capital of North America, what with the noted humanitarian George Steinbrenner giving Darryl Strawberry a second chance and the well-known altruist Don King giving Mike Tyson a new lease on life.

description: To the Editor:

title: Yankee Prospect Honored
description: Andy Fox, a top Yankee prospect, has been selected the International League hitter of the week. The 24-year-old Fox, who plays both infield and outfield for Class AAA Columbus, batted .350 with three home runs, six runs scored and nine runs batted in. In 11 games this season, Fox is hitting .371 with a .800 slugging percentage.

title: The Owner Says Price Of Pitching Is Too High
description: George Steinbrenner has seen the future of the Yankees, and he does not want to lose any of its elements. The owner, who can influence the immediate future by adding another pitcher, claimed he does not envision trading for a starter. Not while the asking price is so extravagant. Not while teams are lusting after New York's prospects.

title: Treasury Securities Prices Flat in Subdued Trading
description: Prices of Treasury securities were flat yesterday in subdued trading, as investors and dealers waited for more evidence of a slowing economy and for signals from the Fed.

title: UNION PLANTERS TO ACQUIRE CAPITAL BANCORPORATION
description: The Union Planters Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Capital Bancorporation for about $114 million in stock. Under the agreement, Union Planters will exchange 1.185 of its common shares for each share of Capital. Union Planters is a Memphis-based bank holding company with 38 subsidiaries operating 375 branches, mostly in the South. Shares of Union Planters fell 12.5 cents, to $27, on the New York Stock Exchange. Capital, a banking company based in Cape Girardeau, Mo., operates 31 branches through 6 affiliated banks. Shares of Capital fell 37.5 cents, to $29.875, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Divining the Next Act Of the Playful Dead
description: When the psychedelic movement in San Francisco was at its artistic peak in the 1960's, the Grateful Dead and others tried to turn music making back into a folk activity. At the "Acid Test" parties of the writer Ken Kesey, the line between performer and audience was erased, and both were on equal footing in one free-wheeling community. But as the years wore on, optimism faded and psychedelic musicians became rock stars, the Grateful Dead soon rose to a top position in the community and a hierarchy took shape. Today, the Dead are neither part of nor leaders of the Deadheads they play to; they are simply the axis around which that community revolves.

title: Hartford to Slow Company Role in Schools
description: After a rancorous public hearing about the future of Hartford's troubled public schools, the city's Board of Education voted late Monday to slow down a plan to give districtwide management authority to a private education company.

title: A Giant Health Care Company Is Said to Be Looking for a Buyer
description: The Metrahealth Companies, the nation's largest health care company created last year as a joint venture by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company and Travelers Inc., is looking for a buyer, insurance executives and industry analysts said yesterday.

title: Miami Player Is Suspended
description: When Miami Hurricanes linebacker JAMES BURGESS was arrested following an altercation at a dance club, the new coach, BUTCH DAVIS, acted quickly. Davis suspended Burgess yesterday for at least two games. The police charged Burgess early Monday with battery on a police officer and resisting arrest without violence.

title: Bills' Top Pick in the Fold
description: Offensive lineman RUBEN BROWN, the top draft pick for the Buffalo Bills, has agreed to a five-year contract worth $5.6 million, The Buffalo News reported yesterday.

title: Prosecutors Plan to Cut Short Their Case Against Simpson
description: Prosecutors in the O. J. Simpson case said today that they were shortening their case, in part by dropping plans for additional testimony on Mr. Simpson's violent relationship with his former wife, and could present the rest of their evidence by the end of next week.

title: U.S. Ruling May Undercut Brennan's Other Projects
description: For years, Robert E. Brennan's troubles in the securities industry have had little effect on his other business ventures or his philanthropic efforts.

title: At the Nation's Table: Miami Beach; An Art Deco Jewel Resurfaces, With Food
description: In Florida's South Beach, the trendy Art Deco district of Miami Beach, restaurants come and go. But Nemo, a new restaurant at the southernmost tip of South Beach, seems to have staying power. With its boldly designed dining room and adventurous menu, Nemo has gained a loyal following since it opened in January.

title: Sylvia Horwitz, 83, an Author Who Founded a School in Rome
description: Sylvia Laibman Horwitz, a world traveler, an author and a founder of two schools, died on Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 83.

title: Michael Greenberg Dies at 67; Gave Gloves to Poor in Winter
description: Meyer Michael Greenberg, known to the poor and homeless of New York City for a simple act of charity he performed for 30 years on its meanest street, died on Monday at Rivington House, a Manhattan nursing home. He was 67 and had lived much of his life in Greenwich Village.

title: Yesterday in Washington
description: SURGEON GENERAL NOMINEE: Senator Bob Dole said the Senate would vote at noon today on limiting debate on the nomination of Dr. Henry W. Foster Jr. to be Surgeon General. Mr. Dole said that if the motion to limit debate failed to get the 60 votes needed for approval, a second vote would be held on Thursday. If both votes fail, Mr. Dole said, Dr. Foster's nomination will be shelved.

title:
At the Nation's Table: Santa Fe, N.M.;
Serving Indian Dishes With Ritual and Flair
description: Raw pine walls, reed flute music, the scent of searing buffalo meat -- they could all be found on a visit to an American Indian's home. But they're also part of the ambiance at the Corn Dance Cafe, where simple foods are served with flourish.

description: Reacting angrily to Washington's threat of sanctions on Japanese airlines, the Japanese Government has begun planning to retaliate by blocking some flights from the United States.

description: Members of the Southern Baptist Convention, America's largest Protestant denomination and one founded in large part in defense of slavery, voted overwhelmingly in their annual meeting here today to "repent of racism of which we have been guilty" and to apologize to and ask forgiveness from "all African-Americans."

title: 'Virtual Reality' Conquers Fear of Heights
description: CHRIS KLOCK remembers the first time he was paralyzed with a fear of heights. He was just 10 years old and was climbing the stairs to the top of the Statue of Liberty. "Halfway up there's a place to look out," said Mr. Klock. "It just terrified me. I turned around and walked right down the steps."

title: Philip Morris Cites Inaccurate Statements in Its Cigarette Recall
description: The Philip Morris Companies said yesterday that the company had "erred" by making inaccurate statements about the cause of the company's unprecedented $100 million recall of more than seven billion cigarettes last month. The company also said it had overstated the severity of any medical symptoms that might have been felt by people who smoked any of the recalled cigarettes.

title: CHEMICAL BANKING RAISES DIVIDEND 14 PERCENT
description: The Chemical Banking Corporation raised its quarterly dividend 14 percent yesterday. Chemical, the nation's third-largest banking company, raised the dividend to 50 cents a share from 44 cents a share, payable on July 31 to shareholders of record on July 6. Chemical has raised its dividend four times, or a total of 66.6 percent, since March 1993. Shares of Chemical rose 75 cents, to $47.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Panel Backs Big Cuts in Plans For Environment and Safety
description: A House subcommittee approved deep cuts today in the main scientific and environmental programs at the Interior Department, slashing research money for programs including protection of endangered species and the safety of mines.

title: DOLE ENDS DELAY, MOVING TO BLOCK HEALTH NOMINEE
description: After months of delay, the Senate majority leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, has decided to bring the question of considering the nomination of Dr. Henry W. Foster Jr. as Surgeon General to the Senate floor on Wednesday, after concluding that he had the votes to block it.

title: INSIDE
description: STANLEY CUP FINALS

title: International Briefs; GEC Alsthom Cutbacks
description: GEC Alsthom, a joint venture of the General Electric Company of Britain and Alcatel Alsthom S.A. of France, said its transport division would cut 984 jobs because an order for 27 trains had been cut by 10. The company did not disclose who had reduced the order. GEC-Alsthom Transport has a total work force of 8,700. The jobs will be removed from the payroll over three years, and there will be a policy of voluntary retirement, the company said.

title: CHRONICLE
description: "I thought the job was sufficiently impossible to make it interesting," ROBERT FITZPATRICK said of his appointment yesterday as dean of Columbia University's School of the Arts. Mr. Fitzpatrick, 55, seems to relish new challenges. "I'm starting my eighth career and didn't want to do anything where I would be repeating myself," he said.

title: No Children, Please
description: To The Living Section:

title: Transactions
description: Baseball American League

title: International Briefs; Jardine Buys 9% Stake In Malaysian Car Dealer
description: Jardine Strategic Holdings Ltd. said yesterday that it had paid $180 million for a 9 percent stake in Edaran Otomobil Nasional, Malaysia's largest auto distributor. Khazanah Holdings, owned by the Malaysian Government, was the seller of the 20 million shares, Jardine said. The sale cut Khazanah's stake to 15.5 million shares.

title: FONAR SUES SIEMENS AND PHILIPS UNITS IN PATENT CASE
description: The Fonar Corporation said yesterday that it had sued units of Siemens A.G. of Germany and Philips Electronics N.V. of the Netherlands, accusing them of infringing patents covering magnetic-resonance imaging technology. The suits, which were filed on Friday in Federal District Court in Hauppauge, L.I., follow Fonar's court victory last month in a patent case involving the General Electric Company. In that case, a Federal jury awarded $110.5 million to Fonar, a maker of M.R.I. machines based in Melville. L.I., after concluding that G.E. had infringed two patents. The court has not ruled yet on a motion by G.E. to overturn the verdict. Two of the four patents at issue in the latest suits are the same as those in the G.E. trial.

title: Coffey Feels the Pain Of Two-Game Deficit
description: The red light behind the Detroit goal was glaring at the worst possible time in what was supposed to be a championship Red Wing season. Paul Coffey, who had been brought here to help supply this city with a Stanley Cup after four decades of suffering, was bent in half, face down, hitting his helmet against the ice.

title: COMPAQ INVESTS IN SPEECH-RECOGNITION COMPANY
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation said yesterday that it had invested in Purespeech Inc. as part of a plan to develop speech-recognition capability for its personal computers within a few years. Compaq did not disclose the size of its investment. Compaq, based in Houston, said speech recognition, which enables computers to follow spoken instructions instead of keyboard commands, would eventually become an important feature of computers. Purespeech, based in Cambridge, Mass., has developed a program that lets users "speak" to computers in simple sentences. Purespeech began marketing the program last year to companies offering high-volume telephone services.

title: X-Ray Technician Pleads Guilty
description: A Coast Guard petty officer has pleaded guilty to using his position as an X-ray technician to molest a dozen female recruits during medical exams. Petty Officer Franciscus M. Madigar II, who worked at a clinic at the Coast Guard Training Center, admitted at a court-martial hearing that he had fondled the women after taking unnecessary X-rays.

title: Seeking Quick Fixes, House Adopts System of Correction Days
description: The House of Representatives rang with words like "dumb," "stupid" and "silly" today as Speaker Newt Gingrich promised to undo some of the more inane regulations of the Federal bureaucracy by means of a legislative innovation he named Corrections Day.

title: CHECHEN GUNMEN WHO RAIDED TOWN RELEASE HOSTAGES
description: Chechen gunmen who terrorized a Russian town for five days returned to their homeland in a bus convoy tonight and released their last hostages in a Chechen border town.

title: Bikers' Helmets Don't Protect Against Death
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Science Times yesterday about research on testosterone referred incorrectly in some editions to the relationship between low levels of the hormone and irritability. The low levels were associated with greater irritability.

title: In Search For a Coach, Knicks Talk With Nelson
description: Don Nelson spent much of the past two seasons as an embattled Warrior. Today, he is contemplating spending the next few years of his life as an empowered Knickerbocker.

title: Harnisch Picked Apart By Persistent Phillies
description: Joe McIlvaine gives his patience a little more than a week. But after last night perhaps the Mets' general manager has run out of it.

title: In America; Paradise Lost
description: Milton is a hamlet on the western shore of the Hudson River in rural upstate New York, about 90 minutes north of New York City. It used to have a commercial strip, but that's gone now. You need a functioning sewer system to support business development. Milton got along for years with septic tanks, but they are no longer adequate and the sewage is backed up. In some areas the problem was so severe that property had to be condemned and the owners forced to move. The hamlet remains scenic, with wonderful views of the river, but jobs have vanished, property values have plummeted and Milton seems frozen in a time gone by.

title: Breast Implant Story Remains Far From Over
description: To the Editor:

title: Kirov Brings 3 Fokine Landmarks to U.S.
description: Michel Fokine's ballets are hardly unknown in the United States. Born in 1880 in St. Petersburg, Russia, Fokine became 20th-century ballet's earliest reformer, and his choreography was the mainstay of Serge Diaghilev's Ballets Russes from 1909 to 1914.

title: U.N. Peacekeepers Are Endangered Again, Not by Serbs but by the Bosnian Army
description: After weeks of intense confrontations with separatist Bosnian Serbs, United Nations peacekeepers were threatened today by forces of the Muslim-led Bosnian Government, which is zealously trying to keep secret the details of its military offensive.

title: Dowd's Winner Makes Lemaire Look Psychic
description: Jacques Lemaire is a master of using the Devils' depth to the fullest extent. Despite his team's victory in the opening game of the Stanley Cup finals against the Red Wings, he used two new players tonight in Game 2.

title: Strict Lobbying Rules Suggested For Nonprofit Organizations
description: After a second day of hearings on the business practices of the American Association of Retired Persons, senators from both parties suggested today that Congress tighten the standards for granting tax exemptions to nonprofit organizations that lobby on Capitol Hill.

title: Trump Tries to Convert 50's Style Into 90's Gold; Makeover Starts on Columbus Circle Hotel
description: It is not reliably recorded that Midas ever touched a building. But Donald J. Trump, the developer, has made a successful grab for an aging glass skyscraper on Columbus Circle, and today construction officially begins on his plan to turn the walls of the old Gulf and Western Building into gold. Gold-tinted glass, anyhow.

title: For Inmates, Class of '95 Is Last to Get Tuition From State
description: Robert Ferrara knows he is a lucky man.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-10 GUNMEN RETURN TO CHECHNYA Chechen gunmen who terrorized a Russian town for five days returned to their homeland in a bus convoy and released their last 123 hostages in a Chechen border town. A1 JAPAN AIRLINER HIJACKED A Japanese plane with 365 passengers and crew was hijacked by man claiming to be a follower of the Aum Shinrikyo sect. A1

title: Tokyo's Trade Hypocrisy
description: President Clinton's decision to impose sanctions on Japan for keeping out American cars and car parts has deflected attention from two other trade disputes in which Tokyo is in the wrong. One involves Federal Express, the other Kodak. In the Kodak case, recently disclosed Japanese documents show in detail how Tokyo helped block the American company in violation of its own laws and policies.

title: CHRONICLE
description: SHARON STONE may have misspoken last Friday when she appeared in Washington to talk about cancer. She said that she was told she had lymphoma four years ago, and that "with a lot of positive thinking and holistic healing" -- including giving up caffeine -- "I ended up testing negative several months later."

title: Food Notes
description: Filling a Need in the East 50's

title: Times Co. Deal Is Off
description: The Gannett Company said yesterday that it would not buy The Daily Commercial, a newspaper in Leesburg, Fla., from The New York Times Company. Gannett said on May 8 that it had reached an agreement in principle to buy the paper, which in 1994 sold 31,700 copies a day during the week and 34,500 on Sundays. But the companies said yesterday that they could not agree on the terms of the sale. They declined to provide further details. The Times Company, which bought The Daily Commercial in 1971, will continue to try to sell the paper, said Nancy Nielsen, a spokeswoman for the company.

title: Gooden to Meet Strawberry
description: When Darryl Strawberry's plane lands in Tampa, Fla., on Thursday, Dwight Gooden will be responsible for picking him up at the airport.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Monday about Charles Bennett, a screenwriter, misidentified the director of the 1937 movie "King Solomon's Mines," for which Mr. Bennett shared screen writing credit. The director was Robert Stevenson, not Alfred Hitchcock.

title: FIBREBOARD TO SELL ASSETS OF WOOD PRODUCTS BUSINESS
description: The Fibreboard Corporation agreed yesterday to sell nearly all the assets of its wood products business to Sierra Pacific Industries for $240 million to $250 million. The assets include about 76,000 acres of timberland in central California. Fibreboard, a building products company based in Walnut Creek, Calif., said it expected after-tax proceeds of $170 million to $180 million and said the sale should add about $75 million to $80 million, or $8.50 a share, to its net income. The company reported 1994 net income of $27 million, or $6.02 a share. Shares of Fibreboard rose $4, to $26.25, on the American Stock Exchange after the announcement. Sierra Pacific is a privately held timber company based in Anderson, Calif.

title: Cookouts a la Carte
description: Les Halles, at 411 Park Avenue South (28th Street), is offering several assortments of grill-ready meat -- sausages, brochettes, marinated chicken breasts, steaks, chops and the like -- for delivery in Manhattan.

title: Japan Says Its Economy Was Stagnant in First Quarter of Year
